Author: Collins, Stephen

Author: McCLUSKEY, UNA

Author: Blaug, Ricardo

Author: Allchin, W

Unemployment and Marriage -- The Psychological Meaning of Work

Author: Ruszczynski, Stanley11 Tavistock Instit Marital Studies, 120 Belsize Ln London NW3 England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61303581?accountid=14667

Abstract: A psychoanalytic framework is utilized to investigate some of the psychological meanings & purposes attached to particular work & work roles, & the psychological impact of the loss of these when the work activity is lost, with focus on the couple relationship. If work is used to contain certain internal needs & conflicts, redundancy or unemployment may expose them, with consequences for the nature of individual, couple, family, & social relationships. These arguments are supported drawing on data from couples seeking marital psychotherapy at the Tavistock Instit of Marital Studies in London, England, in the early 1980s. 27 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocabsshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Unemployment+and+Marriage+--+The+Psychological+Meaning+of+Work&amp;rft.au=Ruszczynski%2C+Stanley&amp;rft.aulast=Ruszczynski&amp;rft.aufirst=Stanley&amp;rft.date=1991-04-01&amp;rft.volume=5&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=19&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocabsshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Unemployment+and+Marriage+--+The+Psychological+Meaning+of+Work&amp;rft.au=Ruszczynski%2C+Stanley&amp;rft.aulast=Ruszczynski&amp;rft.aufirst=Stanley&amp;rft.date=1991-04-01&amp;rft.volume=5&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=19&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

The Contribution of Observation Training to Professional Development in Social Work

Author: Trowell, Judith1; Miles, Gillian1 Child & Family Dept Tavistock Clinic, 120 Belsize Ln London NW3 England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61644272?accountid=14667

Abstract: The uses of observational training & the learning to which it can give rise are discussed, in the context of a course involving a selected group of 10 social work tutors. The range of observations undertaken by the participants is described & their evaluations of the experience are presented. It is argued that observation is an important foundational skill in social work practice. The possible place of such training in the social work career continuum in the UK is considered. 2 Figures, 17 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=The+Contribution+of+Observation+Training+to+Professional+Development+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.au=Trowell%2C+Judith%3BMiles%2C+Gillian&amp;rft.aulast=Trowell&amp;rft.aufirst=Judith&amp;rft.date=1991-04-01&amp;rft.volume=5&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=51&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Community Care, Case Management and the Psychodynamic Perspective

Author: Biggs, Simon11 Central Council Education & Training Social Work, Saint Chad's St London WC1H 8AD England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61659688?accountid=14667

Abstract: Proposed changes to community care in the UK are summarized, arguing that case management is a key component of social work skill. Associations between marketplace interaction & the relationship between "caseness" & "care" are discussed, along with issues & psychological defenses to which case management is liable. It is hypothesized that case management is particularly susceptible to conflicts around issues of dependence, independence, & interdependence. Suggestions are made regarding the role that a psychodynamic understanding can play in addressing these problems. 31 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Community+Care%2C+Case+Management+and+the+Psychodynamic+Perspective&amp;rft.au=Biggs%2C+Simon&amp;rft.aulast=Biggs&amp;rft.aufirst=Simon&amp;rft.date=1991-04-01&amp;rft.volume=5&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=71&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

The Impact of a Volunteer Community Care Project in a Primary Health Care Setting

Author: Webber, Vivien1; Barry, Veronica; Davies, Peter; Pietroni, Patrick1 Marylebone Health Centre, 17 Marylebone Rd London NW1 5LT England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61617752?accountid=14667

Abstract: A descriptive account of the establishment of a volunteer community care program, based on patient participation, in an inner-city health center in central London, England. Using results of a questionnaire investigating patients' needs & interests, an outreach program, a befriending scheme, & a variety of patient group activities have been developed. 1 Table, 17 References. Adapted from the source document.

Counselling an Adult Survivor of Child Sexual Abuse

Author: Mold, Tim11 17 Brightside Rd, Hither Green Lewisham SE13 England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61654966?accountid=14667

Abstract: A case study of work with a female survivor of child sexual abuse is presented, drawing on a brief review of the theoretical & empirical literature. The nature of sexual abuse, from a feminist perspective, is discussed. Focus is on the complex issue of gender in the therapeutic relationship & the implications for social work are examined. 19 References. Adapted from the source document.

____________________________________________________________

Ambiguities in Post-Divorce Relationships

Author: Barnes, Gill Gorell11 Tavistock Clinic, London England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61630060?accountid=14667

Abstract: The decision for marital separation often leads to a series of ambiguous processes in family relationships as common assumptions are reorganized & reworked. Explored is how the concept of "family" changes in the minds of individual family members as each begins to construct a new story out of previously shared understandings by redefining the family as it was & projecting it as it will be. These negotiated processes of dislocation & relocation are considered in terms of attachment theory, focusing on the divorce as a family affair, involving the child's relationship with his/her parents, & the relationship between the couple. Productive ways of dealing with these ambiguities are suggested. 17 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Ambiguities+in+Post-Divorce+Relationships&amp;rft.au=Barnes%2C+Gill+Gorell&amp;rft.aulast=Barnes&amp;rft.aufirst=Gill&amp;rft.date=1991-10-01&amp;rft.volume=5&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=143&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Modern Marriage: Concepts of the Public and Private Contract

Author: Lawson, Annette11 10 Holly Lodge Gardens, London N6 6AA England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61322343?accountid=14667

Abstract: The structure of families is undergoing profound transformations. In particular, a sizable minority is delaying or rejecting marriage as the institutionally preferred arrangement of intimate heterosexual couples & for childbearing & rearing. Here, data obtained in a study involving 579 women & men in the UK are used to delineate both stable & changing beliefs about the nature of the public & private contract involved in marriage. Links are drawn between these beliefs & the relative independence of females from traditional constraints on their choices both about their own bodies & their roles as wives, mothers, & workers. It is suggested that professionals need to be particularly aware of the constraints of traditional gender roles as they work with couples in crisis. 1 Appendix, 31 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocabsshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Modern+Marriage%3A+Concepts+of+the+Public+and+Private+Contract&amp;rft.au=Lawson%2C+Annette&amp;rft.aulast=Lawson&amp;rft.aufirst=Annette&amp;rft.date=1991-10-01&amp;rft.volume=5&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=151&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Marriage, Social Policy and Social Work

Author: James, Adrian L1; Wilson, Kate1 Dept Social Policy & Professional Studies U Hull, HU6 7RX England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61639990?accountid=14667

Abstract: It is argued that social workers & marital agencies must consider both marriage & social work within the context of recent changes in social policy. Marriage & divorce are discussed here with reference to the 1989 Children Act, the recent divorce law reforms proposed by the Law Commission, & the 1989 National Health Service Community Care Act in GB. The impact of these transitions is projected to evaluate the newly redefined role of social worker as case manager, & the relationship between the statutory & independent sectors. Particular attention is paid to a couple's continuing need for access to statutory agencies & to the impact of marital problems on child-protection work. 29 References. Adapted from the source document.

____________________________________________________________

Expectations and Experiences of Marriage Today

Author: McAllister, Fiona M1; Mansfield, Penny; Dormor, Duncan J1 One Plus One/Marriage & Partnership Research Central Middlesex Hospital, Action Ln London NW10 7NS

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61310096?accountid=14667

Abstract: Analysis of demographic trends, interviews with 65 couples married in 1979 in London (England) boroughs, & attitudinal surveys reveals an ambiguity in the social perception & private experience of marriage. This ambiguity reflects recent social changes, eg, the emancipation of females (Fs), widespread divorce & the acceptance of premarital sex. Research findings confirm that marriage is problematic in that the reality of married life -- eg, its division of labor, & the amount of time available for the couple alone -- fails to meet many people's aspirations, particularly among Fs, whose desire for intimacy & a common life is especially difficult to achieve. It is concluded that practitioners should be aware of the discrepancy between expectations & reality, & between the expectations of males & Fs. 15 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocabsshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Expectations+and+Experiences+of+Marriage+Today&amp;rft.au=McAllister%2C+Fiona+M%3BMansfield%2C+Penny%3BDormor%2C+Duncan+J&amp;rft.aulast=McAllister&amp;rft.aufirst=Fiona&amp;rft.date=1991-10-01&amp;rft.volume=5&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=181&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocabsshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Expectations+and+Experiences+of+Marriage+Today&amp;rft.au=McAllister%2C+Fiona+M%3BMansfield%2C+Penny%3BDormor%2C+Duncan+J&amp;rft.aulast=McAllister&amp;rft.aufirst=Fiona&amp;rft.date=1991-10-01&amp;rft.volume=5&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=181&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

From "the Problem of Divorce" to "the Problem of Marriage"; the Sociological Work of One Plus One, Marriage and Partnership Research, 1971-1991

Author: Morgan, David11 Dept Sociology U Manchester, M60 1QD England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61316091?accountid=14667

Abstract: Examines the three main sociological studies that have emerged from the Marriage Research Centre, now One Plus One, of Central Middlesex Hospital in London, England. Study themes highlight: the understanding of marriage in processual terms, the interplays between the public & the private, the central importance of gender, & the overall shift from an understanding of divorce as a problem to one that problematizes marriage itself. 9 References. Adapted from the source document.

____________________________________________________________

On the Wrong Track: Reflections on a Failed Encounter

Author: Agass, Dick11 Scalebor Park Hospital, Burley-in-Wharfedale West Yorks England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61601486?accountid=14667

Abstract: A psychodynamic object relations model is used to analyze an unsuccessful attempt at therapy with a very damaged male in his early 40s who became more & more hostile & challenging as the work progressed. The case example permits exploration of the interpersonal dynamics of working with clients who arouse particularly uncomfortable or disturbing feelings in the practitioner, drawing on Melanie Klein's concept of projective identification (eg, see "Notes on Some Schizoid Mechanisms," reprinted in Mitchell, J. [Ed] The Selected Melanie Klein, Harmondsworth: Penguin, 1986 [1946]). It is argued that social workers cannot work effectively & may not even survive professionally unless they can understand & make creative use of their own personal responses to their work. Regular & skilled supervision, which can explore & utilize this vital area of the worker's countertransference, is a fundamental requirement for the training & professional development of practitioners. 54 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=On+the+Wrong+Track%3A+Reflections+on+a+Failed+Encounter&amp;rft.au=Agass%2C+Dick&amp;rft.aulast=Agass&amp;rft.aufirst=Dick&amp;rft.date=1992-04-01&amp;rft.volume=6&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=7&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=On+the+Wrong+Track%3A+Reflections+on+a+Failed+Encounter&amp;rft.au=Agass%2C+Dick&amp;rft.aulast=Agass&amp;rft.aufirst=Dick&amp;rft.date=1992-04-01&amp;rft.volume=6&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=7&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

The Setting of Limits: A Belief in Growth

Author: Casement, Patrick11 122 Mansfield Rd, London NW3 2JB England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61653565?accountid=14667

Abstract: An examination of pressures that social workers often experience with overdependent or demanding clients. Two case studies are presented to demonstrate what the setting of limits involves in practice & how growth can result when the frustration of a client's demands is timely & within the context of an ongoing relationship with the social worker. In The Setting of Limits: A Belief in Growth. A Commentary-1, Gillian Bridge (London School of Humanities, England) contends that this analysis is outdated & neglects one-parent families, ethnic minorities, gender issues, & the results of unemployment, inflation, & social security reductions. However, it still contains invaluable information for social workers as they reassess the nature of their roles & tasks. In The Setting of Limits: A Belief in Growth. A Commentary-2, Ravi Kohli (Middlesex Polytechnique, London, England) also challenges the relevance of these arguments for the social work practitioner of the 1990s, & recommends greater attention to social & political factors underlying individual problems. 2 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=The+Setting+of+Limits%3A+A+Belief+in+Growth&amp;rft.au=Casement%2C+Patrick&amp;rft.aulast=Casement&amp;rft.aufirst=Patrick&amp;rft.date=1992-04-01&amp;rft.volume=6&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=25&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=The+Setting+of+Limits%3A+A+Belief+in+Growth&amp;rft.au=Casement%2C+Patrick&amp;rft.aulast=Casement&amp;rft.aufirst=Patrick&amp;rft.date=1992-04-01&amp;rft.volume=6&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=25&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

The Place of Child Observation in Social Work Training

Author: Wilson, Kate11 Dept Social Policy & Professional Studies U Hull, HU6 7RX England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61629100?accountid=14667

Abstract: It is contended that child observation provides a range of opportunities for learning during the course of social work training. Examples are offered from students' work on a postqualifying, multidisciplinary course in child protection at the U of Hull, England, highlighting issues concerning the structuring of child observation training. 11 References. Adapted from the source document.

____________________________________________________________

Child Observation and Social Work Training

Author: Briggs, Stephen11 Tavistock Clinic, Belsize Ln London NW3 England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61647246?accountid=14667

Abstract: The role for child observation in social work training courses is explored, drawing on personal experiences observing infants over a two-year period & observations made by social work students. Examples of several kinds of observation are offered, & their value to the training experience is discussed. 26 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Child+Observation+and+Social+Work+Training&amp;rft.au=Briggs%2C+Stephen&amp;rft.aulast=Briggs&amp;rft.aufirst=Stephen&amp;rft.date=1992-04-01&amp;rft.volume=6&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=49&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Decisions, Tasks and Uncertainties in Child Protection Work

Author: Archer, Lesley1; Whitaker, Dorothy1 Dept Social Policy & Social Work U York, Heslington YO1 5DD England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61653496?accountid=14667

Abstract: Critical tasks for the social worker involved in child protection are identified, focusing on pressures that even experienced workers encounter when called on to make decisions in the course of such work. Discussion stems from a series of workshops with experienced, competent, specialist child protection workers in a large English city. It is concluded that a systematic approach involving asking oneself questions & seeking to answer them is effective & helps counteract inherent stressors. Ways that training, access to supervision & support, & structural solutions can be directed to establishing & maintaining such an approach are outlined. 28 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Decisions%2C+Tasks+and+Uncertainties+in+Child+Protection+Work&amp;rft.au=Archer%2C+Lesley%3BWhitaker%2C+Dorothy&amp;rft.aulast=Archer&amp;rft.aufirst=Lesley&amp;rft.date=1992-04-01&amp;rft.volume=6&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=63&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Supervision in the Face of No Cure -- Working on the Boundary

Author: Loughlin, Beverly11 Tavistock Clinic, Belsize Ln London NW3 England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61621434?accountid=14667

Abstract: The effect of child sexual abuse on professionals who work with it is discussed. It is suggested that the emotional impact of such work should not be underestimated, & that good supervision that considers the emotional impact of this & similar life crisis interventions is vital for everyone working in this field. 11 References. Anxiety and Child Protection Work in Two National Systems

Author: Cooper, Andrew11 Dept Social Work West London Instit Higher Education, 300 Saint Margarets Rd Twickenham TW1 1PT England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61612623?accountid=14667

Abstract: To complement the work of I. Menzies Lyth on socially constructed defense mechanisms ("Social Systems as a Defense against Anxiety," in Tryst, E., & Murray, H. [Eds], The Social Engagement of Social Science, London: Free Assoc Books, 1990, 439-462), a concept of the social structuring of anxiety is explored through an examination of how professional anxiety in child protection work can be understood as a function of the context in which the work takes place. A comparative study of the French & English systems of child protection (in which practitioners [N not provided] completed questionnaires evaluating a fictional case study) is used for illustrations. All child protection work will mobilize powerful unconscious fantasy & anxiety in practitioners; but differences in the relationship between the social work & legal parts of the system in France & England serve as important factors in containing or perpetuating such anxiety. Ultimately, this is about whether social workers themselves, in their various identifications with abusing families, experience the law as a benign or a punitive authority. 15 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Anxiety+and+Child+Protection+Work+in+Two+National+Systems&amp;rft.au=Cooper%2C+Andrew&amp;rft.aulast=Cooper&amp;rft.aufirst=Andrew&amp;rft.date=1992-10-01&amp;rft.volume=6&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=117&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Anxiety+and+Child+Protection+Work+in+Two+National+Systems&amp;rft.au=Cooper%2C+Andrew&amp;rft.aulast=Cooper&amp;rft.aufirst=Andrew&amp;rft.date=1992-10-01&amp;rft.volume=6&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=117&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Some Obstacles to the Effective Investigation and Registration of Children at Risk -- Issues Gleaned from a Worker's Perspective

Author: Miller, Liza Bingley1; Fisher, Terry1 Dept Social Policy & Social Work U York, Heslington YO1 5DD England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61656727?accountid=14667

Abstract: Considerable social service agency time & resources are channeled into the early stages of recognition, investigation, & assessment that lead to the decision of whether to register a child at risk of abuse. Interviews were conducted with 20 social workers about their involvement in registration decisions for 21 children who represented grave concern. Obstacles to effective investigation & decision making, the workers' knowledge base, & professional support available were measured. Results suggest that social workers need a professional support network to help manage the emotional & ethical challenges to the exercise of professional judgment that can be posed by some child protection cases. 2 Tables, 27 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Some+Obstacles+to+the+Effective+Investigation+and+Registration+of+Children+at+Risk+--+Issues+Gleaned+from+a+Worker%27s+Perspective&amp;rft.au=Miller%2C+Liza+Bingley%3BFisher%2C+Terry&amp;rft.aulast=Miller&amp;rft.aufirst=Liza&amp;rft.date=1992-10-01&amp;rft.volume=6&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=129&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Psychodynamic Theory within the Politics of Social Work Theory

Author: Payne, Malcolm11 Manchester Metropolitan U, Didsbury M20 8RR England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61593801?accountid=14667

Abstract: In an investigation of the political position of psychodynamic theory in social work, three phases of social work theoretical development are explored: the preinfluence, dominance, & alternatives phases. It is contended that a number of problems have created an insecure position for psychodynamic theory, including intense criticism of it, nontherapeutic approaches in social work, restricted training programs, poor professional communication, the novelty of newer perspectives, & poor transfer of new developments. However, strength in related occupations, the adaptiveness & inclusiveness of psychodynamic theory, & the development of postqualifying training offer continuing avenues for strengthening its political position within social work theory. 45 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Psychodynamic+Theory+within+the+Politics+of+Social+Work+Theory&amp;rft.au=Payne%2C+Malcolm&amp;rft.aulast=Payne&amp;rft.aufirst=Malcolm&amp;rft.date=1992-10-01&amp;rft.volume=6&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=141&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Process following Disaster Work

Author: Nursten, Jean11 Dept Community Studies U Reading, Berkshire RG6 2AH England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61638836?accountid=14667

Abstract: A narrative account of the dynamics of planning a research project with people who had received help from social workers at the Hungerford (England) Family Help Unit in 1987 after shootings killed, bereaved, & injured several adults & children. The problems of mounting such a study are discussed, as are the focus changes from those who were helped, to the helpers. Methods are put forward to identify forms of support needed to cope with the stress of disaster work. Finally, the value of support to practitioners is emphasized as a means of enabling them to continue in practice. 21 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Process+following+Disaster+Work&amp;rft.au=Nursten%2C+Jean&amp;rft.aulast=Nursten&amp;rft.aufirst=Jean&amp;rft.date=1992-10-01&amp;rft.volume=6&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=151&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Good Practice in the Face of Anxiety: Social Work with Girls and Young Women

Author: Brown, H C1; Pearce, J J1 School Social Work Middlesex Polytechnic, London N11 2NQ England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61648905?accountid=14667

Abstract: Interview with team leaders, area managers, & day, residential, intermediate treatment, & fostering service managers (N not provided) in an inner London, England, borough are used to develop guidelines regarding social work preventive policies in practice with girls & young women. Because the current political & social context of change offers both restrictions to & scope for change, psychodynamic theory applied in the context of feminist social work practice & a supportive supervisory climate are offered as means to better practice with this client group. 21 References. Adapted from the source document.

____________________________________________________________

A Report of an Intervention with Staff in a Hostel for People with Learning Difficulties

Author: Turton, Brian11 Middlessex U, Enfield EN3 4SF England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61596196?accountid=14667

Abstract: A description of a five-session group discussion designed to help the staff of a hostel for people with learning difficulties devise strategies to better understand the residents & their difficulties. Methods to avoid anxieties about roles, relationships, & tasks when providing residential social work in the area of learning difficulty are discussed. 4 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=A+Report+of+an+Intervention+with+Staff+in+a+Hostel+for+People+with+Learning+Difficulties&amp;rft.au=Turton%2C+Brian&amp;rft.aulast=Turton&amp;rft.aufirst=Brian&amp;rft.date=1992-10-01&amp;rft.volume=6&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=167&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=A+Report+of+an+Intervention+with+Staff+in+a+Hostel+for+People+with+Learning+Difficulties&amp;rft.au=Turton%2C+Brian&amp;rft.aulast=Turton&amp;rft.aufirst=Brian&amp;rft.date=1992-10-01&amp;rft.volume=6&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=167&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Editorial

Author: Simmonds, John11 Goldsmith's Coll U London, SE14 6NW England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61646635?accountid=14667

Abstract: Addresses the question of juvenile crime in the context of the murder in GB of two-year-old James Bulger by two children. Although the response of the British government to public outrage has been the establishment of new institutions aimed at "containment," a societal approach borrowed from social work is advocated instead, favoring reflection before action & focusing less on revenge & more on grief & mourning. Society needs to experience the appropriate feelings of despair, come to terms with the events, & try to learn something. E. Blackwell

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Editorial&amp;rft.au=Simmonds%2C+John&amp;rft.aulast=Simmonds&amp;rft.aufirst=John&amp;rft.date=1993-04-01&amp;rft.volume=7&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=3&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Editorial&amp;rft.au=Simmonds%2C+John&amp;rft.aulast=Simmonds&amp;rft.aufirst=John&amp;rft.date=1993-04-01&amp;rft.volume=7&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=3&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

The Dynamics of Difference: Poverty and Wealth

Author: Yelloly, Margaret11 Tavistock Clinic, 120 Belsize Ln London NW3 5BA England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61587500?accountid=14667

Abstract: Considers the extent of poverty in GB since WWII & argues that psychoanalysis is important in understanding the impact of poverty on personal development needs & the image of self & the ways in which gross inequalities are managed psychologically & socially. Poverty cannot be eradicated until there is agreement as to the nature of a fair society. Psychological reflections on the nature of wealth are discussed. 2 Tables, 27 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=The+Dynamics+of+Difference%3A+Poverty+and+Wealth&amp;rft.au=Yelloly%2C+Margaret&amp;rft.aulast=Yelloly&amp;rft.aufirst=Margaret&amp;rft.date=1993-04-01&amp;rft.volume=7&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=5&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=The+Dynamics+of+Difference%3A+Poverty+and+Wealth&amp;rft.au=Yelloly%2C+Margaret&amp;rft.aulast=Yelloly&amp;rft.aufirst=Margaret&amp;rft.date=1993-04-01&amp;rft.volume=7&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=5&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Pre-Verbal Communication: The Role of Play in Establishing Rhythms of Communication between Self and Other

Author: McCluskey, Una1; Duerden, Sephi1 Dept Social Policy & Social Work U York, YO1 5DD England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61638981?accountid=14667

Abstract: Discusses the implications of the infant research of Daniel N. Stern & describes Stern's theory of the child development process. Stern contended that central to the development process is "attunement," meaning that accurate attunement to the infant on the part of the caregiver facilitates the infant's exploration of the world. It requires the accurate tracking of the infant's emotional or thinking self & interactions, eg, play, which go beyond mimicking to actually add something to the situation. The usefulness of play is demonstrated by a case study of a boy age 5 exhibiting "failure to thrive syndrome" & helped to express himself through play sessions with a therapist. It is shown that the process of attunement between mother & infant can be applied to relationships between therapist & patient. 1 Table, 24 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Pre-Verbal+Communication%3A+The+Role+of+Play+in+Establishing+Rhythms+of+Communication+between+Self+and+Other&amp;rft.au=McCluskey%2C+Una%3BDuerden%2C+Sephi&amp;rft.aulast=McCluskey&amp;rft.aufirst=Una&amp;rft.date=1993-04-01&amp;rft.volume=7&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=17&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Pre-Verbal+Communication%3A+The+Role+of+Play+in+Establishing+Rhythms+of+Communication+between+Self+and+Other&amp;rft.au=McCluskey%2C+Una%3BDuerden%2C+Sephi&amp;rft.aulast=McCluskey&amp;rft.aufirst=Una&amp;rft.date=1993-04-01&amp;rft.volume=7&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=17&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

A 'Lumpy' Circle? One Punctuation in the Evolution of a Gender-Sensitive Approach in Systemic Therapy

Author: Porter, Isobel11 Child & Family Therapy Unit Preston Hospital, Preston Rd North Shields NE23 0LR England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61584291?accountid=14667

Abstract: Addresses the fact that people hold many different cultural beliefs & values & accept them as basic truths, & considers some aspects of systems theory that can incorporate the wider cultural context in developing a gender-sensitive approach in therapy. Discussion includes the concept of circularity, power relations, & the practical tools of circular questions, reframing, & positive connotation. 1 Bibliog, 24 References. Adapted from the source document.

____________________________________________________________

Delicate Liaisons: The Impact of Gender Differences on the Supervisory Relationship within Social Services

Author: Conn, Jane Dutton11 Middlesex Polytechnic, Enfield EN3 4SF England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61587446?accountid=14667

Abstract: Interviews with practitioners, & middle & senior managers (N = 18) within a Social Services Dept in London, England, reveal the impact of gender difference on social work roles & tasks, specifically within the supervisory context. Ignoring this aspect of the supervisory relationship can contribute to frequent misunderstandings & serious consequences. Discussion includes the differences that men & women bring to their work roles, the connections between the "public life" of the work context, the "private life" & psychological development of the individual, & the effect of these differences & connections on the supervisory relationship. 31 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Delicate+Liaisons%3A+The+Impact+of+Gender+Differences+on+the+Supervisory+Relationship+within+Social+Services&amp;rft.au=Conn%2C+Jane+Dutton&amp;rft.aulast=Conn&amp;rft.aufirst=Jane&amp;rft.date=1993-04-01&amp;rft.volume=7&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=41&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

The Use of Self in Experiential Learning for Cross-Cultural Awareness: An Exercise Linking the Personal with the Professional

Author: Nash, Mary

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61638938?accountid=14667

Abstract: Addresses the 1989 Children, Young Person, & Their Families Act in New Zealand, emphasizing that family disputes be settled by social workers rather than the court system, & examines social work courses at Massey U in New Zealand that teach cross-cultural sensitivity & anti-oppressive practice. Attention is given to one course assignment designed to deepen students' understanding of what family means both to them & to others. The students expressed a depth of learning demonstrated by the quality of their work & their desire to produce something of future value to their families. 6 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=The+Use+of+Self+in+Experiential+Learning+for+Cross-Cultural+Awareness%3A+An+Exercise+Linking+the+Personal+with+the+Professional&amp;rft.au=Nash%2C+Mary&amp;rft.aulast=Nash&amp;rft.aufirst=Mary&amp;rft.date=1993-04-01&amp;rft.volume=7&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=55&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Quantifying Creative Encounters: The Bumpy Road to Evaluating Psychodynamic Training

Author: Firth, Malcolm T1; Huxley, Peter J; Oliver, Joseph P J; Margison, Frank1 Dept Psychiatry U Manchester, M60 1QD England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61626206?accountid=14667

Abstract: Reports a four-year evaluation of a one-year course in psychodynamic approaches to practice for social workers at the U of Manchester, England, in terms of its effectiveness for student learning. A variety of measuring tools were employed: student diaries, multiple choice tests, questionnaires on student confidence & tutor skill, student feed-back, & self-reports. Students were required to write dissertations, which helped them apply their learning to their interests & jobs. Students showed a high degree of learning in both objective & subjective analysis. The course improved over the four years & was determined to be successful in meeting its own & student goals. 2 Tables, 1 Figure, 1 Appendix, 16 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Quantifying+Creative+Encounters%3A+The+Bumpy+Road+to+Evaluating+Psychodynamic+Training&amp;rft.au=Firth%2C+Malcolm+T%3BHuxley%2C+Peter+J%3BOliver%2C+Joseph+P+J%3BMargison%2C+Frank&amp;rft.aulast=Firth&amp;rft.aufirst=Malcolm&amp;rft.date=1993-04-01&amp;rft.volume=7&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=63&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

The Battered Social Worker: A Psychodynamic Contribution to Practice, Supervision and Policy

Author: Nathan, Jack11 356 Upland Rd, London SE22 0DP England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61603325?accountid=14667

Abstract: Case illustrations & work from recently undertaken research are used to demonstrate that a psychodynamic perspective can advance social work thinking at the practice, supervisory, & policy levels, especially at a time when undue weight is being given to a managerialist approach. A psychodynamically oriented consultation model used on a postqualifying social work course at Maudsley Hospital in GB is outlined. 12 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=The+Battered+Social+Worker%3A+A+Psychodynamic+Contribution+to+Practice%2C+Supervision+and+Policy&amp;rft.au=Nathan%2C+Jack&amp;rft.aulast=Nathan&amp;rft.aufirst=Jack&amp;rft.date=1993-04-01&amp;rft.volume=7&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=73&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Company town, company estate: Pilgrim's Rest, 1910-1932

Author: Bonner, P; Shapiro, K A

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/29649807?accountid=14667

Abstract: Transvaal Gold Mining Estates (TGME) established a company town for its white workers, and company estate for its black labour force. Describes the TGME's relationship with its respective employees and the Native Affairs Department. Reports labour relations were harmonious while company earnings remained high. Describes the collective forms of resistance that emerged post 1918.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Ametadex&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Company+town%2C+company+estate%3A+Pilgrim%27s+Rest%2C+1910-1932&amp;rft.au=Bonner%2C+P%3BShapiro%2C+K+A&amp;rft.aulast=Bonner&amp;rft.aufirst=P&amp;rft.date=1993-06-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=171&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Self-Defence Is No Offence

Author: Lousada, Julian11 Adult Dept Tavistock Clinic, 120 Belsize Ln London NW3 5BA England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61632244?accountid=14667

Abstract: Explores the extent to which the ideological project of community care legislation in GB reflects a view that social work has of itself, namely, one of denigration, arguing that self-defense can only occur in the context of a belief that there is something worth defending. The threat to social work comes from both without & within, & expresses itself in terms of: ambivalence toward social work activity; a relentless search for ideas & interventions, which is not an indication of a willingness to change but of a lack of confidence; & the adoption of an ideological stance that, far from advancing a clear political point of view, seems more concerned with minimising the anxiety & disappointment inherently associated with modesty of practice. 15 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Self-Defence+Is+No+Offence&amp;rft.au=Lousada%2C+Julian&amp;rft.aulast=Lousada&amp;rft.aufirst=Julian&amp;rft.date=1993-10-01&amp;rft.volume=7&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=103&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Empowerment and Partnership in Mental Health: Towards a Different Relationship

Author: Braye, Suzy1; Preston-Shoot, Michael1 Dept Social Policy & Social Work U Manchester, M13 9PL England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61609861?accountid=14667

Abstract: Although client empowerment & intervention partnership have become accepted principles in mental health-related social work practice, these key principles have been interpreted differently by service stakeholders, such that practicing empowerment & partnership is neither simple nor straightforward. For their potential to be realized, the principles of partnership & empowerment must be located within a conceptual framework that integrates: (1) an understanding of power, inequality, & oppression, & why these concepts are relevant to professional practice; (2) personal & organizational commitments to challenging & changing oppressive practices that maintain inequality; & (3) a practice base that will give expression to these commitments. 2 Figures, 65 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Empowerment+and+Partnership+in+Mental+Health%3A+Towards+a+Different+Relationship&amp;rft.au=Braye%2C+Suzy%3BPreston-Shoot%2C+Michael&amp;rft.aulast=Braye&amp;rft.aufirst=Suzy&amp;rft.date=1993-10-01&amp;rft.volume=7&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=115&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Psychotic Processes and Community Care: The Difficulty in Finding the Third Position

Author: Foster, Angela11 Adult Dept Tavistock Clinic, 120 Belsize Ln London NW3 5BA England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61632171?accountid=14667

Abstract: Describes a woman who is both damaged & damaging, a mental disorder that generates anxiety she cannot contain, which is passed onto the others who constitute her community. For community care to work, it must be possible within the community system to identify & manage the anxieties generated by such mental disturbance. A model of community care is proposed that encompasses mental illness, professional workers, & the community -- three elements seen as the corners of a triangular space that theoretically becomes the container of mentally disturbing anxieties, within which these anxieties can be addressed. This model could enable workers to foresee some difficulties & to address others in a manner that would lead to greater containment & more effective management of mental illness in the community. 1 Figure, 8 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Psychotic+Processes+and+Community+Care%3A+The+Difficulty+in+Finding+the+Third+Position&amp;rft.au=Foster%2C+Angela&amp;rft.aulast=Foster&amp;rft.aufirst=Angela&amp;rft.date=1993-10-01&amp;rft.volume=7&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=129&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Depression and Practice Learning in Mental Health Social Work

Author: Firth, Malcolm T11 Dept Psychiatry U Manchester, M13 9PL England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61582879?accountid=14667

Abstract: Three main areas of learning must be included in mental health social work training: connecting past & present, "being with" & "doing to," & psychiatric phenomenology. This learning emerges most actively through contact with clients whose disorders & predicaments hold echoes for the student workers; most typically, these echoes are depressive. Practice teaching introduces another element of professional disillusionment, notably a shift from ideal to real practice. Current trends in community care are observed to add a further dimension of professional blight. 22 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Depression+and+Practice+Learning+in+Mental+Health+Social+Work&amp;rft.au=Firth%2C+Malcolm+T&amp;rft.aulast=Firth&amp;rft.aufirst=Malcolm&amp;rft.date=1993-10-01&amp;rft.volume=7&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=141&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Psychotherapy with Abused Women in a Women's Agency

Author: Martin, Gill11 Tuke Centre The Retreat, York YO1 5BN England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61618062?accountid=14667

Abstract: Based on the author's experience in the Leeds (England) Women's Counselling & Therapy Service, where individual psychodynamic therapy with sexually abused women accounts for much of the work, the long-term impact of abuse & the main therapeutic issues involved in working with adult survivors are examined through case examples. After briefly describing other aspects of the agency's work, the case for treating abused women in an all-female therapeutic environment is considered. 16 References. Assessment in Adult Mental Health: Present Problems as Past History

Author: Firth, Malcolm T11 School Psychiatry & Behavioural Sciences U Manchester, M13 9PL England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61635442?accountid=14667

Abstract: Outlines a guide to professional assessment of mentally disordered adults & their relatives or care givers. The format is based on the observed & reported experiences of practitioners at pre- & postqualifying levels over 6 years whose use of, & comments on, the format have refined its development. Key texts supporting the assessment rationale, most of which remain readily available, are referred to; the purposes of assessment are discussed; & some guidance on etiological factors is indicated. After a brief consideration of the assessment format itself, an example of a psychosocial assessment report is given. Overall, the emphasis is on the practicality & simplicity of the format, not only as a means to securing essential information, but as a guide to interviewing &, in many instances, to a working alliance with clients. 1 Figure, 50 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Assessment+in+Adult+Mental+Health%3A+Present+Problems+as+Past+History&amp;rft.au=Firth%2C+Malcolm+T&amp;rft.aulast=Firth&amp;rft.aufirst=Malcolm&amp;rft.date=1994-04-01&amp;rft.volume=8&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=3&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

The Place of Procedures in Child Abuse Investigations

Author: Munro, Eileen11 London School Economics & Political Science, WC2A 2AE England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61622097?accountid=14667

Abstract: The role of formal procedures in child protection work is examined. Child abuse deaths in the past have prompted angry public criticism & pressured social work agencies to develop formal policy & procedure in handling child abuse allegations. Formalized procedures have changed the working style of social work professionals by removing autonomy & forcing them to be more explicit & critical in their assessments. Social workers have experienced difficulty in adapting to formalized procedures. Some feel their skills have been devalued, while others rely too much on procedure & believe that their professional goals have been achieved once a checklist of procedures has been completed. Procedure manuals are intended as an aid to social work practice only, & can only be effective if used by skilled & experienced professionals. They are to provide guidelines, but should be subject to criticism & to change. 16 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=The+Place+of+Procedures+in+Child+Abuse+Investigations&amp;rft.au=Munro%2C+Eileen&amp;rft.aulast=Munro&amp;rft.aufirst=Eileen&amp;rft.date=1994-04-01&amp;rft.volume=8&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=19&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=The+Place+of+Procedures+in+Child+Abuse+Investigations&amp;rft.au=Munro%2C+Eileen&amp;rft.aulast=Munro&amp;rft.aufirst=Eileen&amp;rft.date=1994-04-01&amp;rft.volume=8&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=19&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

The Birth of an Infant and the Unconscious Balance of Marriage: A Clinical Example

Author: Lugton, Susan11 25 Shakespeare Grove, Hawthorn Melbourne 3122 Australia

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61622056?accountid=14667

Abstract: Discusses problems between couples that develop, or at least become unmanageable, after the birth of a child, focusing on clinical issues that arose with a particular couple over 18 months. Described is how the birth of their second child brought to the surface the parents' own infantile needs, & how their unconscious marital choice was able to be understood in terms of their respective family histories. The theoretical concepts of projection & projective identification are considered as both defense mechanisms & communicative processes. Their effect on the interactions between the couple & the child, & the couple & the therapist are also discussed, with a view to understanding how a knowledge of projection & projective identification is relevant & useful in psychoanalytically oriented marital therapy. 17 Figures, 22 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=The+Birth+of+an+Infant+and+the+Unconscious+Balance+of+Marriage%3A+A+Clinical+Example&amp;rft.au=Lugton%2C+Susan&amp;rft.aulast=Lugton&amp;rft.aufirst=Susan&amp;rft.date=1994-04-01&amp;rft.volume=8&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=35&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Working with the Sexually Abused Child: The Use of Non-Directive Play Therapy and Family Therapy

Author: Wilson, Kate1; Ryan, Virginia1 Dept Social Policy & Social Work U York, Heslington YO1 5DD England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61627674?accountid=14667

Abstract: Argues that family therapy may be insufficient to address the needs of the sexually abused child, & that because of the nature of the impact of sexual abuse, in most instances individual therapy should be the preferred approach. The circumstances in which family therapy may be indicated are considered, together with the limitations of this therapeutic approach. The nature of the impact of child sexual abuse is explained using a framework of mental development derived from J. Piaget, & it is argued that a method of individual therapy that addresses the experience at different levels should be selected. Reasons for using one form of individual therapy, that of nondirective play therapy, are presented. 17 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Working+with+the+Sexually+Abused+Child%3A+The+Use+of+Non-Directive+Play+Therapy+and+Family+Therapy&amp;rft.au=Wilson%2C+Kate%3BRyan%2C+Virginia&amp;rft.aulast=Wilson&amp;rft.aufirst=Kate&amp;rft.date=1994-04-01&amp;rft.volume=8&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=67&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Community Care and the Social Construction of Citizenship

Author: Phillipson, Chris11 Dept Applied Social Studies U Keele, Stafforshire ST5 5BG England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61587568?accountid=14667

Abstract: Reviews issues concerning the definition of community care in the UK, & presents a theoretical framework for reviewing key developments in this area. Factors in the emergence of community care are analyzed, along with more recent developments, eg, the 1990 National Health Service & Community Care Act. Obstacles that may frustrate attempts to change both the shape & philosophy underpinning care in the community are considered. 55 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Community+Care+and+the+Social+Construction+of+Citizenship&amp;rft.au=Phillipson%2C+Chris&amp;rft.aulast=Phillipson&amp;rft.aufirst=Chris&amp;rft.date=1994-10-01&amp;rft.volume=8&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=103&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Informal Care and Dementia: Lessons for Psychoanalysis and Feminism

Author: Sayers, Janet11 Keynes Coll U Kent, Canterbury CT2 7NP

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61589943?accountid=14667

Abstract: Six case studies, based on in-depth interviews of those looking after a demented spouse at home, are presented that highlight: (1) defenses mobilized in analysts as well as in informal carers by those who are emotionally or cognitively cut off, regressed, anxious, disinhibited, or depressed; & (2) similarities & differences between the sexes in their capacity to take in & process the experience of their dependents as both similar to, & different from, their own. Implications for community care regarding the need to take account of, assess, & tailor its provision to the defensive strategies adopted by carers in looking after those who are losing their minds are discussed. 37 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Informal+Care+and+Dementia%3A+Lessons+for+Psychoanalysis+and+Feminism&amp;rft.au=Sayers%2C+Janet&amp;rft.aulast=Sayers&amp;rft.aufirst=Janet&amp;rft.date=1994-10-01&amp;rft.volume=8&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=123&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Failed Individualism in Community Care: An Example from Elder Abuse

Author: Biggs, Simon11 Dept Applied Social Studies U Keele, Staffordshire ST5 5BG England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61587509?accountid=14667

Abstract: It is argued that individualized notions of citizenship significantly affect how social actors respond to issues such as dependence, independence, interdependence, with consequences that locate unacceptable attributes within "failed individuals." This gives rise to possibilities for collusion among workers, carers, & older people who require services, & forms the basic triangle for interpersonal relations within community care policy. The parallel rise of elder abuse as a recognized social problem is considered in this light & three forms of collusive alliance, based on life-task, family solidarity, & heroic defense, are explored. The possibility of interdependence as a guiding principle that can be used to contain each actor's perspective, while contributing to the development of nonabusive relationships, is examined. 5 Figures, 27 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Failed+Individualism+in+Community+Care%3A+An+Example+from+Elder+Abuse&amp;rft.au=Biggs%2C+Simon&amp;rft.aulast=Biggs&amp;rft.aufirst=Simon&amp;rft.date=1994-10-01&amp;rft.volume=8&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=137&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Failed+Individualism+in+Community+Care%3A+An+Example+from+Elder+Abuse&amp;rft.au=Biggs%2C+Simon&amp;rft.aulast=Biggs&amp;rft.aufirst=Simon&amp;rft.date=1994-10-01&amp;rft.volume=8&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=137&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Some Thoughts on the Adoption of Anti-Racist Practice

Author: Lousada, Julian11 Adult Dept Tavistock Clinic, 120 Belsize Ln London NW3 5BA England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61637346?accountid=14667

Abstract: Uses the metaphor of adoption to explore the issues that accompany an agency's attempt to incorporate antiracist practices. Focus is on how racism insinuates itself into institutions, & on the experience of organisations that adopt antiracist practices. Racism is fundamentally underpinned by hatred & an attack on thinking; too frequently these very characteristics arise in the process, & organization, that struggles against it. If the adoption of a child is to succeed, it is necessary to come to terms with the "failure" of conception. It is suggested that the adoption of an idea, eg, antiracist practice, must contend with a similar failure, & resist the temptation to take on certainty, when the reality is one of anxiety & the unknown. 12 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Some+Thoughts+on+the+Adoption+of+Anti-Racist+Practice&amp;rft.au=Lousada%2C+Julian&amp;rft.aulast=Lousada&amp;rft.aufirst=Julian&amp;rft.date=1994-10-01&amp;rft.volume=8&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=151&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Managing Care in the Community: Analysis of a Training Workshop

Author: Foster, Angela1; Grespi, Lorenzo1 23 Essendine Rd Flat 1, London W9 2LT England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61622159?accountid=14667

Abstract: Describes a ten-week workshop that analyzed & addressed the anxieties generated in community care of the adult mentally ill & argues that anxiety containment needs be internalized by systems of care & care communities. The workshop had a fluctuating attendance (N = 25-30 carers of the mentally ill & those who make & implement related policy) & used both large- & small-group formats. The workshop experienced shifts back & forth between paranoid-schizoid position modes (ie, a focus on self & personal survival) & depressive position modes (ie, a wider focus that permitted reflection on others), but gradually progressed to the latter. It is concluded that the workshop was successful in promoting a combination of therapeutic & managerial skills & the appreciation of the complex relationships within care communities. It could serve as a model of containment to be internalized by care systems. 4 Figures, 8 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Managing+Care+in+the+Community%3A+Analysis+of+a+Training+Workshop&amp;rft.au=Foster%2C+Angela%3BGrespi%2C+Lorenzo&amp;rft.aulast=Foster&amp;rft.aufirst=Angela&amp;rft.date=1994-10-01&amp;rft.volume=8&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=169&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Reason and Emotion in Social Work Practice: Managing Relationships with Difficult Clients

Author: Howe, David1; Hinings, Diana1 School Social Work U East Anglia, Norwich Norfolk NR4 7TJ England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61615004?accountid=14667

Abstract: It is argued that in the course of its history, social work has oscillated between two contrasting views of human nature: that which views people as essentially rational vs predominantly emotional. Concentrating on the area of children & families, it is shown how current legislation & practice guidance are premised on the notion of people as essentially rational beings who are capable of discharging their social obligations & working responsibly toward agreed objectives. On this view, clients should be judged -- & treated -- according to their external performance rather than their internal motivation. It is argued that this view of human nature is overrestrictive & often self-defeating; human nature is inescapably emotional & irrational, & true justice can only be done to the human raw material of social work practice through a psychological understanding of clients in the context of their own unique developmental histories. 14 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Reason+and+Emotion+in+Social+Work+Practice%3A+Managing+Relationships+with+Difficult+Clients&amp;rft.au=Howe%2C+David%3BHinings%2C+Diana&amp;rft.aulast=Howe&amp;rft.aufirst=David&amp;rft.date=1995-04-01&amp;rft.volume=9&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=5&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Reason+and+Emotion+in+Social+Work+Practice%3A+Managing+Relationships+with+Difficult+Clients&amp;rft.au=Howe%2C+David%3BHinings%2C+Diana&amp;rft.aulast=Howe&amp;rft.aufirst=David&amp;rft.date=1995-04-01&amp;rft.volume=9&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=5&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Murder, Suicide and Violence: Impacts on the Social Worker

Author: Smith, Martin S1; Nursten, Jean P1 Buckinghamshire Social Services, Elms Verwood Rd Aylesbury HP20 2AY England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61607899?accountid=14667

Abstract: Describes the impact that working with clients who have been a danger to themselves &/or others has had on the practitioner. An analysis of 4 case studies incorporates attempts to understand behaviors presented by the clients & considers literary writings & theoretical concepts that play a useful part in this process. Coping strategies are reviewed & a plea is made for a recognition of fundamentally stressful & unsettling issues within social work practice. It is acknowledged that the process of reflecting on distressing experiences can be beneficially repeated over a number of years as the participant's powers of reflection deepen. 12 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Murder%2C+Suicide+and+Violence%3A+Impacts+on+the+Social+Worker&amp;rft.au=Smith%2C+Martin+S%3BNursten%2C+Jean+P&amp;rft.aulast=Smith&amp;rft.aufirst=Martin&amp;rft.date=1995-04-01&amp;rft.volume=9&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=15&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

The Impact of Parental Suicide on Children and Staff in Residential Care: A Case Study in the Function of Containment

Author: Ward, Adrian11 Faculty Education & Community Studies U Reading, Earley RG6 1HY England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61585442?accountid=14667

Abstract: A case study is presented of how a residential child care team handled the impact on a group of staff & children of the suicide of the mother of one of the children. A 6-year-old boy with severe emotional disturbance was admitted to residential care after living with his schizophrenic mother in an overpowering symbiotic relationship for his first 5 years. After the child had been in care for 2 years, & after his mother had made earlier self-destructive attempts, she finally committed suicide. The boy's reaction & subsequent progress are recorded, & the impact of these events on the other children in the home & on the staff working with the children is described. The context of the case study is described in terms of the aims & working methods of therapeutic residential child care, & specifically in terms of the task of containment. 17 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=The+Impact+of+Parental+Suicide+on+Children+and+Staff+in+Residential+Care%3A+A+Case+Study+in+the+Function+of+Containment&amp;rft.au=Ward%2C+Adrian&amp;rft.aulast=Ward&amp;rft.aufirst=Adrian&amp;rft.date=1995-04-01&amp;rft.volume=9&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=23&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Social Work and Resettlement

Author: Smith, Kenneth Kirk11 35 North Hill, Highgate London N6 4BS England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61564638?accountid=14667

Abstract: Describes counseling in a social work agency in London, England, that provides hostel accommodation for single homeless women, & works to resettle them into permanent accommodation. Explored is how counseling is influenced when carried on in an agency with a specific social care function vs an agency that offers counseling service alone. Examples are given of people using an attachment to a hostel, & to a worker, as they cope with change & make psychological growth. The power of such workers can only be exercised if they are true to the agency function, & gear their interventions to the task of resettlement. 9 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Social+Work+and+Resettlement&amp;rft.au=Smith%2C+Kenneth+Kirk&amp;rft.aulast=Smith&amp;rft.aufirst=Kenneth&amp;rft.date=1995-04-01&amp;rft.volume=9&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=53&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/
