Community, Care and Quality: A Lesson from Group Psychotherapy -- Making Connections in the Face of the Drive towards Fragmentation

Author: Landau, Naomi1; Wallbank, Michael1 48 Saltram Crescent, London W9 3HR

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61601546?accountid=14667

Abstract: Examines what is meant by the terms "community," "care," & "quality" in current mental health practice. Using personal experience of a successful group psychotherapy project, a creative reinterpretation is offered of the core concepts that supposedly underpin the present shift toward community-based services. A reaffirmation of the mental health practitioner's therapeutic role is called for in helping severely damaged clients to make connections -- both within themselves & beween themselves & the outside world -- at a time when the drive toward fragmentation of service provision poses an additional threat to the precarious mental health of this client group. 1 Figure, 9 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Community%2C+Care+and+Quality%3A+A+Lesson+from+Group+Psychotherapy+--+Making+Connections+in+the+Face+of+the+Drive+towards+Fragmentation&amp;rft.au=Landau%2C+Naomi%3BWallbank%2C+Michael&amp;rft.aulast=Landau&amp;rft.aufirst=Naomi&amp;rft.date=1995-04-01&amp;rft.volume=9&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=63&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Group Work Using Task-Centred Methods as a Potential Way of Helping with Maternal Depression

Author: Woodcock, Johanna11 14 Chepstow Ave, Roborough Plymouth Devon PL6 7EW England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61601506?accountid=14667

Abstract: A case study of a task-centered approach in an 8-week group therapy context with 6 depressed mothers in England. Depressed mothers are likely to suffer from low self-esteem & avoid doing achieveable tasks; the structured approach in task-centered methods allows them to focus on compartmentalizing problems, solve problems through their own action, & gain reinforcement through evaluation of results. The group approach provides a mutual aid support system & alternative tasks to consider. The group process was deemed successful. For the task-centered model to be more appropriate for this problem, a role rehearsal & assertiveness work phase should be included, & more time should be allotted because of these phases & the depressed mother's lack of confidence. 32 References. M. Pflum

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Group+Work+Using+Task-Centred+Methods+as+a+Potential+Way+of+Helping+with+Maternal+Depression&amp;rft.au=Woodcock%2C+Johanna&amp;rft.aulast=Woodcock&amp;rft.aufirst=Johanna&amp;rft.date=1995-04-01&amp;rft.volume=9&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=73&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Group+Work+Using+Task-Centred+Methods+as+a+Potential+Way+of+Helping+with+Maternal+Depression&amp;rft.au=Woodcock%2C+Johanna&amp;rft.aulast=Woodcock&amp;rft.aufirst=Johanna&amp;rft.date=1995-04-01&amp;rft.volume=9&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=73&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Social Work Intervention with Bereaved Children

Author: Hemmings, Peta11 Barnardo's Orchard Project, Orchard House Fenwick Terrace Jesmond Newcastle upon Tyne NE2 2JQ England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61593636?accountid=14667

Abstract: Proposes a short-term social work intervention model to address bereavement in childhood. The practice model considers differences in mourning between adults & children & recognizes the potential of short-term intervention for a long-term issue. Interventions include six counseling sessions with parents, six play sessions with the child(ren), & involvement by teachers. Goals include increasing sensitivity of parents to their child's experience, enhancement of child-parent communication, resource development within the child's environment, & improvement of the child's resourcefulness & sense of competence. Significant outcomes are noted in child & family well-being. An outline of literature on mourning is offered. 61 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Social+Work+Intervention+with+Bereaved+Children&amp;rft.au=Hemmings%2C+Peta&amp;rft.aulast=Hemmings&amp;rft.aufirst=Peta&amp;rft.date=1995-10-01&amp;rft.volume=9&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=109&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Developing Partnerships in Therapeutic Work with Children

Author: Ryan, Virginia1; Wilson, Kate; Fisher, Terry1 Dept Social Policy & Social Work U York, Heslington YO1 5DD England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61567226?accountid=14667

Abstract: Examines the therapeutic application of partnership principles to assist children within statutory settings. Nondirective play therapy is suggested as an effective intervention method. The concept of partnership is evaluated through various literary sources & applied to the relation between caregiver & child to enhance a supportive environment. An analysis of practice tasks focuses on involvement of carers, therapists, & social workers. Suggestions are offered to address partnership issues such as information sharing, confidentiality, & power sharing. 17 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Developing+Partnerships+in+Therapeutic+Work+with+Children&amp;rft.au=Ryan%2C+Virginia%3BWilson%2C+Kate%3BFisher%2C+Terry&amp;rft.aulast=Ryan&amp;rft.aufirst=Virginia&amp;rft.date=1995-10-01&amp;rft.volume=9&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=131&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Accounting for Self-Harm: Holding the Balance

Author: Varley, Mary1; White, Susan1 c/o White -- School Social Work U Manchester, M13 9PL England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61626293?accountid=14667

Abstract: Child care workers who encounter parents who have harmed, or threatened to harm, themselves must balance the needs of children & of parents. Assumptions about risk assessment can mask the social significance of self-harm, as illustrated by case studies. It is asserted that preventing parents from discussing the difficulties of parenthood with social workers is harmful; recommendations are offered for social workers to negotiate within the professional context. 47 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Accounting+for+Self-Harm%3A+Holding+the+Balance&amp;rft.au=Varley%2C+Mary%3BWhite%2C+Susan&amp;rft.aulast=Varley&amp;rft.aufirst=Mary&amp;rft.date=1995-10-01&amp;rft.volume=9&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=141&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Parallel Process: Emotional and Physical Digestion in Adolescents with Eating Disorders

Author: Briggs, Stephen11 Adolescent Dept Tavistock Clinic, 120 Belsize Ln London NW3 5BA England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61626249?accountid=14667

Abstract: An examination of psychoanalytical psychotherapy for adolescents with eating disorders. Two clinical examples (male & female mid-teen patients at the Adolescent Dept of the Tavistock Clinic in London, England) illustrate the importance of transference & countertransference in parallel physical & emotional processes. A comparison is offered between the patients' object relations & quality of early object relations in babies with feeding difficulties. It is concluded that therapists must consider the tendency to respond collusively to patients in countertransference, & the pattern of object relations that relate to prototypes of defensive configurations observable in early infancy. 19 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Parallel+Process%3A+Emotional+and+Physical+Digestion+in+Adolescents+with+Eating+Disorders&amp;rft.au=Briggs%2C+Stephen&amp;rft.aulast=Briggs&amp;rft.aufirst=Stephen&amp;rft.date=1995-10-01&amp;rft.volume=9&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=155&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Therapeutic Letters to, from and between Children in Family Therapy

Author: Marner, Torben11 Dept Child & Adolescent Psychiatry Hilleroed Hospital, DK-3400 Denmark

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61604046?accountid=14667

Abstract: Discusses the therapeutic use of letter writing within the context of family therapy, drawing on the work of M. White & D. Epston (1990). The use of letters written to the child by the therapist following a family session is shown to be effective in strengthening the child's efforts to overcome the problem. Examples are given of letters written by a therapist to children, of letters written by children to one another, & of letters written by a therapist & children to their teachers enlisting their support. 4 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Therapeutic+Letters+to%2C+from+and+between+Children+in+Family+Therapy&amp;rft.au=Marner%2C+Torben&amp;rft.aulast=Marner&amp;rft.aufirst=Torben&amp;rft.date=1995-10-01&amp;rft.volume=9&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=169&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

The 'Matching Principle': Exploring Connections between Practice and Training in Therapeutic Child Care. Part 1: Therapeutic Child Care and the Holding Environment

Author: Ward, Adrian11 Dept Community Studies U Reading, RG6 1HY England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61617465?accountid=14667

Abstract: A framework for recognizing the associations between social work practice & training is suggested through the "matching principle" applied in the context of therapeutic care & treatment of children in group care settings. The theoretical framework is centered on the notion of a holding environment, as illustrated by practice in family centers & therapeutic communities for children & adolescents. It is asserted that the therapeutic group care context can be coordinated through the concept of holding environment, such that principles of practice & theory can be matched in training. 18 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=The+%27Matching+Principle%27%3A+Exploring+Connections+between+Practice+and+Training+in+Therapeutic+Child+Care.+Part+1%3A+Therapeutic+Child+Care+and+the+Holding+Environment&amp;rft.au=Ward%2C+Adrian&amp;rft.aulast=Ward&amp;rft.aufirst=Adrian&amp;rft.date=1995-10-01&amp;rft.volume=9&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=177&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

The 'Matching Principle': Exploring Connections between Practice and Training in Therapeutic Child Care. Part II: The Matching Principle -- Concept and Application

Author: Ward, Adrian11 Dept Community Studies U Reading, RG6 1HY England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61593201?accountid=14667

Abstract: (See abstract of Part 1 in SOPODA 18:2.) The "matching principle" is proposed as a guideline for social work training programs, particularly in incorporating the reflection process. Elements of a holding environment can be provided in the training context by applying the matching principle in order to enhance the effectiveness of training. This is illustrated through the training program design of the therapeutic child care Master's-level program at the U of Reading, England. Examples are offered of training elements, eg, experiential groups, staff meetings, & seminars intended to match practice elements. Further applications & limitations are discussed. 6 References. Adapted from the source document.

Developing Skills in Therapeutic Communication in Daily Living with Emotionally Disturbed Children and Young People

Author: McMahon, Linnet11 Dept Community Studies U Reading, Earley RG6 1HY England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61563723?accountid=14667

Abstract: Examines opportunities for therapeutic communication with emotionally disturbed children & young people in residential homes, schools, & family centers. Building on workers' intuitive skills, a theoretical framework for therapeutic communication is illustrated by experiences of members of a Master's-level social work course offered at the U of Reading, England. The holding environment of the program is seen to support the course's emotional demands. Experiences of course members address processes of realization & symbolization in conceptualizing experience. 21 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Developing+Skills+in+Therapeutic+Communication+in+Daily+Living+with+Emotionally+Disturbed+Children+and+Young+People&amp;rft.au=McMahon%2C+Linnet&amp;rft.aulast=McMahon&amp;rft.aufirst=Linnet&amp;rft.date=1995-10-01&amp;rft.volume=9&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=199&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

On Retaining a Reflective Space: Making Sense of Interactions in Work and Work Groups

Author: Preston-Shoot, Michael11 Liverpool John Moores U, L7 4DN England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61560223?accountid=14667

Abstract: The potential of the concept of reflective space in analyzing & understanding interactions in work & work groups is examined. Dominant management discourses on work groups focus on goal setting, mission statements, & performance appraisal & planning, & neglect role relationships, task definition in individual groups, & intergroup performance, & issues of intimacy, emotion, envy, & competitiveness that may have significant impacts on individual & work group performance. Retention of a reflective space in the workplace allows individuals to step out of rigid workplace roles & examine interactions at four levels: (1) intrapersonal; (2) interpersonal; (3) sociopolitical or structural; & (4) task. Tools for retaining a reflective space include: hypothesizing, circular questions, countertransference, hunting the latitude, reversing polarity, team histories, & internal supervision. 37 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=On+Retaining+a+Reflective+Space%3A+Making+Sense+of+Interactions+in+Work+and+Work+Groups&amp;rft.au=Preston-Shoot%2C+Michael&amp;rft.aulast=Preston-Shoot&amp;rft.aufirst=Michael&amp;rft.date=1996-05-01&amp;rft.volume=10&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=9&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Maintaining the Capacity for Concern during Organisational Restructuring for Community Care

Author: Downes, Celia1; Ernst, Sheila; Smithers, Martyn1 Appletree Cottage Huttons Ambo, York Y06 7HF England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61560097?accountid=14667

Abstract: A strategy for helping the staff of social service organizations to continue meaningful service delivery to clients while coping with the change & ambiguity accompanying organizational restructuring is examined. Organizational change distracts workers from their primary tasks of dealing with clients. The purchaser-provider split can also contribute to creating organizational defenses against the pressure of clients' needs & hostility & pseudo-transactions between practitioners & clients. Meaningful engagement with clients can be facilitated through inservice training that emphasizes the concepts of holding, containment, & capacity for concern. Two modules are highlighted: (1) advanced casework, & (2) supervision, consultation, & staff development. The mirroring with the modules of process in direct work with users is illustrated & dynamic reflection processes are discussed. 36 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Maintaining+the+Capacity+for+Concern+during+Organisational+Restructuring+for+Community+Care&amp;rft.au=Downes%2C+Celia%3BErnst%2C+Sheila%3BSmithers%2C+Martyn&amp;rft.aulast=Downes&amp;rft.aufirst=Celia&amp;rft.date=1996-05-01&amp;rft.volume=10&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=25&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Internal Consultation and Child Protection Work

Author: Rushton, Alan1; Nathan, Jack1 Dept Social Work Maudsley Hospital, 101 Denmark Hill London SE5 8AZ England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61560183?accountid=14667

Abstract: Because the challenge to improve investigative & postinvestigative child protection work may be met by increasing practice consultation, a qualitative study explored how child protection consultation was provided internally in London, England, pressurized social services departments. Focus groups with 13 staff examined when & where case-based consultation took place. Obstacles to safeguarding consultation opportunities were identified. The findings indicate a need for further development of consultant posts, which are relatively new. Special attention should be paid to their status & location in the organization, consultants' training needs, & assessment of consultation skills. 15 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Internal+Consultation+and+Child+Protection+Work&amp;rft.au=Rushton%2C+Alan%3BNathan%2C+Jack&amp;rft.aulast=Rushton&amp;rft.aufirst=Alan&amp;rft.date=1996-05-01&amp;rft.volume=10&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=41&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Staff Support in Organisations Providing Therapeutic Care

Author: Sudbery, John1; Bradley, Jennifer1 School Social Work University Coll Salford, M6 6PU England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61581183?accountid=14667

Abstract: Gives an overview of the role & organization of support for staff who provide therapeutic care, with specific reference to social services departments. Reasons for providing staff care in any organization are discussed before consideration is given to the particular case of employment in agencies that provide therapeutic services. Staff care is related to three aspects of countertransference, with an emphasis on the significance of the underlying emotional dynamics in this type of organization. A case study illustrates. Organizational arrangements for staff care are considered in terms of employee assistance programs, ethical issues in staff counselling funded by employers, & manager responsibility. 56 References. Adapted from the source document.

Why Ever Do We Do It? Unconscious Motivation in Choosing Social Work as a Career

Author: Vincent, Jane11 Leeds Community & Mental Health Services Academic Unit Child & Adolescent Mental Health, 12A Clarendon Rd LS2 9NN England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61593611?accountid=14667

Abstract: Analyzes questionnaire data from 31 social work students in the UK to discuss why individuals may be unconsciously motivated to undertake such a difficult & demanding career as social work. The questionnaires included objective measures of compulsive caregiving & parentification, as well as subjective reports of early parenting experiences, including early separations from parents. Possible implications of these findings are discussed in relation to the recruitment, training, & ongoing support of social workers. 22 References. Adapted from the source document.

____________________________________________________________

Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder in Children: The Social Work Challenge

Author: Parker, Jonathan1; Randall, Peter1 Family Assessment & Support Unit U Hull, HU6 7RX England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61614736?accountid=14667

Abstract: The implications of posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) in children for social work policy, practice, & training are examined. Although a popular misconception suggests that PTSD is an adult syndrome, PTSD can result from the traumatic experience of childhood sexual abuse. PTSD in children is difficult to detect because not all survivors of childhood sexual abuse display symptoms. A traumagenic dynamic model of PSTD consists of four elements: (1) traumatic sexualization; (2) betrayal; (3) stigmatization; & (4) powerlessness. Symptoms of childhood PTSD range from persistent reexperiencing of the trauma & feelings of guilt to aggressive behavior problems & recurring nightmares. The development of childhood PTSD, case studies of the disorder, & examples of social work practice with PTSD children are discussed. 39 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Post-Traumatic+Stress+Disorder+in+Children%3A+The+Social+Work+Challenge&amp;rft.au=Parker%2C+Jonathan%3BRandall%2C+Peter&amp;rft.aulast=Parker&amp;rft.aufirst=Jonathan&amp;rft.date=1996-05-01&amp;rft.volume=10&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=71&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Social Work: One or Several?

Author: Timms, Noel11 706 Kenilworth Rd Balsall Common, Coventry CV7 7HD England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61587716?accountid=14667

Abstract: Contributes to the debate on the identity of social work, drawing on available history to consider the manifold purposes & orientations contained within social work. A simple fourfold classification of the benefits of social work is suggested & applied to common social work values & to the distinctive beliefs of the functionalist school of social work. 1 Table, 21 References. Adapted from the source document.

Black Social Work Students and Practitioners: Survival Strategies

Author: Bryan, Agnes1; Aymer, Cathy1 Dept Social Work Brunel University Coll, Twickenham Middlesex TW1 1PT England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61555422?accountid=14667

Abstract: Black social workers (BSWs) in GB occupy a precarious position in the margins of both society & social work, as contemporary discourses on self & Other & social projections of badness & madness make apparent. In response, many BSWs have adopted unprofitable professional defenses, primarily because their distorted sense of self & feelings of inferiority affect how they make life & work choices & whether they can identify & seize opportunities. Here, a process of cultural & psychological transformation is outlined, entailing a substantial reexamination of BSWs' beliefs & values, & thus, leads not only to this group's professional survival, but to its professional growth. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Black+Social+Work+Students+and+Practitioners%3A+Survival+Strategies&amp;rft.au=Bryan%2C+Agnes%3BAymer%2C+Cathy&amp;rft.aulast=Bryan&amp;rft.aufirst=Agnes&amp;rft.date=1996-11-01&amp;rft.volume=10&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=113&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Instrumentalism, Knowledge and Gender in Social Work

Author: Froggett, Lynn11 Dept Social Work U Central Lancashire, Preston PR1 2HE England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61505101?accountid=14667

Abstract: By substituting instrumental knowledge for the kind of discursive, interpretive, & reflexive knowledge on which social workers have traditionally relied, public sector managerialism, through an ideological & gendered discourse, has brought about profound cultural changes in social work organizations. But while the expectations, guidelines, & procedures developed in a managerial culture facilitate recognition of organizational objectives & allow for unambiguous transmission of information, they can also function as an alternative organizational defense against anxiety. Such environments may be damaging to those who work in them & to their clients, because they threaten the intersubjective sense-making that, at its best, has been a part of the stock-in-trade of traditional social work. 29 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocabsshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Instrumentalism%2C+Knowledge+and+Gender+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.au=Froggett%2C+Lynn&amp;rft.aulast=Froggett&amp;rft.aufirst=Lynn&amp;rft.date=1996-11-01&amp;rft.volume=10&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=119&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

The Institute as Container of Unconscious Feelings: The Therapeutic Challenge of Adolescents in Residential Care

Author: Collie, Andrew11 9 Saint Vincent's Hamlet, Brentwood Essex CM14 5QX England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61550562?accountid=14667

Abstract: It is argued that part of the reason that the failure rate among residential institutions caring for damaged adolescents in contemporary GB is so high lies in the rapidly changing social context in which such institutions operate, based on a comparative analysis of two disparate approaches to residential treatment -- a psychodynamic therapeutic community & a local authority community home. Case study data indicate that social workers can only help damaged young people at the unconscious level if they are willing & able to pay attention to unconscious communication, interpret its meaning fairly accurately, & respond appropriately. Four specific areas where action is needed if unconscious processes are to be incorporated into the therapy are identified. 13 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=The+Institute+as+Container+of+Unconscious+Feelings%3A+The+Therapeutic+Challenge+of+Adolescents+in+Residential+Care&amp;rft.au=Collie%2C+Andrew&amp;rft.aulast=Collie&amp;rft.aufirst=Andrew&amp;rft.date=1996-11-01&amp;rft.volume=10&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=129&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Psychoanalysis and the Politics of Organisational Theory

Author: Cooper, Andrew11 Dept Social Work Tavistock Clinic, 120 Belsize Ln London NW3 5BA England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61491679?accountid=14667

Abstract: Discusses the importance of a fuller engagement between psychoanalytic & sociological understandings of organizational life. Open systems theory, which is most often deployed in the psychoanalytic tradition to conceptualize the interplay between organizations & their social environment, may help explain the intersection between socially constructed defenses in social work & widespread attacks on the profession. This potential is examined in relation to the work of Talcott Parsons (1952), which is used to problematize the reductionist tendencies in the psychoanalytic tradition of organizational theory that limit the ability to explain how psychological, cultural, & political forces produce characteristic modes of collective professional consciousness. 8 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocabsshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Psychoanalysis+and+the+Politics+of+Organisational+Theory&amp;rft.au=Cooper%2C+Andrew&amp;rft.aulast=Cooper&amp;rft.aufirst=Andrew&amp;rft.date=1996-11-01&amp;rft.volume=10&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=137&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

What Ceremony of Words Can Patch the Havoc? The Vitality of Literature in the Therapeutic Encounter

Author: Smith, Martin11 Katharine Knapp House, Stretton Close Tylers Green High Wycombe Buckinghamshire HP10 8EW England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61580306?accountid=14667

Abstract: Literary passages & poems, particularly those by Sylvia Plath & Franz Kafka, have contributed to & enhanced therapeutic work with distressed & disturbed clients. Various case studies & examples from a therapeutic group are reviewed to show how literature can function as a communicator of feeling at an unconscious level & to evaluate whether literature might also serve as a defense against painful material, rather than contributing to an understanding of it. Finally, an attempt is made to understand how the healing value of literature & the arts might best be incorporated in the therapeutic encounter. 28 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=What+Ceremony+of+Words+Can+Patch+the+Havoc%3F+The+Vitality+of+Literature+in+the+Therapeutic+Encounter&amp;rft.au=Smith%2C+Martin&amp;rft.aulast=Smith&amp;rft.aufirst=Martin&amp;rft.date=1996-11-01&amp;rft.volume=10&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=147&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Psychodynamics and Empowerment in Community Mental Health

Author: Davis, Haddy11 22 Bollo Ln, Chiswick London W4 5LT England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61580258?accountid=14667

Abstract: Analyzes the relationship between psychodynamic principles & empowerment philosophy, as applied to community mental health care, by identifying essential elements of a practice model based on accountability, authority, & the interpersonal tensions that arise in everyday relationships. Since empowerment philosophy is more a system of values than a model for mental health work, it does not in itself provide an adequate framework for understanding & working with mentally disturbed individuals. However, it is demonstrated that empowerment philosophy can contribute to providing services that sustain people in the community. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Psychodynamics+and+Empowerment+in+Community+Mental+Health&amp;rft.au=Davis%2C+Haddy&amp;rft.aulast=Davis&amp;rft.aufirst=Haddy&amp;rft.date=1996-11-01&amp;rft.volume=10&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=157&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Psychodynamics+and+Empowerment+in+Community+Mental+Health&amp;rft.au=Davis%2C+Haddy&amp;rft.aulast=Davis&amp;rft.aufirst=Haddy&amp;rft.date=1996-11-01&amp;rft.volume=10&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=157&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Subject: *Empowerment; *Psychodynamics; *Community Mental Health; *Psychotherapy; Mental Illness

Developing Skills in Working Individually with Children

Author: Hindle, Debbie1; Miller, Tony1 Thorneywood Unit, Porchester Rd Nottingham NG3 6LF England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61588053?accountid=14667

Abstract: Issues encountered by social work professionals in shifting from child protection work with abused children to long-term individual work following child protection investigations were examined through discussion of the formation & operations of an individual child work consultation group (N = 6 members) that was run for three 12-week terms & allowed members to present & discuss case material twice a term. Case study materials are provided. Issues encountered by the social workers included (1) feeling incapable of making sense of what occurred during individual sessions; (2) evocation of strong feelings in workers, eg, childhood memories; (3) the conflict between the culture of the social work agency & choice of room & play materials for sessions & establishment of clear boundaries for session times; & (4) conflict between seeing child as victims vs having problems in their own right. 9 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Developing+Skills+in+Working+Individually+with+Children&amp;rft.au=Hindle%2C+Debbie%3BMiller%2C+Tony&amp;rft.aulast=Hindle&amp;rft.aufirst=Debbie&amp;rft.date=1997-05-01&amp;rft.volume=11&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=9&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Factitious Disorders by Proxy: A Trap for the Unwary

Author: Randall, Peter1; Parker, Jonathan1 Family Assessment & Support Unit U Hull, HU6 7RX England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61532718?accountid=14667

Abstract: Reviews the literature on factitious disorders by proxy. A description of the disorder & its place relative to similar disorders are provided. The epidemiology & course of the disorder are examined, & the symptoms by which it may be recognized are identified. A case study illustrates the main features of this disorder & demonstrates how easy it is for practitioners to be misled by the abuser. Finally, the prospect for successful intervention is examined, & the criteria that are associated with success are detailed. 1 Appendix, 38 References. Adapted from the source document.

Groups for Women Survivors of Childhood Sexual Abuse: The Implications of Attachment Theory

Author: Hooper, Carol-Ann1; Koprowska, Juliet; McCluskey, Una1 Dept Social Policy & Social Work U York, Heslington YO1 5DD England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61564789?accountid=14667

Abstract: Suggests that attachment theory provides a conceptual framework for understanding how groups can help women recover from childhood experiences of sexual abuse. It is proposed that some of the characteristic manifestations of childhood sexual abuse in adult survivors can be understood in attachment terms, with reference to internal working models of relationships. The role that groups (in conjunction with other forms of help & support) can play in the recovery process through influencing internal working models is considered. The relative merits of short-term, long-term, professionally led, & self-help groups are discussed. 34 References. Adapted from the source document.

____________________________________________________________

A Response to "Psychoanalysis and the Politics of Organisational Theory"

Author: Blackwell, Dick

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61520847?accountid=14667

Abstract: Responds to Andrew Cooper's article (1996 [see abstract 9706708]) discussing the incorporation of the psychoanalytic theory of organizations into mainstream sociology through the work of Talcott Parsons. Cooper's use of a structural functionalist approach & Parsons's nondialectical perspective of society suggests that organizations operate in relative social harmony, &, though he identifies the political dimension of deprofessionalization in the management of anxiety, that element of his applied model lays the framework for, at best, only a one- or two-dimensional analysis. In contrast, Sigmund Freud's traditional psychoanalytic model has roots in the dialectical tradition of German philosophy & suggests that individuals are in dialectical opposition to institutions that can emerge in myriad complex transactions. The relationship of the traditional psychoanalytic model to social work & health service is discussed. 4 References. D. Generoli

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocabsshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=A+Response+to+%22Psychoanalysis+and+the+Politics+of+Organisational+Theory%22&amp;rft.au=Blackwell%2C+Dick&amp;rft.aulast=Blackwell&amp;rft.aufirst=Dick&amp;rft.date=1997-05-01&amp;rft.volume=11&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=41&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocabsshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=A+Response+to+%22Psychoanalysis+and+the+Politics+of+Organisational+Theory%22&amp;rft.au=Blackwell%2C+Dick&amp;rft.aulast=Blackwell&amp;rft.aufirst=Dick&amp;rft.date=1997-05-01&amp;rft.volume=11&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=41&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

The End as a Means to Growth -- Within the Social Work Relationship

Author: Nursten, Jean P11 Dept Community Studies U Reading, Earley RG6 1HY England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61553717?accountid=14667

Abstract: Explores the meaning & outcome of the ending of professional relationships, focusing on social workers & their clients. It is taken that endings in such relations may reawaken earlier losses. Considered is the teaching of the topic at preprofessional stages & during social work courses for under- & postgraduates. Examples of students' practice in GB illustrate how endings may demonstrate growth through the experience. 9 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=The+End+as+a+Means+to+Growth+--+Within+the+Social+Work+Relationship&amp;rft.au=Nursten%2C+Jean+P&amp;rft.aulast=Nursten&amp;rft.aufirst=Jean&amp;rft.date=1997-11-01&amp;rft.volume=11&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=73&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Education Social Work with a Traveller Woman

Author: Nickson, Kathleen1; Sudbery, John1 Traveller Education Service, Denton Town Hall Market St M34 2AP England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61528968?accountid=14667

Abstract: Draws on case records for a Traveller woman & her children, supplemented with semistructured interviews with 50 Gypsies & case providers in GB, to show how education-related social work draws on a continuously evolving casework tradition. Casework description illustrates that practical & environmental help is intimately bound up with therapeutic help for the entire family, & that problems facing an individual Gypsy can only be understood in the context of current social policy affecting all Travellers. Examining how certain concepts have a culturally specific signification in Gypsy life, it is argued that the effective delivery of both practical & psychotherapeutic help requires an understanding of the ethnic & cultural context. Implications for social work in a new century are discussed. 1 Table, 37 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Education+Social+Work+with+a+Traveller+Woman&amp;rft.au=Nickson%2C+Kathleen%3BSudbery%2C+John&amp;rft.aulast=Nickson&amp;rft.aufirst=Kathleen&amp;rft.date=1997-11-01&amp;rft.volume=11&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=91&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Hearing Voices, Talking Difference: A Dialogic Approach to Anti-Oppressive Practice

Author: Turney, Danielle11 Goldsmiths' Coll, London SE14 6NW England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61581582?accountid=14667

Abstract: Discusses the centrality of the idea of antioppressive practice to social work & the difficulty of its implementation in social work education, training, & practice. It is suggested that hermeneutic philosophy may have some contribution to make to social work thinking & practice, & that a conception of practice grounded in a theory of dialogic understanding may help practitioners frame a more adequate response to situations of oppression & inequality. The underlying hermeneutic framework is outlined & the potential contribution of a dialogic model of understanding to a developing antioppressive practice in social work is discussed, highlighting a connection between the dialogic approach associated with Gadamerian hermeneutics & the politics of empowerment articulated by the black feminist writer Patricia Hill Collins (1991). 43 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Hearing+Voices%2C+Talking+Difference%3A+A+Dialogic+Approach+to+Anti-Oppressive+Practice&amp;rft.au=Turney%2C+Danielle&amp;rft.aulast=Turney&amp;rft.aufirst=Danielle&amp;rft.date=1997-11-01&amp;rft.volume=11&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=115&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Hearing+Voices%2C+Talking+Difference%3A+A+Dialogic+Approach+to+Anti-Oppressive+Practice&amp;rft.au=Turney%2C+Danielle&amp;rft.aulast=Turney&amp;rft.aufirst=Danielle&amp;rft.date=1997-11-01&amp;rft.volume=11&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=115&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Thinking the Unthinkable: 'White Liberal' Defences against Understanding in Anti-Racist Training

Author: Cooper, Andrew11 Tavistock Clinic, 120 Belsize Ln London NW3 5BA England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61581544?accountid=14667

Abstract: Draws on 10 years' teaching experience to analyze a range of group processes that occurred during antiracist training workshops with qualifying social work students in GB. The principal focus is to understand white students' defenses against authentic learning about their own anxieties regarding black colleagues, & how such anxieties will be an obstacle to the possibility of a depth engagement with racism, unless they are surmounted. 11 References. Adapted from the source document.

____________________________________________________________

A Response to 'Factitious Disorders by Proxy: A Trap for the Unwary'. Parent Induced Illness, Factitious Illness by Proxy (Munchausen by Proxy)

Author: Trowell, J1; Miles, G1 Tavistock Clinic, 120 Belsize Ln London NW3 5BA England

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61525849?accountid=14667

Abstract: Expands on Peter Randall & Jonathan Parker's (1997 [see abstract 98W28506]) review of the literature on factitious illness (ie, Munchausen Syndrome by Proxy), describing some of its clinical presentations & implications for health care & social work practitioners. Case examples of parents inducing illness in their children include illness presenting as neurological problems, diabetes, gastrointestinal problems, & physical injury. It is noted that such abuse cases often involve strong & convincing parental denial, an unsuspecting pediatrician, & disagreement, splitting, & paranoid projections among involved professionals; however, treatment by a multidisciplinary team is recommended over that by an individual. 11 References. E. Blackwell

Assessment for adoption: The child's perspective

Author: Aves, Corinne

____________________________________________________________

Relationship-Based Thinking and Practice in Social Work

Author: Howe, David11 School Social Work U East Anglia, Norwich NR4 7TJ UK

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61572233?accountid=14667

Abstract: Social worker-client relationships are increasingly seen in procedural, legal, & administrative terms. However, research studies examining both client satisfaction & intervention effectiveness regularly find that the psychosocial qualities of the worker-client relationship are a major component in the success or otherwise of the service offered. It is argued here that the psychological selves of both practitioners & users acquire many of their characteristics, including personality, esteem, efficacy, & defensive behaviors, in relationships developed throughout the lifespan. The level of social understanding & social competence that people develop depends on the quality of their relationship history. If poor relationships are where psychosocial competences go awry, then good relationships are where they are likely to recover. Implications for the quality, character, & skill of the relationship experiences offered to clients by social workers are considered. 33 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Relationship-Based+Thinking+and+Practice+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.au=Howe%2C+David&amp;rft.aulast=Howe&amp;rft.aufirst=David&amp;rft.date=1998-05-01&amp;rft.volume=12&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=45&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

The Mistreatment of Elderly People

Author: Pugh, Steve

____________________________________________________________

Managing Conflict: A Psychodynamic Approach to Understanding Court Welfare Practice

Author: Pollard, Rachel11 U Manchester, 5th Floor, Crawford House, Precinct Centre, Oxford Rd, Manchester, M13 9QS tel/fax: 0161-275-2864/2281

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61637862?accountid=14667

Abstract: Examines how family court welfare practice (an area of probation service) is affected by the organizational & institutional context in which it operates, particularly the tensions of being managed by the probation service & being accountable both to that organization & the civil courts. One of the main sources of tension & conflict for welfare officers is that their work involves contact with people, both adults & children, experiencing profound emotional distress while the organizational & institutional context in which they work denies & represses the emotional content of such experience. Further tension is found in daily confrontation with families & individuals facing unbearable personal pain & acting on behalf of a system that, if not directly responsible for that pain, at least indirectly contributes to it by failing to address the social & economic deprivation that exacerbates family distress. Welfare officer coping strategies are discussed, highlighting the notion of more training & knowledge acquisition. In this light, a psychodynamic approach to court welfare practice is presented as a means for officers to gain insight into the organizational & institutional context in which they work. 25 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Managing+Conflict%3A+A+Psychodynamic+Approach+to+Understanding+Court+Welfare+Practice&amp;rft.au=Pollard%2C+Rachel&amp;rft.aulast=Pollard&amp;rft.aufirst=Rachel&amp;rft.date=1999-05-01&amp;rft.volume=13&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=19&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Managing+Conflict%3A+A+Psychodynamic+Approach+to+Understanding+Court+Welfare+Practice&amp;rft.au=Pollard%2C+Rachel&amp;rft.aulast=Pollard&amp;rft.aufirst=Rachel&amp;rft.date=1999-05-01&amp;rft.volume=13&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=19&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Variations on a scream: A journey through post-traumatic stress disorder

Author: Smith, Martin

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/217570926?accountid=14667

Abstract: None available.

____________________________________________________________

Defending Social and Health Services under Threat: Questions and Strategies

Author: Levitt, Louis1; Beckerman, Aaron H; Johnson, Paul1 Yeshiva U, Wurzweiler School of Social Work, Belfer Hall, 2495 Amsterdam Ave, New York, NY 10033-3299

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61648385?accountid=14667

Abstract: Discusses IMPACT 97, an interdisciplinary conference in New York City, 1997, aimed at the collection & dissemination of data documenting harm being done by cutbacks in health & social services. It was partly inspired by an international conference held earlier in the year in GB on the human services crisis. Both conferences demonstrated that interdisciplinary collaboration was possible; could result in the collection & dissemination of key social data; & could receive practitioner, key organization, & funding support. Considered here is how to defend social & health services, addressing why the social work profession & its services are under attack, what can be done, what forces are shaping its future, & how practitioners can take part in that. The intent is to look for parallels that can inspire mutual support in dealing with the increasingly intolerable situation of US & British social work. 28 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Defending+Social+and+Health+Services+under+Threat%3A+Questions+and+Strategies&amp;rft.au=Levitt%2C+Louis%3BBeckerman%2C+Aaron+H%3BJohnson%2C+Paul&amp;rft.aulast=Levitt&amp;rft.aufirst=Louis&amp;rft.date=1999-05-01&amp;rft.volume=13&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=59&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

The Psychological Impact of Migration: Practice Considerations in Working with Hispanic Women

Author: Leon, Ana M1; Dziegielewski, Sophia F1 U Central Florida, School of Social Work, PO Box 163358, Orlando, FL 32816-3358 tel/fax: 407-823-2114/5697

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61658225?accountid=14667

Abstract: Presents challenges experienced by Hispanic women who migrate to the US, where they are placed in an unfamiliar & sometimes conflictual cultural context. Existing literature is used to emphasize the importance of integrating aspects of the Hispanic culture in delivering therapeutic services to these women. Psychological problems resulting from the migration experience are identified, & the use of defense mechanisms such as idealization is highlighted. The interdependent relationship between culturally sensitive practice & clinical diagnosis is explored. Therapeutic group sessions are presented as one way to help these immigrant women develop mutual support systems, increase their self-esteem, resolve difficulties produced by the migratory experience, identify community resources, & increase parenting skills. Future applications of this type of intervention model are suggested. 66 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=The+Psychological+Impact+of+Migration%3A+Practice+Considerations+in+Working+with+Hispanic+Women&amp;rft.au=Leon%2C+Ana+M%3BDziegielewski%2C+Sophia+F&amp;rft.aulast=Leon&amp;rft.aufirst=Ana&amp;rft.date=1999-05-01&amp;rft.volume=13&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=69&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Quantifying Creative Encounters: Part Two

Author: Firth, Malcolm T1; Moss, Steve; Margison, Frank1 Central Manchester Healthcare NHS Trust, Manchester Royal Infirmary, Oxford Rd, Manchester M13 9BX, UK

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61610538?accountid=14667

Abstract: A postqualifying course in psychodynamic approaches to practice used a competence approach to evaluation of course & training outcomes. Here, Part Two of an evaluation (Part One, 1993) focuses on 14 core competences identified by expert practitioners as being central to psychodynamic practice & to analysis of training outcomes. Scale data from 64 students, ages 26-54, were highly variable, although the trend toward improvement in skill & confidence was clear, most markedly over the final phase. While this suggested overall course effectiveness, factor analysis failed to identify any more specific discrimination of skill components. More evident were global judgments of competence, by tutors in particular. As with other competence-based training programs, comparing assessments of competence with actual therapeutic outcomes might advance the identification & evaluation of practitioner competence. 2 Tables, 2 Figures, 1 Appendix, 16 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Quantifying+Creative+Encounters%3A+Part+Two&amp;rft.au=Firth%2C+Malcolm+T%3BMoss%2C+Steve%3BMargison%2C+Frank&amp;rft.aulast=Firth&amp;rft.aufirst=Malcolm&amp;rft.date=1999-05-01&amp;rft.volume=13&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=93&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Links between Infant Observation and Reflective Social Work Practice

Author: Briggs, Stephen11 Adolescent Dept, Tavistock Clinic, London, UK

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61642619?accountid=14667

Abstract: Explores the contribution made by infant observation procedures (observing a baby 1 hour weekly in the home for 2 years) to social work in three areas: (1) social work training; (2) understanding human interaction in areas of social work concern (eg, parent-child interaction, child abuse & protection); & (3) practice in specific areas of social policy. The notion that the method of infant observation has a key contribution to make to the underlying methods, attitudes, & performance of social workers is explored through a study of the links between infant observation & the two concepts of "the reflective practitioner" & "social space." These contributions to effective social work practice are in opposition to the currently dominant legalistic, procedural, & competency-driven paradigm. 38 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Links+between+Infant+Observation+and+Reflective+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.au=Briggs%2C+Stephen&amp;rft.aulast=Briggs&amp;rft.aufirst=Stephen&amp;rft.date=1999-11-01&amp;rft.volume=13&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=147&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Links+between+Infant+Observation+and+Reflective+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.au=Briggs%2C+Stephen&amp;rft.aulast=Briggs&amp;rft.aufirst=Stephen&amp;rft.date=1999-11-01&amp;rft.volume=13&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=147&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

____________________________________________________________

Supervision of Fear in Social Work. A Re-Evaluation of Reassurance

Author: Smith, Martin11 Katherine Knapp House, Stretton Close, Tylers Green, Bucks, UK

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61639701?accountid=14667

Abstract: Acknowledges the crucial importance of supervision to social work practice with reference to a study in which 61 employees of UK social services departments were interviewed with regard to times when they had experienced fear in their work. One question they were asked was "What responses would you like from an ideal supervisor to whom you took an experience of fear?" Answers revealed that participants wanted a supervisor to "be there" for them, have time for them, & listen without criticism. Understanding, acknowledgment, recognition, validation, affirmation, & confirmation of the supervisee were also thought to be important. Detailed descriptions given by two of the interviewees convey a sense of the fears they experienced & the impact of these fears. What they subsequently found helpful in their processing of the fears is also described. In light of these findings, the function of reassurance in the supervisory relationship is discussed. 23 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Supervision+of+Fear+in+Social+Work.+A+Re-Evaluation+of+Reassurance&amp;rft.au=Smith%2C+Martin&amp;rft.aulast=Smith&amp;rft.aufirst=Martin&amp;rft.date=2000-05-01&amp;rft.volume=14&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=17&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Supervision+of+Fear+in+Social+Work.+A+Re-Evaluation+of+Reassurance&amp;rft.au=Smith%2C+Martin&amp;rft.aulast=Smith&amp;rft.aufirst=Martin&amp;rft.date=2000-05-01&amp;rft.volume=14&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=17&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Learning from Personal Experience: Reflexions on Social Work Practice with Mothers in Child and Family Care

Author: Sheppard, Johanna11 Dept Social Policy & Social Work, U Plymouth, Devon, UK

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61622063?accountid=14667

Abstract: Attempts to show how using a reflexive approach can make it possible to develop a better understanding of the experiences of mothers subject to child & family social work intervention. The author's own experience of motherhood is drawn on to show the ideological assumptions behind the professionals' responses to the problems & challenges of parenting. This situation is explored through a critical analysis of dominant assumptions underlying some psychological literature & child care policies, focusing on their failure to address social disadvantage as a factor in parenting. An illustrative example from social work practice is presented in the light of this analysis. Offered in conclusion is an examination of how the reflexive consideration of personal experience, dominant ideas, & practice can help to provide a deeper understanding of the dilemmas of parenthood for families subject to child & family care intervention. 47 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Learning+from+Personal+Experience%3A+Reflexions+on+Social+Work+Practice+with+Mothers+in+Child+and+Family+Care&amp;rft.au=Sheppard%2C+Johanna&amp;rft.aulast=Sheppard&amp;rft.aufirst=Johanna&amp;rft.date=2000-05-01&amp;rft.volume=14&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=37&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Social Work -- A Shifting Paradigm

Author: Skerrett, Debbie11 Leaving Care Team, London, UK

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61647802?accountid=14667

Abstract: Explores the changing role of social work in the context of community care legislation, the political era, & the resulting care management process, using Thomas S. Kuhn's (1970 edition) concept of paradigms. It is suggested that social work values & theories, in the context of the current environment, are creating a shift in the social welfare paradigm & social work practice. It is proposed that there is a fundamental conflict between the traditional values & model of social work & the evolving care management role that social workers are assuming, which is creating an identity crisis for social work professionals. Social work is in a state of transition & crisis; to redefine itself, it needs to consolidate its basis for being. Social work needs to realign itself with its value base -- to put the client first, before the state or its own professional interests -- or it is in danger of becoming simply an agent of the state, rather than a service striving for equality & the welfare of its communities. To do this, the profession needs to clarify its purpose, define whom it is serving, & determine how it proposes to move forward. 24 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Social+Work+--+A+Shifting+Paradigm&amp;rft.au=Skerrett%2C+Debbie&amp;rft.aulast=Skerrett&amp;rft.aufirst=Debbie&amp;rft.date=2000-05-01&amp;rft.volume=14&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=63&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

Stumbling towards Oblivion or Discovering New Horizons? Observations on the Relationship between Social Work Education and Practice

Author: Preston-Shoot, Michael11 Liverpool John Moores U, UK m.prestonshoot@livjm.ac.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61496678?accountid=14667

Abstract: What should social work education be training students for? What should the relationship be between social work education & practice? The first half of this article cautions that social work education, as currently constituted, may "unfit" people. Principally, this is because social work practice, as envisaged by employer interests, has not been subject to the same critical scrutiny as social work education & has come to dominate perceptions of the training task. The dangers that follow from this position are outlined. The second half of the article proceeds to explore the contribution that practice teachers & tutors can make to enable practitioners to remain confident, credible, critical, & creative in this practice environment. The article concludes with some observations on the future as envisaged in the proposals to modernize social services & create a General Social Care Council. 53 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Stumbling+towards+Oblivion+or+Discovering+New+Horizons%3F+Observations+on+the+Relationship+between+Social+Work+Education+and+Practice&amp;rft.au=Preston-Shoot%2C+Michael&amp;rft.aulast=Preston-Shoot&amp;rft.aufirst=Michael&amp;rft.date=2000-11-01&amp;rft.volume=14&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=87&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Stumbling+towards+Oblivion+or+Discovering+New+Horizons%3F+Observations+on+the+Relationship+between+Social+Work+Education+and+Practice&amp;rft.au=Preston-Shoot%2C+Michael&amp;rft.aulast=Preston-Shoot&amp;rft.aufirst=Michael&amp;rft.date=2000-11-01&amp;rft.volume=14&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=87&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Self and Social Work: Towards an Integrated Model of Learning

Author: Ruch, Gillian11 Dept Social Work Studies, U Southampton, Highfield, UK g.m.ruch@soton.ac.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61504461?accountid=14667

Abstract: My experiences as a social work practitioner, DipSw tutor, & research student form the basis for this article, which uses a narrative, auto-ethnographic approach to illustrate the complexities & potential of reflective learning. A theoretical account of the nature of reflective learning & the reflection process is outlined before an autobiographical account, which provides an example of the reflective learning process. The key themes of holistic approaches to learning, the significance of the self & multiple subjectivities, the personal in the professional, & the importance of attending to the process & content of learning are explored. Examples of shortcomings in the current learning environment are included & drawn on to highlight the potential for more reflective approaches within the DipSw tutorial system. I suggest that given the anxiety-provoking nature of the situations they face, student practitioners need to embrace reflective learning if they are to avoid becoming restrictive, routinized, & ritualistic in their practice. 66 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Self+and+Social+Work%3A+Towards+an+Integrated+Model+of+Learning&amp;rft.au=Ruch%2C+Gillian&amp;rft.aulast=Ruch&amp;rft.aufirst=Gillian&amp;rft.date=2000-11-01&amp;rft.volume=14&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=99&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

8008: The Measures of a Competent Child Care Social Worker?

Author: Cooper, Barry11 Bristol Social Services Dept, Staff Training & Development Section, Barton Hill, Bristol, UK barry_cooper@bristol-city.gov.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61458996?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper reflects upon some mixed messages found in recent consultation & framework documents that have been issued as part of the debate surrounding the government's emphasis upon education & training within its "modernization" agenda. It identifies the long-standing arguments about "testing" vs "learning" or "contextual" paradigms & suggests that, perhaps there is still scope to influence the future direction of social work. The author has drawn upon his research with social workers & their team managers in current postqualification award programs to argue for a renewed emphasis upon the interpersonal & relationship aspects of educational processes within more broadly conceived sociocultural contexts. A focus upon reflexively defined concepts of "engagement" & "assessment" is used to explore constructivist arguments that locate individuals within an interplay of potential & constraints. It is argued that constructive engagements within revised conceptions of assessment can form the basis of a framework of continuing professional development that starts from & develops the unique realities of social work practice. This requires the committed involvement of more people, in the negotiation of a professional practice agenda for knowledge creation through relationships, rather than the imposition of more measures. 37 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=8008%3A+The+Measures+of+a+Competent+Child+Care+Social+Worker%3F&amp;rft.au=Cooper%2C+Barry&amp;rft.aulast=Cooper&amp;rft.aufirst=Barry&amp;rft.date=2000-11-01&amp;rft.volume=14&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=113&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Exporting the Tavistock Model to Social Services: Clinical Consultative and Teaching Aspects

Author: Canham, Hamish11 Tavistock Clinic, Child & Family Dept, London, UK

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61458826?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper describes how the author setup a child psychotherapy service within a social services department to provide support for clients & workers. The model of work employed is based on the application of psychoanalytic ideas. Aspects of the service developed are outlined including the range & type of clinical work & consultation undertaken. The particular focus of this paper is how the difficulties of the client group can infect the workers. There is a description of a year-long course based on the Tavistock child psychotherapy model, which has been run for social services staff. This course has been designed to help workers make sense of & cope with the extremely painful situations that confront them when working with a severely deprived client population. Adapted from the source document.
