Teaching Psychology to Social Workers: Dilemmas of Programme Design

Author: Mayhew, John11 Liverpool John Moores U, UK

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61458306?accountid=14667

Abstract: The discipline of psychology can be defined by specifying its content. This can be done by listing its various subdisciplines. Such a listing provides the basis for examining some of the dilemmas associated with choice of content & the depth to which the content is to be taught. Psychology can also be defined as a product of history & a history that has taken place in a certain cultural context. The dominant context has been that of the university, which has sought to emphasize the importance of a scientific & empirical approach. The limitations of this approach are identified & discussed along with those of (solely) conceptual approaches that are found in more practical spheres like those of counseling & psychotherapy. Finally, relating psychology to other disciplines provides another perspective on its essential nature. With the nature of the discipline in mind, some consideration is given to the psychology of learning applied psychology. 47 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Teaching+Psychology+to+Social+Workers%3A+Dilemmas+of+Programme+Design&amp;rft.au=Mayhew%2C+John&amp;rft.aulast=Mayhew&amp;rft.aufirst=John&amp;rft.date=2000-11-01&amp;rft.volume=14&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=135&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Teaching+Psychology+to+Social+Workers%3A+Dilemmas+of+Programme+Design&amp;rft.au=Mayhew%2C+John&amp;rft.aulast=Mayhew&amp;rft.aufirst=John&amp;rft.date=2000-11-01&amp;rft.volume=14&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=135&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Subject: *Psychology; *Counseling; *Psychotherapy; *Academic Disciplines

Title: Teaching Psychology to Social Workers: Dilemmas of Programme Design

Winning Hearts and Minds? -- Emotional Labour and Learning for Care Management Work

Author: Gorman, Helen11 Faculty Health & Community Care, U Central England Birmingham Helen.Gorman@uce.ac.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61504519?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper is based on empirical research into the skill needs of care managers & examines the legacy of care management & the effect that "new managerialist" approaches have had on care management work. The concept of emotional labor is used in context & applied to the work of care managers where the ultimate aim is quality outcomes for users of services. The paper argues that recognizing the validity of the concept of emotional labor in context relates to the need for a greater acknowledgment of the skills required by care managers. "Soft skills" that involve improving own learning & performance through reflection, problem solving, & working with others are the key skills required for complex care management work. A rationale is made for reconsidering competency approaches to training in favor of continuing professional development. A preferred approach is one that emphasizes both the personal & professional aspects of learning & the social world of the learner. 2 Figures, 37 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Winning+Hearts+and+Minds%3F+--+Emotional+Labour+and+Learning+for+Care+Management+Work&amp;rft.au=Gorman%2C+Helen&amp;rft.aulast=Gorman&amp;rft.aufirst=Helen&amp;rft.date=2000-11-01&amp;rft.volume=14&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=149&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Creating a Space for Reflection on Teaching: The 1997-99 Department of Human Relations Work Discussion Groups

Author: Price, Heather S11 Dept Human Relations, U East London, Essex h.s.price@uel.ac.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61459115?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article presents an overview of three staff development projects whose aim was to provide university staff with a reflective space in which to share their experiences of teaching psychosocial studies & social work to a large, heterogeneous body of students. Aspects of the staff-student relationship are discussed. The author aims to show how staff & students could have similar expectations & experiences in these subject areas in a "new" university; but also widely divergent ones. It is argued that "quality" resides in the staff-student relationship, & in the goodwill & commitment of each to articulate together their understanding of the material to be learned. On the basis of the success of the projects, a case is made for the value of a self-reflexive "work discussion" space for teaching practitioners. 19 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Creating+a+Space+for+Reflection+on+Teaching%3A+The+1997-99+Department+of+Human+Relations+Work+Discussion+Groups&amp;rft.au=Price%2C+Heather+S&amp;rft.aulast=Price&amp;rft.aufirst=Heather&amp;rft.date=2000-11-01&amp;rft.volume=14&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=159&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

The Psycho-Social Subject in 'Evidence-Based Practice'

Author: Hollway, Wendy11 Open U, Milton Keynes, UK

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61469759?accountid=14667

Abstract: I provide a theoretical outline, followed by two case examples, of a qualitative method called the free association narrative interview that produces evidence congruent with the kinds & contexts of knowledge that human service professionals use in their work. I focus on qualitative methods & the shortcomings of semistructured interviewing as an alternative method for evidence-based practice & argue that the theory of the research subject & the research relationship that is assumed in most qualitative methods is misguided & affects the character of the evidence produced. I outline an alternative theory of the (research) subject, a psychosocial subject, drawing on psychoanalytic concepts that emphasize unconscious conflict, defenses against anxiety, & the centrality of unconscious intersubjective dynamics in the research, as in other, relationships. Two examples illustrate the approach. I conclude by arguing that the kind of evidence illustrated here, being congruent with the vicissitudes of most human service professionals' work with clients, could provide a model for evidence-based practice that is not only more appropriate but also helpful for professional development. 16 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=The+Psycho-Social+Subject+in+%27Evidence-Based+Practice%27&amp;rft.au=Hollway%2C+Wendy&amp;rft.aulast=Hollway&amp;rft.aufirst=Wendy&amp;rft.date=2001-05-01&amp;rft.volume=15&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=9&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Black on Black Encounters: Exploring Some Psychological and Political Processes among Black Professionals and Students in Black-Only Support Groups

Author: Bryan, Agnes

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61467401?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article examines the issues for black professionals in welfare organizations & black students in higher education as we interact with each other as black people. It offers a blend of empirical description & theorizing of the group dynamics that occur as black professionals & black students interrelate in black-only groups. It shows how diverse & complex the issues are & invites us to rethink the notion of "black identity." the politics of identity is the politics of how individuals & members of minorities perceive themselves (as opposed to the hegemony that society might impose on them). The struggle for hegemony is played out not only on a national or international stage but also between groups & individuals within groups. 13 References. Adapted from the source document.

Shit is Good: Mental Health Social Work with Lives of Squalor

Author: Smith, Stephen

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61467137?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper investigates the phenomenon of three clients living in squalor, all with severe & enduring mental health problems, who are on the caseload of a mental health social work team. By thinking about the clients both individually & as a group, within a psychoanalytic framework, it attempts to understand their squalor in a new way, with particular regard to the transference & countertransference experienced by the practitioner. By making use of social work literature as well as that concerning organizations & community care, it also discussed the impact that these clients make on the wider community & examines some of the dilemmas faced by the practitioner. The implications for social work are serious & far-reaching; these are discussed with regard to long-term intervention as well as professional & personal scrutiny. 15 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Shit+is+Good%3A+Mental+Health+Social+Work+with+Lives+of+Squalor&amp;rft.au=Smith%2C+Stephen&amp;rft.aulast=Smith&amp;rft.aufirst=Stephen&amp;rft.date=2001-05-01&amp;rft.volume=15&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=37&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

The Terrors of Night and the Arrows of Day. Social Workers' Processes in the Aftermath of Murder

Author: Smith, Martin11 Buckinghamshire Social Services Emergency Duty Team, Tylers Green, UK msmith@buckcc.gov.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61467150?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper provides extended extracts from interviews conducted with three social workers as part of a study inquiring into social workers' experiences of stress. For the purposes of this study, experienced practitioners were asked to recall a time that stood out in their minds as causing them stress. They were asked to describe the experience itself, how it had affected them, how they responded to it, & what they had found helpful & unhelpful when attempting to deal with it. The three participants all talked of their involvement with service users who had killed others. They described personal & organizational responses to the murders & told of internal processes & responses from others that were found to be helpful & unhelpful. The haunting quality of such experiences is apparent throughout the accounts, as is the relevance of psychodynamic theory & concepts. The importance of creating & using a therapeutic space in which it is possible to have ideas about how such stress can be addresses is emphasized. 19 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=The+Terrors+of+Night+and+the+Arrows+of+Day.+Social+Workers%27+Processes+in+the+Aftermath+of+Murder&amp;rft.au=Smith%2C+Martin&amp;rft.aulast=Smith&amp;rft.aufirst=Martin&amp;rft.date=2001-05-01&amp;rft.volume=15&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=57&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=The+Terrors+of+Night+and+the+Arrows+of+Day.+Social+Workers%27+Processes+in+the+Aftermath+of+Murder&amp;rft.au=Smith%2C+Martin&amp;rft.aulast=Smith&amp;rft.aufirst=Martin&amp;rft.date=2001-05-01&amp;rft.volume=15&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=57&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Reflective Practice in a Process for the Re-Approval of ASWs: An Exploration of Some Inevitable Resistance

Author: Jordan, Ruth; Parkinson, Clare

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61523090?accountid=14667

Abstract: In this article, a mental health trainer & a group facilitator explore the background to developing a new protocol to manage the reapproval of mental health social workers in an inner London borough. The new procedure involved social workers attending a series of small group sessions in which they were invited to present & reflect on their work with clients. The dynamics of these sessions &, in particular, some of the transferential material between group members & facilitator are explored here. The significance for mental health social work, postqualifying learning, & the possibilities of reflective practice is considered. 22 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Reflective+Practice+in+a+Process+for+the+Re-Approval+of+ASWs%3A+An+Exploration+of+Some+Inevitable+Resistance&amp;rft.au=Jordan%2C+Ruth%3BParkinson%2C+Clare&amp;rft.aulast=Jordan&amp;rft.aufirst=Ruth&amp;rft.date=2001-05-01&amp;rft.volume=15&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=67&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Reflective+Practice+in+a+Process+for+the+Re-Approval+of+ASWs%3A+An+Exploration+of+Some+Inevitable+Resistance&amp;rft.au=Jordan%2C+Ruth%3BParkinson%2C+Clare&amp;rft.aulast=Jordan&amp;rft.aufirst=Ruth&amp;rft.date=2001-05-01&amp;rft.volume=15&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=67&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

____________________________________________________________

The Duty to Care and the Need to Split

Author: Foster, Angela

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61439188?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper arises out of psychoanalytically oriented consultancy to teams of staff in the helping professions where there is a statutory "duty to care." It takes as its premise the seemingly paradoxical hypothesis that workers may need to split off part of their emotional experience in order to preserve their own mental health & provide reliable services to their clients. I argue that while a professional duty to care requires us to be emotionally "in touch," the demands of our clients & of the institutional response to the duty to care cause us to split off parts of our awareness. I also argue that, provided the splitting does not become extreme, we are doing no more or less than the rest of society; ie, there is a degree of "normal splitting" that numbs our awareness of danger & destructiveness & seeks to protect us from to much anxiety & pain. Yet if professional workers are charged with the responsibility of assessing risk & acting accordingly for the protection of all concerned, they need ways of being "in touch," illustrating the difficulty & the pain of reintegrating the splits, & offering insights that can arise out of this work with examples from my consultancy work. 13 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=The+Duty+to+Care+and+the+Need+to+Split&amp;rft.au=Foster%2C+Angela&amp;rft.aulast=Foster&amp;rft.aufirst=Angela&amp;rft.date=2001-05-01&amp;rft.volume=15&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=81&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=The+Duty+to+Care+and+the+Need+to+Split&amp;rft.au=Foster%2C+Angela&amp;rft.aulast=Foster&amp;rft.aufirst=Angela&amp;rft.date=2001-05-01&amp;rft.volume=15&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=81&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Managing the Process of Change in Residential Child Care: A Consultancy Approach

Author: Watson, David1; West, Janice1 Glasgow Caledonian U, UK

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61523134?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article explores the impact of a consultancy undertaken with groups of residential child care staff within a large local authority who were experiencing considerable changes in their working environment as a result of a review of residential care structures. The authors were invited to engage directly with staff on an individual & group basis to help them work through the barriers they perceived to changing their approach to practice. The theoretical underpinning for the work was Charles Handy's (1993) belief that change is more likely to have a positive outcome when staff have an investment in & contribution to the change processes. The model of change utilized in the sessions with staff was Kurt Lewin's three stages of "unfreezing," "change," & "refreezing." The consultancy raised a number of issues about the process of change & how this can be achieved within the residential child care context. In particular, it highlighted the problems of assuming that change is a linear process that can be directly controlled & managed in the flux & uncertainty that characterize this sector. In Commentary on "Managing the Process of Change in Residential Child Care: A Consultancy Approach," Stephen Briggs looks at a number of questions that were raised in his mind about the process of change in this instance. He emphasizes the primary requirement of supervision in helping adolescents work through the issues involved in such changes. 21 References. Adapted from the source document.

____________________________________________________________

Racialising Emotional Labour and Emotionalising Racialised Labour: Anger, Fear and Shame in Social Welfare

Author: Gunaratnam, Yasmin1; Lewis, Gail1 School Health & Social Welfare, Open U, Milton Keynes, UK

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61475374?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper brings together the empirical work of Yasmin Gunaratnam with hospice social workers & that of Gail Lewis with local authority social workers. It uses a conceptually expanded notion of "emotional labor" to explore & theorize links between different forms of emotion management & racialized subject positions & practices in social care for both those categorized as "ethnic minorities" & as "white." The analytic framework draws upon the political scholarship of Audre Lorde & Thandeka & the psychoanalytic work of Melanie Klein to explore talk about the production of anger, fear, & shame. A common focus in the writing of these different authors is the self/other relation & the attention given to personal, interpersonal, inter-group, & intra-group dynamics. The paper argues that the irrational & unconscious aspects of racial dynamics cannot simply be countered by appeals to the rational. There is a need to recognize & integrate rather than "split" positive & negative emotions about the self & "others." Such integration is seen as a source of internal strength & psychic health making for the possibility of caring & constructive relationships in social care organizations through which the complexities of difference can be recognized & valued. 42 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Racialising+Emotional+Labour+and+Emotionalising+Racialised+Labour%3A+Anger%2C+Fear+and+Shame+in+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.au=Gunaratnam%2C+Yasmin%3BLewis%2C+Gail&amp;rft.aulast=Gunaratnam&amp;rft.aufirst=Yasmin&amp;rft.date=2001-11-01&amp;rft.volume=15&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=131&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530120090593

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Racialising+Emotional+Labour+and+Emotionalising+Racialised+Labour%3A+Anger%2C+Fear+and+Shame+in+Social+Welfare&amp;rft.au=Gunaratnam%2C+Yasmin%3BLewis%2C+Gail&amp;rft.aulast=Gunaratnam&amp;rft.aufirst=Yasmin&amp;rft.date=2001-11-01&amp;rft.volume=15&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=131&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530120090593

____________________________________________________________

'He's Not My Carer -- He's My Husband': Personal and Policy Constructions of Care in Mental Health

Author: Henderson, Jeanette11 School Health & Social Welfare, Open U, Milton Keynes, UK jeanette.henderson@open.ac.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61467365?accountid=14667

Abstract: The construction of "care" in the professional & UK legislative & policy arenas has been the focus of much interest in recent years. A growing awareness of the needs of "carers" in their own right & a recognition of the conflicting needs of "carers" & users of services informs practice in health & social care where discourses of care focus on "care" as duty, burden, & responsibility. The complexity of the roles & tasks that make up the lived experience of someone who "cares" for & about another is well documented, especially in the areas of older people & physical disability. This paper seeks to locate individual experiences of "care" in mental health alongside the construction of "care" in mental health policy & legislation within the UK. The paper draws both on preliminary research with couples, & an analysis of the development of "care" in policy & law. This dual analysis indicates that, while practitioners in health & social care recognize the needs of people who consider themselves to be "carers," not all people subscribe to the identity of "carer" or "cared for" in their relationship. 32 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=%27He%27s+Not+My+Carer+--+He%27s+My+Husband%27%3A+Personal+and+Policy+Constructions+of+Care+in+Mental+Health&amp;rft.au=Henderson%2C+Jeanette&amp;rft.aulast=Henderson&amp;rft.aufirst=Jeanette&amp;rft.date=2001-11-01&amp;rft.volume=15&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=149&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530120090601

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=%27He%27s+Not+My+Carer+--+He%27s+My+Husband%27%3A+Personal+and+Policy+Constructions+of+Care+in+Mental+Health&amp;rft.au=Henderson%2C+Jeanette&amp;rft.aulast=Henderson&amp;rft.aufirst=Jeanette&amp;rft.date=2001-11-01&amp;rft.volume=15&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=149&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530120090601

Emotional Labour in the Classroom: A Psychoanalytic Perspective

Author: Price, Heather11 School Social Sciences, U East London, Dagenham, Essex, UK h.s.price@uel.ac.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61529113?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article explores the nature of the emotional labor that teachers perform in their daily professional lives. It reviews the work of the sociologist Arlie Hochschild in order to assess how applicable her account of the nature of emotional labor is to the world of the classroom. It suggests that her account focuses on emotional labor as exploitative, &therefore ignores its rewarding dimensions. It argues that the Object Relations psychoanalytic tradition offers a richer account of emotional life in general & emotional labor in particular. Object Relations theory is applied to describe the emotional labor of the teacher. Four observations of teachers at work in their classrooms are presented & analyzed. The article aims to show how the unconscious dynamics of recognition & mis-recognition underpin success or failure at effective teaching & learning in the classroom. 19 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Emotional+Labour+in+the+Classroom%3A+A+Psychoanalytic+Perspective&amp;rft.au=Price%2C+Heather&amp;rft.aulast=Price&amp;rft.aufirst=Heather&amp;rft.date=2001-11-01&amp;rft.volume=15&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=161&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530120090610

____________________________________________________________

Nurture, Bureaucracy and Re-Balancing the Mind and Heart

Author: Rogers, Anita M11 School Health & Social Welfare, Open U, Milton Keynes, UK

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61481476?accountid=14667

Abstract: With increasing managerialism & bureaucratization in the caring professions, where the focus of attention is directed primarily to the techno-rational, the instrumental, & the impersonal, care becomes labor in the service of economy, efficiency, & effectiveness. Relying on the work of psychodynamic theorists, the first part of this paper offers a critical analysis of selected "snapshots of practice" demonstrating the costs of abdicating emotion & nurture in the care process. The second part of the paper describes an 18-month cooperative inquiry involving women practitioner/students in health, social care, & education. The study highlights the quest for meaning & significance in learning & work & the process of rebalancing the mind & heart in the context of the bureaucratic organization as one of heroic dimensions. Establishing a sustained community of care yielded a renewed sense of direction & creative action among participants. 27 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Nurture%2C+Bureaucracy+and+Re-Balancing+the+Mind+and+Heart&amp;rft.au=Rogers%2C+Anita+M&amp;rft.aulast=Rogers&amp;rft.aufirst=Anita&amp;rft.date=2001-11-01&amp;rft.volume=15&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=181&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530120090629

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Nurture%2C+Bureaucracy+and+Re-Balancing+the+Mind+and+Heart&amp;rft.au=Rogers%2C+Anita+M&amp;rft.aulast=Rogers&amp;rft.aufirst=Anita&amp;rft.date=2001-11-01&amp;rft.volume=15&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=181&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530120090629

____________________________________________________________

Working with Neglected Children and Their Families

Author: Turney, Danielle1; Tanner, Karen1 Goldsmiths Coll, U London, UK d.turney@gold.ac.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61476641?accountid=14667

Abstract: Child neglect has proved a particularly difficult area for social work to address. In the first part of the paper, a number of reasons for this are discussed. We go on to suggest that chronic child neglect characteristically involves the breakdown or absence of a relationship of care. Therefore, the social work response needs to include a focus on the relationship difficulties between parent & child which manifest as either an unwillingness or inability on the part of the primary carer to offer reliable, adequate care, & on broader relationship difficulties within the family. In arguing for an approach that pays attention to the intra-personal & relational dynamics of neglect, we draw specifically on attachment theory & consider how Ainsworth's (1978) typology of attachment patterns can shed light on parenting styles & patterns of family functioning associated with chronic neglect. We use the concept of the "internal working model" to develop an understanding of the ways in which family members understand & live out their relationships -- with each other & with the worker. We conclude by suggesting that this relational approach requires an ability on the part of the social worker to work both with & within relationships, & look at the contribution that a critically informed relationship-based approach can make to work with families where child neglect occurs. 60 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Working+with+Neglected+Children+and+Their+Families&amp;rft.au=Turney%2C+Danielle%3BTanner%2C+Karen&amp;rft.aulast=Turney&amp;rft.aufirst=Danielle&amp;rft.date=2001-11-01&amp;rft.volume=15&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=193&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530120090638

____________________________________________________________

Michael, Part One: A Boy of Twelve in Conflict with the School Authorities

Author: O'Neill, Sylvia

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61481495?accountid=14667

Abstract: A single case, brought to a seminar led by the author, is presented here to illustrate a dual focus inherent in the social work task. The core of the social work task is the process by which, in the course of an ongoing dialogue, the social worker's independent point of view is brought into relation to the immediate preoccupations & point of view of the client(s). In the case illustration, that of a boy with school behavior problems, the family presented itself implicitly, but with a persuasive sense of closure, as a mother-&-son two-person family. The social worker thought beyond this to the question of a father (& a father's authority) as a significant line of inquiry. A detailed account is given of the process, calling for tact & a finely tuned sense of relevance, by which she bridged the two points of view. 2 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Michael%2C+Part+One%3A+A+Boy+of+Twelve+in+Conflict+with+the+School+Authorities&amp;rft.au=O%27Neill%2C+Sylvia&amp;rft.aulast=O%27Neill&amp;rft.aufirst=Sylvia&amp;rft.date=2001-11-01&amp;rft.volume=15&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=205&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530120090647

____________________________________________________________

Keeping Our Heads: Preserving Therapeutic Values in a Time of Change

Author: Cooper, Andrew11 Tavistock Clinic, London, UK

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61531152?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper offers a discursive overview of the present state of therapeutic social work in GB today, & locates this in the context of political & ideological struggles over the nature of the profession in the last two decades. Therapeutic social work has often been contrasted with more politically driven models of practice, but the author suggests that it is now a political task to defend & promote these practices & perspectives. Consistent with the principles underpinning therapeutic practice, practitioners are posited as individually & collectively indebted to one another & to their teachers for the skills they have, & recognition of this is what might bind us into a community capable of fighting to preserve what we value. This paper was given as the opening address at the Therapeutic Social Work Today conference, held at the Tavistock Clinic in 2001. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Keeping+Our+Heads%3A+Preserving+Therapeutic+Values+in+a+Time+of+Change&amp;rft.au=Cooper%2C+Andrew&amp;rft.aulast=Cooper&amp;rft.aufirst=Andrew&amp;rft.date=2002-05-01&amp;rft.volume=16&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=7&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530220134700

The Dilemmas for Black Social Work Professionals: Therapeutic Implications

Author: Aymer, Cathy11 Brunel U, Twickenham, UK

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61537558?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper explores the nature of social work & therapeutic practice from the perspective of black practitioners in GB today. Black practitioners carry their histories of hurt, loss & reunion, migration, & racism with them, & this lends a particular meaning to the idea of "therapeutic" for them. The writer articulates some of the complexities & tensions of black professional social work identity through a number of vignettes based on her own experience & biography. The paper was presented as a keynote address at the Therapeutic Social Work Today conference at the Tavistock Clinic in 2001. 3 References. Adapted from the source document.

Working across Boundaries: Systemic and Psychodynamic Perspectives on Multi-Disciplinary and Inter-Agency Practice

Author: Granville, Julia1; Langton, Patricia1 Monroe Young Family Centre, London, UK

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61486086?accountid=14667

Abstract: Concepts drawn from a workshop on systemic & psychoanalytic ideas helpful in managing the process of working across professional boundary issues are presented. Boundary areas are encountered between different disciplines, hierarchical levels of social work teams, client families & the team, &/or different sections of the multidisciplinary & multi-agency case network. In boundary work, mirroring involves recognizing patterns of family or system interaction that the team or agencies act out in parallel, similar to transference & countertransference in psychoanalysis. Reflection & reflexivity are critical to work therapeutically for change in families, eg, reflection on the social worker's relations & position within the team. Reflections of the workshop participants on their own experiences in social work teams are also presented. 16 References. M. Pflum

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Working+across+Boundaries%3A+Systemic+and+Psychodynamic+Perspectives+on+Multi-Disciplinary+and+Inter-Agency+Practice&amp;rft.au=Granville%2C+Julia%3BLangton%2C+Patricia&amp;rft.aulast=Granville&amp;rft.aufirst=Julia&amp;rft.date=2002-05-01&amp;rft.volume=16&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=23&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530220134728

A Therapeutic Social Work Team in Practice

Author: Walker, Dawn1; Hext, Jan1 Therapeutic Social Work Team, Osmondthorpe Centre, Leeds, UK

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61483929?accountid=14667

Abstract: In 1996, as a result of interagency collaboration between social services & health, Leeds Social Services Dept brought together three groups of social workers undertaking therapeutic work into a centrally managed team. Continued inter-agency working together has ensured that the Therapeutic Social Work Team has become an established service for children & families. This paper describes the work of the team by focusing on four areas: the context of interagency collaboration, therapeutic work in the child protection process, managing different theoretical approaches in one team, & evaluating practice. 8 References. Adapted from the source document.

Single Session Family Intervention in a Local Authority Family Centre Setting

Author: Curtis, Alan1; Whittaker, Andy; Stevens, Suzie; Lennon, Annie1 Witham Family Centre, Essex Social Services, UK

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61486872?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article describes single-session systemic work with families using a "reflecting team" in a local authority family center context. The model draws upon solution-focused approaches, reflecting team ideas, narrative approaches, & research into single sessions to provide a responsive, early intervention service to colleagues in a local social work team. We have incorporated issues raised by participants at our workshop, which was part of the Therapeutic Social Work Today conference at the Tavistock Clinic. 8 References. Adapted from the source document.

____________________________________________________________

Getting a Picture of the Client's World-View: Art-Making and Subjectivity as Evidence

Author: Newell-Walker, Ursula11 School Health & Community, U Derby, Mickleover, UK

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61536115?accountid=14667

Abstract: Paintings & drawings can enrich & amplify understanding of dilemmas that may otherwise be limited by reliance on verbal data alone, such as client conversations, interviews, & case-notes. In order for social workers to make sense of this additional information, they will need to use their subjective understandings, which, because of their very subjectivity, need then to be cross-checked with other forms of evidence. This article outlines an approach useful in social work practice with adult clients. It is based on research with a community group of volunteers from the Midlands who chose to join a project exploring midlife & its transitions. It was found that art making of a particular order, which accentuated sensory exploration, curiosity, & experimentation, contributed toward a changed relationship with self & with the external world. Key indicators lay in changes in use of language, choice of art materials, & color. 4 Figures, 29 References. Adapted from the source document.

Half in Love with Easeful Death? Social Work with Adolescents Who Harm Themselves

Author: Smith, Martin11 Buckinghamshire Social Services Emergency Duty Team, UK msmith@buckcc.gov.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61486903?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper begins by defining what is meant by adolescence & reviewing the literature that indicates concern for the high rates of suicidal behavior in adolescence. Possible explanations as to why adolescents harm themselves are considered, as is the contagious aspect of some suicidal behaviors. Extracts from three interviews conducted with young women in residential care who have engaged in self-harming behaviors are then considered. Links are made between what they say & relevant theory. The paper goes on to discuss the impact of suicidal behavior in residential care settings. It concludes that it is essential to create time & space to think carefully about this complex & multifaceted difficulty both for the adolescents themselves & those in the caring professions charged with the responsibility of trying to help them. 46 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Half+in+Love+with+Easeful+Death%3F+Social+Work+with+Adolescents+Who+Harm+Themselves&amp;rft.au=Smith%2C+Martin&amp;rft.aulast=Smith&amp;rft.aufirst=Martin&amp;rft.date=2002-05-01&amp;rft.volume=16&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=55&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530220134764

____________________________________________________________

The Troubled Mind of Northern Ireland: Social Care Object Relations Theory and Political Conflict

Author: Kapur, Raman1; Campbell, Jim1 Threshold, Belfast, Northern Ireland

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61446692?accountid=14667

Abstract: Although a great deal has been written about the Northern Irish conflict, there have been few attempts to apply psychoanalytical theory to social work, social care, & health care practice. In this paper, the authors argue that object relations theory, in particular the work of Klein & post-Kleinian writers, can be used to explore the relationship between wider social conflict, individual thought processes, & professional interventions. Object relations theory will be used to illustrate how conflictual states of mind find their way into everyday discourses. In particular, the concepts of paranoid-schizoid functioning, destructive narcissism, manic defenses, & psychotic personality functioning are used to highlight the way in which madness becomes part of a way of life in a society exposed to 30 years of the troubles. The authors conclude that a wider use of object relations theory may be helpful to professionals in the context of the current peace process in Northern Ireland. 29 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=The+Troubled+Mind+of+Northern+Ireland%3A+Social+Care+Object+Relations+Theory+and+Political+Conflict&amp;rft.au=Kapur%2C+Raman%3BCampbell%2C+Jim&amp;rft.aulast=Kapur&amp;rft.aufirst=Raman&amp;rft.date=2002-05-01&amp;rft.volume=16&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=67&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530220134773

The Court, the Couple and the Consultant: Is There Room for a Third Position?

Author: Freedman, Judith

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61525863?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper describes assessment work for the family courts that is informed by psychodynamic understanding of parents who have abused their children. The aim of this work is to increase the Court's understanding of the parents. The author focuses on the role that she & her colleagues adopt, attempting to find a third position to facilitate curiosity & thinking, trying not to become part of a process of apportioning blame. 10 References. Adapted from the source document.

____________________________________________________________

Social Work and Therapy: Reclaiming a Generic Therapeutic Space in Child and Family Work

Author: Donovan, Mary11 Ana Freud Centre, London, UK mary.donovan@annafreud.org

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61503521?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper underlines the need for contemporary social work to conceptualize a therapeutic stance for the profession. It argues that social work is most likely to reconnect with therapy in the generic space between the specialist approaches in child & family work. The therapeutic space historically inhabited by social work has straddled the personal & the social & a coherent therapeutic framework needs to encompass this dual perspective. The historical opposition between two of the main specialist therapies in the field -- the psychoanalytic & the systemic -- & the resulting entrenched divisions, has made it extremely difficult for social work to articulate an integrative stance. Contemporary recognition of some commonality between psychoanalytic & systemic therapy is therefore encouraging from a social work perspective. It offers an important vantage point from which social work might reappraise its own past integrative therapeutic tradition encapsulated in the psychosocial model of casework. The paper concludes with case material, which explores the psychosocial parameters of therapeutic engagement by the social worker & the generic therapeutic space in which such work unfolds. 44 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Social+Work+and+Therapy%3A+Reclaiming+a+Generic+Therapeutic+Space+in+Child+and+Family+Work&amp;rft.au=Donovan%2C+Mary&amp;rft.aulast=Donovan&amp;rft.aufirst=Mary&amp;rft.date=2002-11-01&amp;rft.volume=16&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=113&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0265053022000033685

Countertransference, Supervision and the Reflection Process

Author: Agass, Dick11 Dept Psychotherapy, Lynfield Mount Hospital, West Yorkshire, UK dick.agass@bdct.nhs.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61518053?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper is concerned with the central importance of countertransference in the helping process, & with the role of supervision in helping therapeutically oriented workers to understand & make use of their own emotional responses to the client. The perils of being drawn into some kind of defensive "acting out" with the client are discussed. Case material is used to illustrate (1) the impact of the client's projections on the worker, & (2) the way in which supervision may itself become the arena for a "reflection" or re-enactment of an object-relationship from the client's internal world. 9 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Countertransference%2C+Supervision+and+the+Reflection+Process&amp;rft.au=Agass%2C+Dick&amp;rft.aulast=Agass&amp;rft.aufirst=Dick&amp;rft.date=2002-11-01&amp;rft.volume=16&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=125&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0265053022000033694

Working with the Risk of Suicide in Young People

Author: Briggs, Stephen11 Adolescent Dept, Tavistock Clinic, London, UK sbriggs@tavi-port.nhs.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61503548?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper provides a psychoanalytic framework for working with adolescents at risk of suicide, which, it is argued, is essential for understanding the wide range of presentations of suicidality in adolescence, & for making sense of the powerful emotional impact of this work on the worker. The paper locates the discussion in the context of current knowledge of patterns of suicidality, & focuses on discussing internal dynamics & the adolescents' relationships with the body. It concludes that a containing reflective space is the most effective way of reducing suicide risk in each individual case. 41 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Working+with+the+Risk+of+Suicide+in+Young+People&amp;rft.au=Briggs%2C+Stephen&amp;rft.aulast=Briggs&amp;rft.aufirst=Stephen&amp;rft.date=2002-11-01&amp;rft.volume=16&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=135&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0265053022000033702

____________________________________________________________

Key Features of Therapeutic Social Work: The Use of Relationship

Author: Sudbery, John11 Dept Social Work, U Salford J.Sudbery@salford.ac.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61475518?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article summarizes key features of therapeutic social work from a psychodynamic perspective. The emphasis throughout is on the social worker's use of relationship. The article's starting point is that whatever their other concerns -- welfare administration, advocacy, social action, practical assistance, or social control, for example -- social workers have a core responsibility for outcomes that are therapeutic, empowering, & developmental. The key components of relationship are analyzed as attention to basic need, response to aggressive impulses & the lessening of punitive self-criticism. These are located within the conceptual framework (set out earlier in the article, with examples) of transference, countertransference, & the punitive superego. Such work requires a managerial supervisory function that supports & enables this use of relationship. Core components are the provision of staff support & suitable work arrangements & expectations. 38 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Key+Features+of+Therapeutic+Social+Work%3A+The+Use+of+Relationship&amp;rft.au=Sudbery%2C+John&amp;rft.aulast=Sudbery&amp;rft.aufirst=John&amp;rft.date=2002-11-01&amp;rft.volume=16&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=149&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0265053022000033711

Fostering Care: The Child, the Family and the Professional System

Author: Barratt, Sara11 Child & Family Dept, Tavistock Clinic, London, UK SBarratt@tavi-port.org

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61539885?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper looks at the context for foster care & the possible reasons for the crisis in the foster care system. The author seeks to connect family of origin experiences of foster carers with their motivation to foster & suggests that therapeutic interventions for foster children should also include work within foster families. 3 Figures, 17 References. Filling the Psychic Gap: Understanding Psychosomatic Problems in a Multicultural Clinic

Author: Keval, Narendra11 Dept Clinical Psychology, Avenue Clinic, Hertfordshire, UK

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61540186?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper describes an analytic approach I used some years ago when working in a multicultural clinic to understand psychosomatic difficulties in an Asian Muslim woman who suffered from recurring headaches & dizzy spells. Her symptoms revealed & concealed a much-needed psychic equilibrium aimed at producing a stalemate in her mental growth & development. The headaches occurred when she began to think about herself, particularly conflicting thoughts & feelings she found intolerable because they represented signs of psychic movement & separation. The dizzy spells acted like a psychic switch that closed her mind down & enabled her to escape into a fantasy of fusion with her mother that would have posed another type of psychic threat -- the potential loss of her identity. Adopting others both literally & metaphorically had the aim of filling a psychic gap left by a failure of internalization resulting in an 'addictive' way of relating to others such as her husband & the wider system of health care professionals who ultimately failed her. 17 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Filling+the+Psychic+Gap%3A+Understanding+Psychosomatic+Problems+in+a+Multicultural+Clinic&amp;rft.au=Keval%2C+Narendra&amp;rft.aulast=Keval&amp;rft.aufirst=Narendra&amp;rft.date=2002-11-01&amp;rft.volume=16&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=175&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0265053022000033739

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Filling+the+Psychic+Gap%3A+Understanding+Psychosomatic+Problems+in+a+Multicultural+Clinic&amp;rft.au=Keval%2C+Narendra&amp;rft.aulast=Keval&amp;rft.aufirst=Narendra&amp;rft.date=2002-11-01&amp;rft.volume=16&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=175&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0265053022000033739

A Question of Survival: Who Cares for the Carers?

Author: Fox, Maureen11 Child & Family Dept, Tavistock Clinic, London, UK MFox@tavi-port.org

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61502831?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper describes a young refugee's experience of unbearable emotional pain & its impact on the professionals who work with her. It demonstrates the importance of adequate support for professionals working with refugees; & the difficulties for both individuals & organizations in tolerating the limitations of resources. Psycho-Analytic Insight and Relationships Revisited

Author: Mack, Beverley11 Assessment & Therapeutic Service, Surrey, UK

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61476595?accountid=14667

Abstract: A review essay on a book by Isca Salzberger-Wittenberg, Psycho-Analytic Insight and Relationships: A Kleinian Approach discusses the main theoretical ideas in the book & how the author applies them to social casework. I consider the relevance of these ideas to contemporary social work in terms of their contribution to the knowledge base of social work & social work methods. I argue that Kleinian ideas can make an important contribution to understanding the interpsychic & intrapsychic aspects of human experience with which social workers come into contact. I suggest that the author writes about the casework relationship with little regard to the social & political contexts in which social work is undertaken, & in contemporary social work, there needs to be a relationship between three different elements: the client as an individual in his/her social context; the emotional dynamics of the client-worker relationship; & the integration of theory, social policy & the legal framework. 19 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Psycho-Analytic+Insight+and+Relationships+Revisited&amp;rft.au=Mack%2C+Beverley&amp;rft.aulast=Mack&amp;rft.aufirst=Beverley&amp;rft.date=2002-11-01&amp;rft.volume=16&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=191&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0265053022000033757

____________________________________________________________

Mate and Stalemate Revisited

Author: Dearnley, Katy11 Child & Family Dept, Tavistock Clinic, London, UK kdearnley@tavi-port.nhs.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61544310?accountid=14667

Abstract: Offers a reevaluation of a book by J. Mattinson & Sinclair, FRIMate and Stalemate & assesses its relevance to contemporary social work 23 years after its initial publication. The book describes an action research project conducted by the Instit of Marital Studies (now the Tavistock Marital Studies Instit) in England designed to develop marital casework methods for use in the delivery of social services to local authority clients. Its insights into both the conscious & unconscious forces driving clients & workers in an inner-city social services department are deemed extremely valuable, as are its analyses of the problems faced by social workers in local authority settings. The detailed theoretical framework that grounds the book's description of the client-worker relationship, both clinically based & rooted in psychoanalytic thinking, is also praised, as is its attention to the institutional factors & their impact on service delivery. Reasons why the book is generally unfamiliar to contemporary marriage & family practitioners are explored & a rereading is urged. 8 References. K. Hyatt Stewart

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Mate+and+Stalemate+Revisited&amp;rft.au=Dearnley%2C+Katy&amp;rft.aulast=Dearnley&amp;rft.aufirst=Katy&amp;rft.date=2002-11-01&amp;rft.volume=16&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=203&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0265053022000033766

The Experience of Teaching and Learning in Social Work. The Teaching of Young Child Observation: A Historical Overview

Author: Miles, Gillian11 Child & Family Dept, Tavistock Clinic, London, UK Gillian-Miles@bigfoot.com

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61492970?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper describes the setting up in 1989 of the Tavistock/CCETSW course in young child observation for social work tutors & practice teachers, against the background of the immense pressures on social workers, particularly in the field of child protection. The paper summarizes the potential learning from young child observation, & its contribution within social work training. It outlines the issues that faced the social work trainers as they went on to introduce & teach observation on their courses, & draws on an evaluative study in which the members of the course participated, giving their views on the value of observation training. 14 References. Adapted from the source document.

Experience of Undertaking Infant Observation as Part of the Post-Qualifying Award in Child Care

Author: King, Rosie

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61507819?accountid=14667

Abstract: Inquiries into child deaths have pointed to the difficulty that social workers seem to have of 'holding the child in mind.' Undertaking 'child observation' can be a powerful way of understanding what these difficulties are about & how to work in a way that is child focused, while being attentive to adult considerations crucial to children's positive development. This is an account of an experience of undertaking a 10-week child observational study as part of the Post Qualifying Award in Child Care from a student's perspective. It suggests that developing observational skills & an understanding of psychotherapeutic ideas enhanced the practitioner's ability to work with uncertainty & make accurate assessments. 27 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Experience+of+Undertaking+Infant+Observation+as+Part+of+the+Post-Qualifying+Award+in+Child+Care&amp;rft.au=King%2C+Rosie&amp;rft.aulast=King&amp;rft.aufirst=Rosie&amp;rft.date=2002-11-01&amp;rft.volume=16&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=213&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0265053022000033784

____________________________________________________________

Changing Learning and Learning Change: Making a Difference in Education, Policy and Practice

Author: Preston-Shoot, Michael11 Dept Applied Social Studies, U Luton, UK michael.preston-shoot@luton.ac.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61496929?accountid=14667

Abstract: Themes of dehumanization, demoralization, insecurity, & powerlessness are identified from research evidence of the experiences of social work staff & clients. Similar themes are uncovered in a review of policy making across different social work client groups. The picture that emerges is contrasted with official pronouncements about the goals of policy making & about social work's aims & purposes, while their impact is revealed through the operation of various defensive responses. The paper moves on to survey several misunderstandings about practice & policy change before concluding by identifying spaces where teaching & learning social work can effect a shift of mind, where practitioners & managers can begin to make a difference to their own & their clients' experiences of social work. 46 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Changing+Learning+and+Learning+Change%3A+Making+a+Difference+in+Education%2C+Policy+and+Practice&amp;rft.au=Preston-Shoot%2C+Michael&amp;rft.aulast=Preston-Shoot&amp;rft.aufirst=Michael&amp;rft.date=2003-05-01&amp;rft.volume=17&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=9&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0265053032000071493

____________________________________________________________

Michael, Part Two: Crisis and Resolution in the Transference

Author: O'Neill, Sylvia

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61496736?accountid=14667

Abstract: This is the second of two linked papers seeking to trace certain processes in a social worker/family relationship. 'Michael, Part One: A Boy of Twelve in Conflict with the School Authorities' recounted two discussions of a case presented to a practice seminar led by the author. This paper describes a third seminar presentation & discussion of 'Michael.' Michael's central problem of an insecure, unstable, & ambivalent relation to his father, to which he reacted with difficult behavior, was repeated when the social worker was inadvertently embroiled in the family's interactive strategy. In the ensuing crisis, the boy was excluded from school. The social worker contained the crisis & paved the way for a deeper understanding of the central problem when she acknowledged that something had gone wrong in the relationship with herself. The view that limited unwitting collusion with the central problem & subsequent acknowledgement of the error is potentially facilitating, in the context of otherwise steady consistency, accords well with Mattinson & Sinclair's (1979) research. Conceptually, the author draws also on Oedipal & transference theory. The 'third position' aspect of Oedipal theory is applied variously to the function of the father, the social worker, & the seminar. 20 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Michael%2C+Part+Two%3A+Crisis+and+Resolution+in+the+Transference&amp;rft.au=O%27Neill%2C+Sylvia&amp;rft.aulast=O%27Neill&amp;rft.aufirst=Sylvia&amp;rft.date=2003-05-01&amp;rft.volume=17&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=25&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0265053032000071448

Devils and Deep Blue Seas: The Social Worker In-Between

Author: Thompson, Paul11 West London Mission, UK paul.thompson@wlm.org.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61496770?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper examines the role of the approved social worker, as defined by s.114 of the Mental Health Act 1983, with particular regard to ethical dilemmas in crisis intervention. Issues of management accountability, health, & safety are set against the approved social worker's statutory responsibility to assess people experiencing mental health problems &, where necessary, admit to psychiatric hospital under compulsion. Consideration is given to the impact of this work upon the worker, on whom extreme & sometimes conflicting demands are made. An attempt is made to integrate these viewpoints within a fundamentally psychodynamic perspective. 29 References. Adapted from the source document.

Touch: Its Use in Psychotherapy

Author: Strozier, Anne L1; Krizek, Claudette; Sale, Kimberly1 School Social Work, U South Florida, Tampa strozier@chuma1.cas.usf.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61544594?accountid=14667

Abstract: The use of touch as a therapeutic intervention is a matter of controversy. While the literature reflects the healing potential of touch, it also identifies concern that touch can be harmful to our clients. This article reports the results of an exploratory research project on how social work therapists are touching their clients, as well as their reasons for using touch or not using touch. The results of the study show that the therapists sampled use touch with their clients, but have received little education, training, or supervision on the use of touch. The authors encourage further dialogue & research about this potentially powerful but complex intervention. 7 Tables, 25 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Touch%3A+Its+Use+in+Psychotherapy&amp;rft.au=Strozier%2C+Anne+L%3BKrizek%2C+Claudette%3BSale%2C+Kimberly&amp;rft.aulast=Strozier&amp;rft.aufirst=Anne&amp;rft.date=2003-05-01&amp;rft.volume=17&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=49&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0265053032000071457

Sanjhe Range/Shared Colours, Shared Lives: A Multicultural Approach to Mental Health Practice

Author: Burman, Erica1; Gowrisunkur, Jaya; Walker, Kanta1 Dept Psychology Speech & Pathology, Manchester Metropolitan U, UK e.burman@mmu.ac.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61544637?accountid=14667

Abstract: In this paper, we reflect upon processes involved in setting up a development project challenging black people's linguistic & cultural exclusion from psychotherapeutic services. Firstly, we situate the project within broader debates about issues of culture & (other forms of) identity in therapy, highlighting implications for therapy arising from the pervasive culture of racism & racialization that positions black people as bearers of 'race,' & white people as devoid of color/'culture.' We critique institutional responses to the current demand for intercultural & multicultural approaches that tend to focus on technical devices such as cultural matching at the expense of (1) treating communities as culturally homogeneous; & (2) passing responsibility for culturally appropriate provision onto specialist agencies or 'culturally equipped' individuals. Secondly, we present an account of the institutional resistances, professional tensions, & community responses encountered in the setting up of Sanjhe Rang, a project offering psychotherapy in first language provision in a range of South Asian languages in Rochdale, Lancashire. Finally, we outline some reflections arising from this specific project & suggest some implications for ways of thinking about culturally autonomous, cross-community, & cross-disciplinary collaborations around mental health practices. 56 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Sanjhe+Range%2FShared+Colours%2C+Shared+Lives%3A+A+Multicultural+Approach+to+Mental+Health+Practice&amp;rft.au=Burman%2C+Erica%3BGowrisunkur%2C+Jaya%3BWalker%2C+Kanta&amp;rft.aulast=Burman&amp;rft.aufirst=Erica&amp;rft.date=2003-05-01&amp;rft.volume=17&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=63&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0265053032000071529

Traditional versus Western Perceptions of Mental Illness: Women of Moroccan Origin Treated in an Israeli Mental Health Center

Author: Latzer, Yael11 Psychiatric Division, Eating Disorders Clinic, Rambam Medical Center, Haifa, Israel latzer@netvision.net.il

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61546966?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper focuses on the problems encountered in providing Westernized psychiatric treatment to a population with traditional healing beliefs. The sample comprised women of Moroccan origin living in Israel undergoing treatment for psychiatric disorders (N=38) & their treating psychiatrists (N=9). Ethnographic interviews were conducted between both groups. The results revealed that the symptoms, perceptions of the illness, & problems encountered in the therapeutic relationship differed across three age groups, young women (20-30 years), more mature women (31-42 years), & older women (43-60 years). While cultural conflict appeared to affect the development of mental illness in each group, this was most pronounced among women in the middle age range. Moreover, problems in the therapeutic alliance were greatest in this age group. The data from the therapists indicated that they maintained a Western perspective in both their understanding & diagnoses of these patients' illnesses. The different perspectives of the therapists & each of the three groups of women are discussed. It is concluded that professionals treating traditional populations must avoid imposing Western standards, & consider the treatment in the context of cultural beliefs. The developmental stages of the individual, & the stage of acculturation must also be taken into account if treatment is to be effective. 3 Tables, 1 Figure, 67 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Traditional+versus+Western+Perceptions+of+Mental+Illness%3A+Women+of+Moroccan+Origin+Treated+in+an+Israeli+Mental+Health+Center&amp;rft.au=Latzer%2C+Yael&amp;rft.aulast=Latzer&amp;rft.aufirst=Yael&amp;rft.date=2003-05-01&amp;rft.volume=17&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=77&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0265053032000071501

From Pathology to Postmodernism: A Debate on 'Race' and Mental Health

Author: Desai, Suki11 U Wolverhampton, Castle View, Dudley, UK in6265@wlv.ac.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61550186?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article suggests that 'race' & psychiatry are inextricably linked &, as such, 'mental illness' constitutes a precondition of black people's psyche. Postmodernist & poststructuralist analysis are used to question the way that mental health problems have been socially constructed in Western psychiatry. For health & social care workers to effectively respond to racism within psychiatry & community care provision, it is necessary for them to understand the relationship that exists between & informs 'race' & psychiatry. 37 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=From+Pathology+to+Postmodernism%3A+A+Debate+on+%27Race%27+and+Mental+Health&amp;rft.au=Desai%2C+Suki&amp;rft.aulast=Desai&amp;rft.aufirst=Suki&amp;rft.date=2003-05-01&amp;rft.volume=17&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=95&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0265053032000071538
