____________________________________________________________

Responses of Health and Social Care Staff to South Asian Women Who Attempt Suicide and/or Self-Harm

Author: Batsleer, Janet1; Chantler, Khatidja; Burman, Erica1 Dept Applied Community Studies, Manchester Metropolitan U, Didsbury, UK j.batsleer@mmu.ac.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61449379?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper draws on a ten-month British study completed in Apr 2001 investigating service responses to women of South Asian background who had attempted suicide or who self-harmed. The scope of the study is briefly outlined & an analysis of perspectives documented in the study is presented, drawing on research interviews with 18 staff from a variety of health & social care disciplines & with seven survivors of attempted suicide/self-harm. The implications of this analysis for improving practice are considered. Attitudes surrounding attempted suicide & self-harm are discussed. The issue of 'race anxiety' is also discussed. The factors seen by workers as contributing to South Asian women's attempted suicide are considered, with a particular focus on the difficulties caused in the delivery of services by commonsense accounts of cultural issues. Current approaches to the delivery of services to South Asian women are identified & analyzed, showing how their current organization can lead to circularity in referral systems & consequent non-intentional neglect of the needs of this client group. It is urged that proper consideration be given to the support & professional supervision of staff in this complex area of work. 16 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Responses+of+Health+and+Social+Care+Staff+to+South+Asian+Women+Who+Attempt+Suicide+and%2For+Self-Harm&amp;rft.au=Batsleer%2C+Janet%3BChantler%2C+Khatidja%3BBurman%2C+Erica&amp;rft.aulast=Batsleer&amp;rft.aufirst=Janet&amp;rft.date=2003-05-01&amp;rft.volume=17&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=103&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0265053032000071484

An Analysis of Conflict Experienced between Agencies Involved with Asylum Seekers

Author: Khan, Parves

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61449387?accountid=14667

Abstract: During the summer of 1999, four boats carrying 599 asylum seekers from the People's Republic of China entered Canadian waters off the west coast of Vancouver Island, British Columbia. The event sparked federal & provincial government agencies & community organizations to move quickly to manage the unprecedented service demands created by their arrival. Agencies, from various jurisdictions, many with no history of collaborating with one another, began to liaise. In the course of working together, collaboration was hampered by a lack of clarity over respective roles, strains on agency resources, poor communication, & lack of consultation. The root of these conflict areas lay with the difficulty of reconciling differing agency mandates. It is however argued that such differences in agency mandates became the subject of polarizing agency positions as a result of the heightened political context. This included the relentless media attention & coverage scrutinizing the arrival of the asylum seekers. 40 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=An+Analysis+of+Conflict+Experienced+between+Agencies+Involved+with+Asylum+Seekers&amp;rft.au=Khan%2C+Parves&amp;rft.aulast=Khan&amp;rft.aufirst=Parves&amp;rft.date=2003-05-01&amp;rft.volume=17&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=115&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0265053032000071439

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=An+Analysis+of+Conflict+Experienced+between+Agencies+Involved+with+Asylum+Seekers&amp;rft.au=Khan%2C+Parves&amp;rft.aulast=Khan&amp;rft.aufirst=Parves&amp;rft.date=2003-05-01&amp;rft.volume=17&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=115&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0265053032000071439

Broken and Twisted

Author: Bower, Marion11 Tavistock Clinic, London, UK mbower@tavi-port.nhs.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61550287?accountid=14667

Abstract: The title of this paper refers to a social worker's description of the horrific injuries inflicted on a baby by its carers. These sorts of injuries, both emotional & physical, raise questions about how we prepare social workers to be both receptive to pain & distress, & also professionally resilient. 1 Figure, 10 References. ____________________________________________________________

Gorgons, Cars and the Frightful Fiend: Representations of Fear in Social Work and Counselling

Author: Smith, Martin11 Emergency Duty Team, Katharine Knapp House, Buckinghamshire msmith@buckscc.gov.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61450141?accountid=14667

Abstract: Two main themes can be traced throughout this paper. One concerns the way in which material can emerge from research data & come to shape a study in a way that was not anticipated at the outset. The other is that experiences of distress & fear can be considered & understood only indirectly & this process is aided by encouraging participants' free associations to material rather than by asking direct questions. The paper begins with an explanation of how interest in researching the impact of fear on social workers & counselors emerged from research into social workers' experiences of distress. A surprising finding of the research into fear was the number of times cars & driving featured in participants' responses. These mentions seemed a way of drawing attention to deeper resonances & meanings of integral significance. Substantive quotations from data are provided & analyzed to illustrate ways in which cars might have been used to express fears of the fracturing of basic trust, the violation of the secure base, & the uncanny. The paper concludes with the contention that an approach allowing the importance of participants' free associations to material is likely to be helpful when researching sensitive subjects. 26 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Gorgons%2C+Cars+and+the+Frightful+Fiend%3A+Representations+of+Fear+in+Social+Work+and+Counselling&amp;rft.au=Smith%2C+Martin&amp;rft.aulast=Smith&amp;rft.aufirst=Martin&amp;rft.date=2003-11-01&amp;rft.volume=17&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=153&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F026505302000145671

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Gorgons%2C+Cars+and+the+Frightful+Fiend%3A+Representations+of+Fear+in+Social+Work+and+Counselling&amp;rft.au=Smith%2C+Martin&amp;rft.aulast=Smith&amp;rft.aufirst=Martin&amp;rft.date=2003-11-01&amp;rft.volume=17&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=153&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F026505302000145671

____________________________________________________________

Effective Relationship-Based Practice: A Theoretical Exploration

Author: Trevithick, Pamela11 School Policy Studies, U Bristol, UK Pam.Trevithick@bristol.ac.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61537705?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper looks at the importance of a relationship-based approach within social work. It explores past writings on the social worker-client relationship, why the relationship was seen to be central to effectiveness & good practice, & why this perspective fell out of favor. It revisits the importance of a relationship-based approach, within a psychosocial perspective, in relation to eight areas of practice. These include the assessment task & process; relationship difficulties; people who are vulnerable or reliant on others for their well-being; situations that require practitioners to be able to hold & contain anxiety; the relationship as a foundation for capacity building, empowerment, & developing people's potential; & in relation to disadvantaged & marginalised sectors of the population, how social workers can use the 'frontline' knowledge they have gained through the relationships they have created in political ways -- to bear witness & report on 'social ills' as they impact on the lives of service users. A final section looks briefly at how the service user-social worker relationship is perceived & described in the Benchmarking Statement, National Occupational Standards, & the General Social Care Council's Rules & Requirements & their implications in terms of the new social work degree. 72 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Effective+Relationship-Based+Practice%3A+A+Theoretical+Exploration&amp;rft.au=Trevithick%2C+Pamela&amp;rft.aulast=Trevithick&amp;rft.aufirst=Pamela&amp;rft.date=2003-11-01&amp;rft.volume=17&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=163&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Database: Social Services Abstracts

____________________________________________________________

Surviving the Swamp: Using Cognitive Behavioural Therapy in a Social Work Setting

Author: Matthews, Stuart1; Harvey, Anna; Trevithick, Pamela1 South Gloucester Social Services, Adolescent Support Services, UK

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61500870?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper explores the attempts of an adolescent support team working for South Gloucestershire Social Services, to integrate Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) into its practice. We explain how we, as a team, undertook a yearlong course of study in CBT & discuss the advantages & difficulties we encountered. Then, beginning with a case study, we draw out the limitations of trying to use CBT in a social work setting. We focus specifically on how the complications of wider family systems will often compromise individual therapeutic work with young people & conclude that a more pragmatic approach to CBT is required in social work, rather than attempts to replicate work carried out in the clinical setting. 17 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Surviving+the+Swamp%3A+Using+Cognitive+Behavioural+Therapy+in+a+Social+Work+Setting&amp;rft.au=Matthews%2C+Stuart%3BHarvey%2C+Anna%3BTrevithick%2C+Pamela&amp;rft.aulast=Matthews&amp;rft.aufirst=Stuart&amp;rft.date=2003-11-01&amp;rft.volume=17&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=177&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F026505302000145680

Express Yourself! A Student's Experience of Running a Movement Improvisation Workshop

Author: Palmer, John

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61500899?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper is an account of a social work student's experience running an improvisation workshop while on placement in a children's residential home. It describes the ways in which children were able to use movement & music in a spontaneous & unstructured manner to express their emotions, & how the improvised use of music can enable children to relate to, & understand, their experience. 2 References. Adapted from the source document.

____________________________________________________________

Learning from the Victoria Climbie Inquiry

Author: Rustin, Michael11 School Social Sciences, U East London, Dagenham, Essex, UK m.j.rustin@uel.ac.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61518630?accountid=14667

Abstract: This critical review of the Report of the Victoria Climbie Inquiry contends that the quasi-judicial procedure adopted in this Inquiry was well adapted to providing a detailed analysis of the sequence of events that took place, & to attributing responsibility for failures & errors to individuals involved with the case. However, it finds this method of investigation inadequate as a means of exploring the systemic problems that give rise to poor service provision, & of identifying solutions to these. The predominantly procedural focus of its numerous recommendations reflects the bureaucratic approach that now prevails in the management & regulation of British public services. The article argues, nevertheless, that the Report & its recommendations have opened up space for some necessary rethinking, & could therefore have a beneficial outcome. 4 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Learning+from+the+Victoria+Climbie+Inquiry&amp;rft.au=Rustin%2C+Michael&amp;rft.aulast=Rustin&amp;rft.aufirst=Michael&amp;rft.date=2004-03-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=9&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0265053032000183679

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Learning+from+the+Victoria+Climbie+Inquiry&amp;rft.au=Rustin%2C+Michael&amp;rft.aulast=Rustin&amp;rft.aufirst=Michael&amp;rft.date=2004-03-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=9&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0265053032000183679

Risk-Taking, Dangerous Behaviour in Childhood: Child Protection and Clinical Strategies

Author: Anderson, Janet11 CFCS, Loughton, UK jananderson010@yahoo.co.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61451434?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper describes the findings of qualitative clinical research into risk-taking, dangerous behavior in childhood using a post-Kleinian psychoanalytic approach undertaken by a child psychotherapist working in a local CAMHS. The purpose of the research was to find a way of understanding this behavior using psychoanalytic thinking & comparing material from a number of cases across a wide age range (grouped into three age bands). Three different situations were identified in which risk-taking, dangerous behavior occurred, termed no-haven, illusory-haven, & perilous-haven. All three havens are dangerous for children. For each haven, there is a different prognosis & a different strategy. 14 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Risk-Taking%2C+Dangerous+Behaviour+in+Childhood%3A+Child+Protection+and+Clinical+Strategies&amp;rft.au=Anderson%2C+Janet&amp;rft.aulast=Anderson&amp;rft.aufirst=Janet&amp;rft.date=2004-03-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=19&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0265053042000180572

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Risk-Taking%2C+Dangerous+Behaviour+in+Childhood%3A+Child+Protection+and+Clinical+Strategies&amp;rft.au=Anderson%2C+Janet&amp;rft.aulast=Anderson&amp;rft.aufirst=Janet&amp;rft.date=2004-03-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=19&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0265053042000180572

____________________________________________________________

Reversing a Spiral of Deprivation: Working to Ameliorate the Relationship of Staff and Boys in a Residential Home

Author: Briggs, Andrew11 Centre Psychoanalytic Studies, U Essex, Wivenhoe Park, Colchester, UK abriggs@essex.ac.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61498620?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper discusses the work of a consultation to a staff group at a residential home for adolescent boys. The work discovered that each encounter increased each group's sense of deprivation. This escalation is understood as their relationship being based on a spiral of deprivation. In this situation, the staff's capacity to think in terms of their training in Winnicott's ideas about residential care, & that behavior has meaning, was lost. By using himself as the container of staff emotional states, through recognizing their communications in terms of Bion's concept of normal projective identification, the consultant was better able to understand the nature of the difficulties in the boys' & staff relationship. Hence, the attempt to engage staff through the consultation was successful, & their capacity to think was restored. The material discussed shows that this development enabled staff to better contain their own & the boys' feelings, thus allowing the spiral to reverse. 9 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Reversing+a+Spiral+of+Deprivation%3A+Working+to+Ameliorate+the+Relationship+of+Staff+and+Boys+in+a+Residential+Home&amp;rft.au=Briggs%2C+Andrew&amp;rft.aulast=Briggs&amp;rft.aufirst=Andrew&amp;rft.date=2004-03-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=33&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0265053042000180536

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Reversing+a+Spiral+of+Deprivation%3A+Working+to+Ameliorate+the+Relationship+of+Staff+and+Boys+in+a+Residential+Home&amp;rft.au=Briggs%2C+Andrew&amp;rft.aulast=Briggs&amp;rft.aufirst=Andrew&amp;rft.date=2004-03-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=33&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0265053042000180536

____________________________________________________________

The Contribution of Observation Training to Professional Development in Social Work

Author: Trowell, Judith1; Miles, Gillian1 Dept Child & Family, Tavistock Clinic, London, UK

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61520034?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper first describes a range of uses of observational training & the learning to which it can give rise. It goes on to describe in detail a specific project that was undertaken by the authors with a selected group of social work trainers. The range of observations undertaken by the participants is described, & their own comments provide first-hand evaluations of the experience. Observation is seen by the authors as one of the most important foundation skills in social work practice. They conclude by sketching out the possible place of such training in the social work career continuum in the UK. 2 Figures, 17 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=The+Contribution+of+Observation+Training+to+Professional+Development+in+Social+Work&amp;rft.au=Trowell%2C+Judith%3BMiles%2C+Gillian&amp;rft.aulast=Trowell&amp;rft.aufirst=Judith&amp;rft.date=2004-03-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=49&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0265053032000183688

____________________________________________________________

Commentary (12 Years On) on 'The Contribution of Observation Training to Professional Development in Social Work' by Judith Trowell and Gillian Miles

Author: Miles, Gillian

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61498653?accountid=14667

Abstract: Reflects on the first year of the CCETSW/Tavistock course, focusing on observation training, for social work tutors. The professional development workshop is praised for breaching agency boundaries & creating an environment to share experiences in the field. The origins & results of the CCETSW/Tavistock course on child services are discussed, & the importance of well-trained social work teachers is emphasized. 9 References. Adapted from the source document.

Database: Social Services Abstracts

____________________________________________________________

How Multiproblem Families Try to Find Support in Social Services

Author: Matos, Ana R1; Sousa, Liliana M1 Dept Health Sciences, U Aveiro, Portugal

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61554482?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article aims to contribute to a better understanding of the relationship between multiproblem families & social agencies, &, in particular, of how families try to find support in larger systems. Usually, multiproblem families are also multi-assisted, since the several problems they live with attract intervention from a wide range of social protection services. Using a qualitative approach, data were collected from 56 multiproblem households via a semistructured interview. Findings suggest seven categories of families: 'outsider' families (who reject the existence of problems, so never try to find support); 'resigned' families (who give up looking for formal support after a first refusal, & continue coping on their own); 'persistent' families (who insist in getting support from several social agencies); 'over-needy' families (any minimal difficulty justifies the search for formal support); 'balanced' families (who apply for formal support only when they experience difficulties in dealing with problems); 'imprudent' families (who ask social agencies for support only when problems reach an unsustainable level); & 'ignored' families (who do not try to get support, so no formal help reaches them). 6 Tables, 21 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=How+Multiproblem+Families+Try+to+Find+Support+in+Social+Services&amp;rft.au=Matos%2C+Ana+R%3BSousa%2C+Liliana+M&amp;rft.aulast=Matos&amp;rft.aufirst=Ana&amp;rft.date=2004-03-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=65&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0265053042000180590

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=How+Multiproblem+Families+Try+to+Find+Support+in+Social+Services&amp;rft.au=Matos%2C+Ana+R%3BSousa%2C+Liliana+M&amp;rft.aulast=Matos&amp;rft.aufirst=Ana&amp;rft.date=2004-03-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=65&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0265053042000180590

____________________________________________________________

Testing Boundaries: The Social Context of Physical and Relational Containment in a Maximum Secure Psychiatric Hospital

Author: Deacon, Jude

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61520089?accountid=14667

Abstract: The article describes some of the history of inpatient psychiatric services & the main focus of recent policy development impacting on the organizational culture of high secure inpatient services. The social & political context for mental health services is located within the recent growth in public concerns about risk & the attendant expectations of professionals, culminating in the proposed reforms of the Mental Health Act (1983) & the development of services for patients diagnosed with severe personality disorders & assessed as being dangerous. Psychodynamic theory is applied to an analysis of working in such a setting, & the unconscious defensive processes, in the current social & political climate. The particular impact on social care services is considered. It is suggested that, in this context, the nature of the primary task challenges the management of boundaries with a resulting infusion of perverse projective processes that potentially undermine professional practices & the possibility of reflective practice. 50 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Testing+Boundaries%3A+The+Social+Context+of+Physical+and+Relational+Containment+in+a+Maximum+Secure+Psychiatric+Hospital&amp;rft.au=Deacon%2C+Jude&amp;rft.aulast=Deacon&amp;rft.aufirst=Jude&amp;rft.date=2004-03-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=81&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0265053042000180545

____________________________________________________________

An Exploration of the Therapeutic Relationship and Counselling Outcomes in a Problem Gambling Counselling Service

Author: Smith, Serena A; Thomas, Shane A; Jackson, Alun C

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61507812?accountid=14667

Abstract: This study examined the relationship between a number of counseling process variables thought to influence counseling outcomes in a sample of 150 clients undertaking short-term counseling in the statewide government-funded Gambler's Help problem gambling counseling services in Victoria, Australia. Factors measured included psychosocial well-being of clients prior to & after counseling; client readiness to change; self-reported gambling activity levels before & after counseling; self-assessment of current gambling behavior; strength of therapeutic alliance; self-reported counseling outcomes achieved in the area of symptoms, life matters, & related problems; & a measure of client satisfaction with the service. The therapeutic alliance was found to have the strongest predictive power with respect to the level of problem resolution achieved by clients across all but one of the problem areas. The implications of these findings for clinical social work practice & education of practitioners are noted. 5 Tables, 24 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=An+Exploration+of+the+Therapeutic+Relationship+and+Counselling+Outcomes+in+a+Problem+Gambling+Counselling+Service&amp;rft.au=Smith%2C+Serena+A%3BThomas%2C+Shane+A%3BJackson%2C+Alun+C&amp;rft.aulast=Smith&amp;rft.aufirst=Serena&amp;rft.date=2004-03-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=99&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0265053042000180581

____________________________________________________________

Parents' and Children's Perceptions of a Family Support Intervention for Child Behavioural Problems

Author: Window, Suzanne1; Richards, Maxine; Vostanis, Panos1 NHS Clinical Governance Support Team, Leicester

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61432703?accountid=14667

Abstract: The aim of this study was to establish the perceptions of children & their parents following a Family Support intervention for child behavioral & related difficulties. One hundred parents & 22 children aged 5-12 years participated in structured interviews, following the intervention. A framework approach to thematic content analysis was used. Themes, categories, & subcategories were established. Parents discussed the usefulness of the intervention & the service in relation to therapeutic work (behavioral techniques & advice), support, practical help, & liaison with other agencies. They also identified service gaps. A number of factors were identified as responsible for improvement, both directly arising from & independently of the intervention. Despite their young age, children had good understanding of the interventions & their role in them, & expressed their wish for active involvement. The intervention was underpinned by a solution-focused therapy model, combined with behavioral techniques. Families' perceptions indicate that they predominantly applied behavioral strategies, while some parents & children generated solutions in other areas of their lives. Family support has an important preventive role & should consist of an integral component of interagency services for children with a broad range of behavioral & emotional difficulties & their families, & have close links with child mental health services. 2 Tables, 2 Figures, 24 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Parents%27+and+Children%27s+Perceptions+of+a+Family+Support+Intervention+for+Child+Behavioural+Problems&amp;rft.au=Window%2C+Suzanne%3BRichards%2C+Maxine%3BVostanis%2C+Panos&amp;rft.aulast=Window&amp;rft.aufirst=Suzanne&amp;rft.date=2004-03-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=113&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0265053042000180554

Commentary on 'Parents and Children's Perceptions of a Family Support Intervention for Child Behavioural Problems' by Suzanne Window, Maxine Richards and Panos Vostanis

Author: Walker, Steven11 School Community Health & Social Studies, APU, Chelmsford, Essex walker54@supanet.com

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61502763?accountid=14667

Abstract: Discusses the concept of family support & suggests a psychosocial model to address research & implementation deficiencies. The findings of the article by Window, Richards, & Vostanis, "Parents and Children's Perceptions of a Family Support Intervention for Child Behavioural Problems" (2004) serve as a foundation for a social worker response to the underlying psychosocial factors of child & adolescent mental health issues. Risk & resilience factors are listed, & the elaboration of a psychosocial model is advocated. 19 References. Adapted from the source document.

The NP3 September Study Day: A Participant's Account

Author: Parkinson, Clare11 U East London, Dagenham, Essex, UK c.p.parkinson@uel.ac.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61554531?accountid=14667

Abstract: Discusses the value of a workshop study day in enhancing the relationship-based approach for social work teachers. In small groups, various subjects were examined, including how to enhance a learning space for creative thinking under pressure & other areas of interest for social work instructors. Adapted from the source document.

Community Work and Psychosocial Practice -- Chalk and Cheese or Birds of a Feather?

Author: Walker, Steven11 School Community Health & Social Studies, Anglia Polytechnic U, Chelmsford, Essex, UK s.walker@apu.ac.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61517663?accountid=14667

Abstract: Orthodox assumptions about different methods of social work practice need to be reexamined & refined in order to continue to ensure that the profession is using the most relevant & effective ways of assessing & intervening in contemporary child & family practice. This paper suggests that the rigid distinctions between practice orientations serve to hinder, rather than foster creativity & flexibility, in modern complex situations. Community work & psychosocial practice appear to have little in common but seen through fresh eyes & with intellectual agility they can be perceived as offering the optimum combination for an integrated holistic approach that can contribute to a socially inclusive practice while simultaneously effecting change at the intra-psychic level. 90 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Community+Work+and+Psychosocial+Practice+--+Chalk+and+Cheese+or+Birds+of+a+Feather%3F&amp;rft.au=Walker%2C+Steven&amp;rft.aulast=Walker&amp;rft.aufirst=Steven&amp;rft.date=2004-07-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=161&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0265053042000230981

Matching and Mismatching in Teenage Adoptions: Implications of the Adoption Act for Practice

Author: Briggs, Stephen1; Webb, Liz1 Tavistock Centre, London, UK sbriggs@tavi-port.nhs.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61552707?accountid=14667

Abstract: The Adoption & Children Act 2002 has considerable implications for practice. Targets for increasing the numbers of children leaving care for adoption will mean an increased emphasis on adoption for older children, for whom disruption rates have been high. Relatively little is known about teenagers in adoption, including knowledge about which kinds of young people succeed with which kinds of parents. Nor is much known about which kinds of service provide most appropriate & helpful support for adopted teenagers. The Adoption Act requires comprehensive post-adoption support services, which will include specialist therapeutically oriented services. This paper reviews teenage adoptions, & pays particular attention to the ways in which therapeutically oriented post-adoption services might make a significant contribution. This leads to a discussion of factors that underpin processes of 'matching' between young people & their adoptive parents. 41 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Matching+and+Mismatching+in+Teenage+Adoptions%3A+Implications+of+the+Adoption+Act+for+Practice&amp;rft.au=Briggs%2C+Stephen%3BWebb%2C+Liz&amp;rft.aulast=Briggs&amp;rft.aufirst=Stephen&amp;rft.date=2004-07-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=181&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F026505304200059430

Revisiting the Agent of Social Control Role: Implications for Substance Abuse Treatment

Author: Burman, Sondra11 Schusterman Center, School Social Work, U Oklahoma, Tulsa sburman@ou.edu

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61510184?accountid=14667

Abstract: The agent of social control & its responsibilities & goals provide an important function in social work practice. Workers in varied positions often combine this role with others that define the profession. Yet in the not too distant past, a debate arose as to whether this role, focusing on promoting & protecting the general welfare of society, could be congruent with also fostering the improved functioning & self-determination of individual clients. Periodically, this topic emerges to challenge the appropriateness of these dual activities in satisfactorily & equitably serving both constituents. 43 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Revisiting+the+Agent+of+Social+Control+Role%3A+Implications+for+Substance+Abuse+Treatment&amp;rft.au=Burman%2C+Sondra&amp;rft.aulast=Burman&amp;rft.aufirst=Sondra&amp;rft.date=2004-07-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=197&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0265053042000231016

Rewards and Frustrations of Being a Social Worker: A Qualitative Study

Author: Francozo, Maria de Fatima de Campos1; Cassorla, Roosevelt Moises Smeke1 Cepre-Unicamp, Campinas, Brazil

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61551527?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper deals with aspects of actual professional experience of social workers, in order to grasp a framework for professional rewards & frustrations. A qualitative research tool was chosen, life histories, & social workers interviewed (N = 10). The subjects were women who graduated between the 1950s & the 1990s from schools of social work in Brazil, & whose practice, present or past, involves direct contact with clients. The reasons explaining satisfying professional situations are rooted in professional experiences that were translated into personal development, the establishment of personal ties, & the acquisition of skills. Perceptions of having contributed toward solving a difficult situation & recognition from their clients were positively appraised. These are rewarding situations from which social workers derive the feeling of having created something that is positive for the clients & for themselves. Unpleasant situations were described as unfair situations experienced by clients, poor working conditions, & difficulties concerning interprofessional relationships. Inferences on the feminine role as influencing social workers' rewards & frustrations with the profession, as well as inferences on possible unconscious configurations underlying some of the data were drawn. 12 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Rewards+and+Frustrations+of+Being+a+Social+Worker%3A+A+Qualitative+Study&amp;rft.au=Francozo%2C+Maria+de+Fatima+de+Campos%3BCassorla%2C+Roosevelt+Moises+Smeke&amp;rft.aulast=Francozo&amp;rft.aufirst=Maria+de+Fatima+de&amp;rft.date=2004-07-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=211&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0265053042000231025

The Contribution of Psychoanalytical Observation in Child Protection Assessments

Author: Fleming, Shelagh

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61524468?accountid=14667

Abstract: In this paper, I describe my role in undertaking child protection assessments in my work for a family center managed by a national voluntary child care organization. I explore how psychoanalytical observation provides additional knowledge informing assessments of risk for children. In an example that I discuss in some detail, I show how observation provides a means for assessing relationships between children & parents that leads to informed recommendations to court. In a second example, I show how observation can be linked with a therapeutic approach to generate necessary change in parenting capacity. I conclude that observation is an important & effective training for professionals responsible for protecting children from harm. 20 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=The+Contribution+of+Psychoanalytical+Observation+in+Child+Protection+Assessments&amp;rft.au=Fleming%2C+Shelagh&amp;rft.aulast=Fleming&amp;rft.aufirst=Shelagh&amp;rft.date=2004-07-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=223&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0265053042000206041

Too Close In or Too Far Out -- Learning to Hold the Role of Observer: Tutors' Introduction to a Social Work Student's Reflections on Her Experience of Learning through Child Observation

Author: McMahon, Linnet1; Farnfield, Steve1 School Health & Social Care, U Reading, Earley, UK

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61490517?accountid=14667

Abstract: In this & a second linked paper (Natasha Quitak, 'Difficulties in Holding the Role of the Observer'), social work tutors & a former student examine the learning that can come from the experience of infant & child observation in social work qualifying training. The ability to hold the role of observer is an essential skill for social work that can to a large extent be learned. It involves finding a distance close enough to experience the feelings involved in the child's relationships but far enough out to be able to think about them. Difficulties in managing the anxieties involved in the task may be linked to students' own familial & cultural patterns of relating. Attachment theory & psychodynamic thinking provide the theoretical underpinning for learning. 10 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Too+Close+In+or+Too+Far+Out+--+Learning+to+Hold+the+Role+of+Observer%3A+Tutors%27+Introduction+to+a+Social+Work+Student%27s+Reflections+on+Her+Experience+of+Learning+through+Child+Observation&amp;rft.au=McMahon%2C+Linnet%3BFarnfield%2C+Steve&amp;rft.aulast=McMahon&amp;rft.aufirst=Linnet&amp;rft.date=2004-07-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=239&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0265053042000231034

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Too+Close+In+or+Too+Far+Out+--+Learning+to+Hold+the+Role+of+Observer%3A+Tutors%27+Introduction+to+a+Social+Work+Student%27s+Reflections+on+Her+Experience+of+Learning+through+Child+Observation&amp;rft.au=McMahon%2C+Linnet%3BFarnfield%2C+Steve&amp;rft.aulast=McMahon&amp;rft.aufirst=Linnet&amp;rft.date=2004-07-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=239&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0265053042000231034

____________________________________________________________

Difficulties in Holding the Role of the Observer

Author: Quitak, Natasha11 School Health & Social Care, U Reading, Earley, UK

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61532491?accountid=14667

Abstract: This is the second of two linked papers on learning from infant & child observation in social work qualifying training (linked with Linnet McMahon & Steve Farnfield 'Too Close In or Too Far Out'). A former student reflects on her own observation experience. She considers the anxieties aroused & their containment, which became possible initially through reflection in the seminar group & ultimately through her internalization of the reflective process. She discusses the value of her learning in subsequent practice in palliative care. 16 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Difficulties+in+Holding+the+Role+of+the+Observer&amp;rft.au=Quitak%2C+Natasha&amp;rft.aulast=Quitak&amp;rft.aufirst=Natasha&amp;rft.date=2004-07-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=247&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0265053042000231052

Killing the Angel in a Room of One's Own. Being as Unconscious as Possible When Writing Up Qualitative Research

Author: Smith, Martin11 Katharine Knapp House, Stretton Close, Tylers Green, Buckinghamshire, UK msmith@buckscc.gov.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61551580?accountid=14667

Abstract: The author begins this paper by establishing a context of writing within a qualitative research framework. He goes on to identify blocks to writing in part one of the paper. In part two, various strategies for negotiating these blocks are suggested & illustrated. Extracts of writings from George Orwell, Virginia Woolf, Dylan Thomas, & Ted Hughes, among others, are used to show how these great writers have acknowledged & negotiated blocks in the production of their work. Links & connections with writing up qualitative research are made. The crucial & recurring theme of the paper is that the unconscious is to be trusted as an invaluable ally in accessing & producing writing of value. Thinking about writing, while necessary to some extent, should therefore be given second place to the primary importance of clearing a space within which the unconscious can be befriended & surprise us & thereby facilitate the writing process. 24 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Killing+the+Angel+in+a+Room+of+One%27s+Own.+Being+as+Unconscious+as+Possible+When+Writing+Up+Qualitative+Research&amp;rft.au=Smith%2C+Martin&amp;rft.aulast=Smith&amp;rft.aufirst=Martin&amp;rft.date=2004-07-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=255&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0265053042000231043

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Killing+the+Angel+in+a+Room+of+One%27s+Own.+Being+as+Unconscious+as+Possible+When+Writing+Up+Qualitative+Research&amp;rft.au=Smith%2C+Martin&amp;rft.aulast=Smith&amp;rft.aufirst=Martin&amp;rft.date=2004-07-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=255&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0265053042000231043

Infant Observation as Research: Cross-Disciplinary Links

Author: Rhode, Maria11 Tavistock Centre, U East London, UK mrhode@tavi-port.nhs.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61498514?accountid=14667

Abstract: Infant observation has long been an essential part of many clinical trainings, as well as a component of some academic courses in applied psychoanalysis, but its research potential is just beginning to be tapped. This paper reviews some of the literature on infant observation as a research method. This type of naturalistic observation is compared & contrasted with empirical research in the laboratory with regard to the results that may best be obtained by each method. Strategies for the retrieval of information from process recordings are discussed, & the importance of convergent findings from different lines of enquiry & of theoretical triangulation is considered. Observations illustrating language development are used as an example of the further dimension that naturalistic observations can contribute to formulations deriving from clinical practice & empirical laboratory research. It is argued that convergences with psychoanalytic theory & with formulations from other disciplines, such as literary criticism, strengthen the confidence that may be accorded to formulations deriving from infant observation. 61 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Infant+Observation+as+Research%3A+Cross-Disciplinary+Links&amp;rft.au=Rhode%2C+Maria&amp;rft.aulast=Rhode&amp;rft.aufirst=Maria&amp;rft.date=2004-11-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=283&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0265053042000314384

Researching Relationships from an Attachment Perspective: The Use of Behavioral, Interview, Self-Report and Projective Measures

Author: Shemmings, David11 U East Anglia, Norwich, Norfolk d.shemmings@uea.ac.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61433917?accountid=14667

Abstract: Having demonstrated its credentials as one of the more elegant & robust conceptualizations of human relationships, attachment theory has considerable relevance to social work. Attachment-based research has flourished over the past few years & it now includes an impressive array of studies across the lifespan. This article considers four different measures used in attachment-based research, although more discussion is devoted to interview & projective measures because they specifically embrace a psychodynamic approach in their design & analytic focus. The aim of the article is to provide a brief overview of each measure & to offer some illustrative examples using practice-related material. 1 Figure, 32 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Researching+Relationships+from+an+Attachment+Perspective%3A+The+Use+of+Behavioral%2C+Interview%2C+Self-Report+and+Projective+Measures&amp;rft.au=Shemmings%2C+David&amp;rft.aulast=Shemmings&amp;rft.aufirst=David&amp;rft.date=2004-11-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=299&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0265053042000314393

Inside-Out: Resocialisation from Prison as a Biographical Process. A Longitudinal Approach to the Psychodynamics of Imprisonment

Author: Bereswill, Mechthild11 Criminological Research Instit, U Hannover, Germany bereswill@kfn.uni-hannover.de

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61544348?accountid=14667

Abstract: Closed institutions for juveniles have always been subject to public debates. The polarized arguments that have been exchanged for years in media, politics, & practice are in the end not very helpful in terms of a deeper understanding of the effects of total institutions, especially in respect of understanding the influence of imprisonment on the ongoing integration conflicts of socially marginalized adolescents. The following text approaches the experience of imprisonment & release from the perspective of young males being imprisoned in juvenile detention centers in Germany from a qualitative & longitudinal research design. Three case examples are discussed under the focus of a psychodynamic approach: how do the young men experience incarceration? How does the double-bind structure of pressure & care shape their biographical self-concepts? Which autonomy conflicts do adolescent prisoners have to go through when they leave the closed institution? In all three cases we see that prison is perceived as an institution that promises a holding structure -- a promise that cannot be fulfilled & that reinforces the psychosocial conflicts of marginalized adolescents. 43 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Inside-Out%3A+Resocialisation+from+Prison+as+a+Biographical+Process.+A+Longitudinal+Approach+to+the+Psychodynamics+of+Imprisonment&amp;rft.au=Bereswill%2C+Mechthild&amp;rft.aulast=Bereswill&amp;rft.aufirst=Mechthild&amp;rft.date=2004-11-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=315&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0265053042000314401

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Inside-Out%3A+Resocialisation+from+Prison+as+a+Biographical+Process.+A+Longitudinal+Approach+to+the+Psychodynamics+of+Imprisonment&amp;rft.au=Bereswill%2C+Mechthild&amp;rft.aulast=Bereswill&amp;rft.aufirst=Mechthild&amp;rft.date=2004-11-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=315&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0265053042000314401

____________________________________________________________

Emotional Retreat and Social Exclusion: Towards Biographical Methods in Professional Training

Author: Chamberlayne, Prue11 School Health & Social Welfare, Open U, Milton Keynes, UK p.m.chamberlayne@open.ac.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61433913?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article argues the relevance of biographical case study methods as a tool for professional practice. The case of Laura, manager of a small hostel for homeless people, shows hidden reserves of emotional understanding that Laura finds too risky to bring into play. Analysis of the structure of the interview shows the enactment & lowering of Laura's defenses in interaction with the interviewer. The article argues for support & supervision to allow professionals to recognize & use their capacities for emotional thinking, & that this kind of "experiential truth" is key both for users & professionals in tackling social exclusion. Methodological parallels between biographical methods & effective training are also drawn through discussion of responses to a training video based on a fictionalized version of a critical incident from this interview. 30 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Emotional+Retreat+and+Social+Exclusion%3A+Towards+Biographical+Methods+in+Professional+Training&amp;rft.au=Chamberlayne%2C+Prue&amp;rft.aulast=Chamberlayne&amp;rft.aufirst=Prue&amp;rft.date=2004-11-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=337&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0265053042000314410

Interactions among 'Other Women': Creating Personal and Social Meaning

Author: Puigvert, Lidia1; Elboj, Carmen1 Dept Sociological Theory, U Barcelona, Spain

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61544859?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article examines the experiences of the "other women", non-academic women, who have created spaces of dialogue in which they are building networks & transforming their lives. It offers an analysis of the psychological & educational barriers they overcome in order to create personal & social change. It shows how dialogic & egalitarian learning & associative settings allow the other women to express their voices & build new proposals for the present & future. This has the potential to present new avenues for social workers & educators in their work with women in general & marginalized women in particular, pointing to more dialogic & egalitarian relationships & dynamics. 25 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Interactions+among+%27Other+Women%27%3A+Creating+Personal+and+Social+Meaning&amp;rft.au=Puigvert%2C+Lidia%3BElboj%2C+Carmen&amp;rft.aulast=Puigvert&amp;rft.aufirst=Lidia&amp;rft.date=2004-11-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=351&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0265053042000314429

____________________________________________________________

Achieving Reflexivity: Moving Researchers from Analysis to Interpretation in Collaborative Inquiry

Author: Savin-Baden, Maggi11 Coventry U, UK m.savinbaden@coventry.ac.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61529184?accountid=14667

Abstract: The idea of "teaching" reflexivity might seem to some to be a nonsense but many students, both undergraduate & postgraduate, struggle with "it" as a concept, a process, & as a means of moving away from simplistic themed research categories toward in-depth interpretation. This paper will examine the nature of reflexivity from the perspective of a personal stance & suggest the use of particular strategies for interpreting data reflexively. Such strategies include the use of biographical accounts & organizing principles, the exploration of metaphor & metonymy & the utilization of poetry as an interpretative device. It will offer particular ways of undertaking reflexive interpretation that have been used successfully with many postgraduate students & researchers. 18 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Achieving+Reflexivity%3A+Moving+Researchers+from+Analysis+to+Interpretation+in+Collaborative+Inquiry&amp;rft.au=Savin-Baden%2C+Maggi&amp;rft.aulast=Savin-Baden&amp;rft.aufirst=Maggi&amp;rft.date=2004-11-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=365&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0265053042000314438

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Achieving+Reflexivity%3A+Moving+Researchers+from+Analysis+to+Interpretation+in+Collaborative+Inquiry&amp;rft.au=Savin-Baden%2C+Maggi&amp;rft.aulast=Savin-Baden&amp;rft.aufirst=Maggi&amp;rft.date=2004-11-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=365&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0265053042000314438

____________________________________________________________

Dilemmas in Research: Issues of Vulnerability and Disempowerment for the Social Worker/Researcher

Author: Davison, Judy11 Dept Health & Community Studies, Bournemouth U, Wigton, UK jdavison@bournemouth.ac.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61544215?accountid=14667

Abstract: Qualitative research ethics discussions have established a sound knowledge & practice base that advises on the protection & rights of the research informants. This paper, although supporting the primacy of informant safety, will highlight less visible research debates. The potential for vulnerability & harm of the social work researcher will be explored. The value of achieving heightened empathy & emotional resonance with research participants is considered as a process which the author suggests is likely to increase the richness of the research data, but also may accentuate researcher vulnerability or distress. The author's experience of doing personal research with vulnerable informants, & of being a social work research supervisor, will be used to reflect on processes & practices that she claims may make social work researchers particularly vulnerable to conflict & distress. Data from her recent research which explored the experiences of social work researchers will be used to illustrate these issues. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Dilemmas+in+Research%3A+Issues+of+Vulnerability+and+Disempowerment+for+the+Social+Worker%2FResearcher&amp;rft.au=Davison%2C+Judy&amp;rft.aulast=Davison&amp;rft.aufirst=Judy&amp;rft.date=2004-11-01&amp;rft.volume=18&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=379&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F0265053042000314447

Exploring Fatherhood: Masculinity and Intersubjectivity in the Research Process

Author: Robb, Martin11 School Health & Social Welfare, Open U, Milton Keynes, UK m.p.robb@open.ac.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61454229?accountid=14667

Abstract: Exploring issues of fatherhood with men raises important questions about how identities are produced in the research process, & particularly about the part played by gender when both researcher & "researched" are men. The article draws on the author's recent research with British fathers & makes extensive use of an individual case study to suggest ways in which defensive & intersubjective processes interact in the production of one man's narrative of fatherhood & in the process of interpretation & analysis. The article's conclusions have implications both for researching masculinity & for working with men. 22 References. Adapted from the source document.

Psychotherapy for Parents: A Protective Factor for Children at Risk

Author: Brennan, Sue

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61523345?accountid=14667

Abstract: In this paper I shall provide a self-reflective account of the development of a psychoanalytic psychotherapy service for the parents & carers of children considered to be at risk of abuse or neglect by social workers or child mental health professionals. I will discuss some of my thinking in setting up such a service & the difficulties, both clinical & operational, that I have encountered. I will draw tentative conclusions about the effectiveness of once-weekly psychotherapy for parents in protecting their children from harm & promoting their development. I will illustrate the difficulties & my conclusions with clinical material. 8 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Psychotherapy+for+Parents%3A+A+Protective+Factor+for+Children+at+Risk&amp;rft.au=Brennan%2C+Sue&amp;rft.aulast=Brennan&amp;rft.aufirst=Sue&amp;rft.date=2005-03-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=5&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530500071803

An Intersubjective Perspective on Vicarious Trauma and Its Impact on the Clinical Process

Author: Rasmussen, Brian11 School Social Work, U British Columbia, Okanagan, Kelowna brasmussen@ouc.bc.ca

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61523289?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper suggests that intersubjectivity theory provides a valuable metatheoretical framework to understand the dynamic interplay of vicarious traumatization within clinical practice. Practice implications of this view shift our attention to what lies between the therapist & client, the impact of working with traumatized clients, as well as the need for clinical supervision. With an emphasis on context, mutuality, reciprocal interaction, affect regulation, emotional understanding, countertransference, cotransference, & empathy, intersubjectivity theory provides an additional perspective on trauma, the clinical process, & its impact on the therapist. 35 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=An+Intersubjective+Perspective+on+Vicarious+Trauma+and+Its+Impact+on+the+Clinical+Process&amp;rft.au=Rasmussen%2C+Brian&amp;rft.aulast=Rasmussen&amp;rft.aufirst=Brian&amp;rft.date=2005-03-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=19&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530500071829

Teaching in Lithuania -- The Personal and the Professional: The Role of the Countertransference

Author: Linford, Sandra11 British Assoc Psychotherapists, London, UK sandra@linford99.freeserve.co.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61558718?accountid=14667

Abstract: The aim of this paper is to demonstrate the central role of the countertransference as a catalyst for understanding for both teacher & student. During a week of teaching basic psychoanalytic concepts to Lithuanian university students in central Lithuania, I discovered that there was an absence or lack of understanding between the group I was teaching & myself. Our expectations were very different. On a political, cultural level, I was faced with a Lithuanian understanding of the world that is quite different from a Western European perspective. This personal narrative explores how I used my countertransference to the group, & their countertransference to their clinical work, as a tool to begin to explore the professional issues we have in common & to struggle to understand the differences. It was impressive to observe, through the lived experience of this work, the development of a well-functioning group that had overcome not only the difficulties that accompany large groups but that had taken on board a new way of thinking & working. I returned in October 2004 for a further week's teaching & a continuation of a joint teaching-learning enterprise. 6 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Teaching+in+Lithuania+--+The+Personal+and+the+Professional%3A+The+Role+of+the+Countertransference&amp;rft.au=Linford%2C+Sandra&amp;rft.aulast=Linford&amp;rft.aufirst=Sandra&amp;rft.date=2005-03-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=31&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530500071845

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Teaching+in+Lithuania+--+The+Personal+and+the+Professional%3A+The+Role+of+the+Countertransference&amp;rft.au=Linford%2C+Sandra&amp;rft.aulast=Linford&amp;rft.aufirst=Sandra&amp;rft.date=2005-03-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=31&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530500071845

'Acting as a Good Parent Would'? Psychosocial Support for Parents in a Children's Hospital

Author: Sudbery, John1; Blenkinship, Angela1 School Community/Health Sciences/Social Care, U Salford, UK j.sudbery@salford.ac.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61433645?accountid=14667

Abstract: In a children's hospital, the primary responsibility of attending to the physical well-being of the child also requires skilled attention to the needs of parents or other family members. This paper draws on the experience of a hospital-based support service to explore the diversity of these needs. Particular use is made of attachment theory & psychodynamic thinking to analyze what is involved, & the paper highlights social work's psychosocial model as the framework which integrates the practical, cognitive & the emotional, the individual & social dimensions. 1 Appendix, 24 References. Adapted from the source document.

Taking the Debate on Reflexivity Further: Psychodynamic Team Analysis of a BNIM Interview

Author: Buckner, Stefanie11 Dept Social Work, U Central Lancashire stef.buckner@gmail.com

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61557847?accountid=14667

Abstract: Much has been written on the presence of researcher subjectivity in qualitative research & the concept of reflexivity, & efforts to account for researcher influence abound. A vast proportion of this literature examines interviewer effects & is confined to the relationship between researcher & respondent in the interview interaction. The present paper extends this focus. It contributes insights from a collaborative team project by presenting a case study of a biographical-narrative interview in an organizational setting. The psychodynamically informed panel analysis considered dynamics not only in the interview, but also in the research team & the organization. This proved valuable in making explicit latent ways in which the interviewer, subject to such wider dynamics, shaped the interview accordingly. The paper shows that awareness of the nature of researcher influence can lead to important insights about the phenomenon studied. 17 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Taking+the+Debate+on+Reflexivity+Further%3A+Psychodynamic+Team+Analysis+of+a+BNIM+Interview&amp;rft.au=Buckner%2C+Stefanie&amp;rft.aulast=Buckner&amp;rft.aufirst=Stefanie&amp;rft.date=2005-03-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=59&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530500071969

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Taking+the+Debate+on+Reflexivity+Further%3A+Psychodynamic+Team+Analysis+of+a+BNIM+Interview&amp;rft.au=Buckner%2C+Stefanie&amp;rft.aulast=Buckner&amp;rft.aufirst=Stefanie&amp;rft.date=2005-03-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=59&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530500071969

The Long Gone Promise of Social Work: Ambivalence and Individualisation in Social Services Administration

Author: Andersen, Linda Lundgaard11 Dept Educational Studies, Roskilde U, Denmark lla@ruc.dk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61508890?accountid=14667

Abstract: The article analyses one case: a sickness benefit office in a social services department. It takes as a starting point that organizations function as projection surfaces for fantasies, emotions & reactions. The psycho-societal perspective clarifies how a social services department transfers a crucial dilemma in social work onto social workers by processes of individualizing. The dilemma relates to the disparity between clients' complex life situations & the limited possibilities for social workers to resolve them. There is an ambiguity in this transference. In cases of failure, management seeks explanations not by looking at possible organizational or societal restrictions or explanations, but rather at the social workers' personal & professional life histories -- they are subjected to a life historic individualization & stigmatisation. Social workers, on the other hand, display ambivalence towards influencing case administrative work, which can be interpreted as an adequate defense mechanism. The article then introduces the concept of individualization that reflects the dialectic processes of subjectivity & objectivity & leads to a contextualized analysis of social work. 22 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=The+Long+Gone+Promise+of+Social+Work%3A+Ambivalence+and+Individualisation+in+Social+Services+Administration&amp;rft.au=Andersen%2C+Linda+Lundgaard&amp;rft.aulast=Andersen&amp;rft.aufirst=Linda&amp;rft.date=2005-03-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=73&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530500071985

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=The+Long+Gone+Promise+of+Social+Work%3A+Ambivalence+and+Individualisation+in+Social+Services+Administration&amp;rft.au=Andersen%2C+Linda+Lundgaard&amp;rft.aulast=Andersen&amp;rft.aufirst=Linda&amp;rft.date=2005-03-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=73&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530500071985
