Ethnographies of Practice -- Practising Ethnography: Resources for Self-Reflective Social Work

Author: Riemann, Gerhard11 Dept Social Work, U Bamberg, Germany gerhard.riemann@sowes.uni-bamberg.de

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61557803?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper argues that acquiring competencies in different approaches & procedures in qualitative or interpretative social research provides a strong foundation for case analysis in professional social work practice. When students of social work become familiar with such research & are encouraged to engage in their own supervised projects they develop skills for a circumspect & sensitive practice with clients. The paper reports on work with students of social work in Germany, which can be described as an attempt to help them to become self-reflective ethnographers in their own affairs, of their own emergent social work practice. It spells out different phases of a process in which they learn to make their own practice strange. This process consists of developing different competencies in observing, analyzing & writing, & requires a setting in which students' written observations & reflections can be shared & discussed by their peers in a critical, egalitarian & supportive manner. The author thinks that such a critical & self-critical discourse which addresses professional issues in general, as well as the individual student's (or practioner's) experiences & reflections, can have important implications for the collective development of social work & its relationship with other professions. 33 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Ethnographies+of+Practice+--+Practising+Ethnography%3A+Resources+for+Self-Reflective+Social+Work&amp;rft.au=Riemann%2C+Gerhard&amp;rft.aulast=Riemann&amp;rft.aufirst=Gerhard&amp;rft.date=2005-03-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=87&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530500072009

An Exploration of the Issues Raised by Living with a Child with Autistic Spectrum Disorder and a Professional's Attempt to Move beyond Pity and Blame

Author: Hingley-Jones, Helen11 Middlesex U, UK H.Hingley-Jones@mdx.ac.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61433327?accountid=14667

Abstract: A case study is introduced to help explain why working with disabled children & their families can sometimes seem like a complex & demanding task for professionals. It is suggested that the emotional component of the parent/professional relationship, particularly where autistic spectrum disorder (ASD) is concerned, can be highly charged & that those concerned can get caught-up unwittingly in a cycle of pity & blame. Psychoanalytic ideas are drawn in to help make sense of the pity/blame cycle, including thoughts about projection, guilt & shame. The importance of moving beyond this state is discussed. An understanding of the possible origins of the difficult emotional circumstances of Juliet & her family & a way forward is indicated. The implications for professionals working in this area are considered. 14 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=An+Exploration+of+the+Issues+Raised+by+Living+with+a+Child+with+Autistic+Spectrum+Disorder+and+a+Professional%27s+Attempt+to+Move+beyond+Pity+and+Blame&amp;rft.au=Hingley-Jones%2C+Helen&amp;rft.aulast=Hingley-Jones&amp;rft.aufirst=Helen&amp;rft.date=2005-07-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=115&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530500143677

____________________________________________________________

Hungry Researchers: The Tensions and Dilemmas of Developing an Emancipatory Research Project with Members of a Hearing Voices Group

Author: Snelling, Emma11 Macmillan Centre, Derriford Hospital, UK emma-snelling@hotmail.com

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61554067?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper follows my experience of developing an emancipatory research project with members of a Hearing Voices Group (HVG) while working simultaneously as both a group facilitator & a researcher. I hope to highlight both the potential of this type of researching as well as some of the tensions & dilemmas. Working with group members whose voices had often been subjugated meant that this power imbalance & ways of addressing it were integral to the research project. Informed by critical psychological & social constructionist perspectives I wanted to undertake a project which would directly benefit the individual participants as well as provide a wider social relevance. I will argue that both the theoretical & methodological perspectives the researcher draws on in order to do this will have a profound impact on the emancipatory potential of the research for both the researcher & researched, especially by determining what stories it is possible to tell. I would like to reflect on the experience of undertaking this research drawing on an interview in which I used the Biographical Narrative Interpretive Method to highlight its potential & limitations for facilitating this type of research. 53 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Hungry+Researchers%3A+The+Tensions+and+Dilemmas+of+Developing+an+Emancipatory+Research+Project+with+Members+of+a+Hearing+Voices+Group&amp;rft.au=Snelling%2C+Emma&amp;rft.aulast=Snelling&amp;rft.aufirst=Emma&amp;rft.date=2005-07-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=131&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530500144584

Negotiating Professional and Social Voices in Research Principles and Practice

Author: Hunter, Shona11 Instit Women's Studies, Cartmel Coll, Lancaster U, UK s.hunter@lancaster.ac.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61530919?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper draws on work conducted for a qualitative interview based study which explores the gendered racialised & professional identifications of health & social care professionals. Participants for the project were drawn from the professional executive committees of recently formed Primary Care Groups/Trusts. The paper discusses how the feminist psychosocial methodological approach developed for the project is theoretically, practically & ethically useful in exploring the voices of those in positions of relative power in relation to both health & social care services & the social relations of gender & ethnicity. The approach draws on psychodynamic accounts of (defended) subjectivity & the feminist work of Carol Gilligan on a voice-centred relational methodology. Coupling the feminist with the psychosocial facilitates an emphasis on voice & dialogic communication between participant & researcher not always captured in psychosocial approaches which tend towards favouring the interviewer as a 'good listener'. This emphasis on dialogue is important in research contexts where prior & ongoing relationships with professional participants make it difficult & indeed undesirable for researchers to maintain silence. 49 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Negotiating+Professional+and+Social+Voices+in+Research+Principles+and+Practice&amp;rft.au=Hunter%2C+Shona&amp;rft.aulast=Hunter&amp;rft.aufirst=Shona&amp;rft.date=2005-07-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=149&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530500144709

Building on Personal Networks When Intervening with Multi-Problem Poor Families

Author: Sousa, Liliana11 Health Sciences Dept, U Aveiro, Portugal Lilianax@cs.ua.pt

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61511280?accountid=14667

Abstract: Which strengths exist in the personal social networks of members of multi-problem poor families? This is a crucial question at a time when a substantial amount of data demonstrates the protector effect of social ties & the harmful effect of their insufficiency in aspects such as well-being, personal development & social adjustment. In addition, recent research has demonstrated that professionals are no longer the only providers of solutions for the problems of families & individuals in need. Therefore, personal networks must be involved so that intervention is based on the competences & strengths of the family, its members & the social networks of these elements. With the aim of analyzing the strengths which exist in the personal social networks of members of multi-problem poor families, a sample of 100 members of these families was surveyed, using a structured interview, based on Sluzki (La red social: frontera de la practica sistemica, Gedisa, Barcelona, 1996). The main results of this exploratory study suggest that: strong family ties constitute a resource to be taken into account; friends & neighbours are a resource that needs to be activated; the members of these families need to develop more reciprocal relationships within their personal network; emotional support is an open door towards the activation of other forms of support; it is necessary to give special attention to two sub-groups (women & the elderly). 4 Tables, 22 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Building+on+Personal+Networks+When+Intervening+with+Multi-Problem+Poor+Families&amp;rft.au=Sousa%2C+Liliana&amp;rft.aulast=Sousa&amp;rft.aufirst=Liliana&amp;rft.date=2005-07-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=163&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530500144766

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Building+on+Personal+Networks+When+Intervening+with+Multi-Problem+Poor+Families&amp;rft.au=Sousa%2C+Liliana&amp;rft.aulast=Sousa&amp;rft.aufirst=Liliana&amp;rft.date=2005-07-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=163&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530500144766

Case Study as a Means of Researching Social Work and Improving Practitioner Education

Author: Greenwood, Dennis1; Lowenthal, Del1 Research Centre Therapeutic Education, Roehampton U

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61452714?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article explores the possibility of using case study methodology as a means of researching social work practice & improving practitioner education. The paper begins by exploring the differences between a case study approach that is influenced by a more scientific orientation to research compared with a method that places more emphasis on the description of the case & is less preoccupied with the need to provide proof in terms of empirical or statistical validation. The importance of describing case examples is identified both as a means of developing individual practice but also for the educational value for social workers in general. The work of Polanyi & the concept of 'tacit' knowledge is described as a basis for harnessing the practice depictions that are presented through a descriptive case study approach, where the emphasis is on developing 'working' knowledge as opposed to any preoccupation with definitive truth. Following on from this discussion on methodology & epistemology a phenomenological-hermeneutic case study approach is presented, where the research outcomes are seen in terms of describing possibilities that could form the basis for developing practice & education in social work. 1 Figure, 17 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Case+Study+as+a+Means+of+Researching+Social+Work+and+Improving+Practitioner+Education&amp;rft.au=Greenwood%2C+Dennis%3BLowenthal%2C+Del&amp;rft.aulast=Greenwood&amp;rft.aufirst=Dennis&amp;rft.date=2005-07-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=181&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530500144782

Participatory Evaluation: Navigating the Emotions of Partnerships

Author: Smith, Pam1; Bryan, Karen1 Centre Research Nursing & Midwifery Education, European Instit Health & Medical Sciences, U Surrey, UK

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61491520?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper describes the processes involved in evaluating a Sure Start programme in one inner city area. The evaluation was set up in the spirit of participatory action research in which the researchers aimed to work in partnership with key stakeholders to both enable & sustain supportive evaluative processes. The evaluation supported the aspirations espoused by the national Sure Start agenda to improve the lives of children under four, their parents & communities through an expressed commitment to partnership working. The paper draws on ethnographic reflections to describe & analyse the processes involved in setting up the evaluation over two years. Issues of trust, ambiguity & conflict associated with partnership working are explored. In particular the emotional components of relationships required to work in partnership are described as a means of managing ambiguity & conflict & promoting trust. Emotional labour is taken as a conceptual starting point to analyse the relationships & the organisational conditions required to sustain partnerships. Further psychoanalytic & sociological studies are drawn upon to aid the analysis & in particular to understand the emotional components of partnerships in the relatively uncharted waters of inner city regeneration work. 28 References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Participatory+Evaluation%3A+Navigating+the+Emotions+of+Partnerships&amp;rft.au=Smith%2C+Pam%3BBryan%2C+Karen&amp;rft.aulast=Smith&amp;rft.aufirst=Pam&amp;rft.date=2005-07-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=195&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530500144881

Some Implications of the Children's National Service Framework for Social Work Practice with Regard to Child Mental Health

Author: Lindsey, Caroline11 Tavistock Clinic, London, UK acclindsey@aol.com

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61375829?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper discusses the implications of the recommendations of the Children's National Service Framework for children & young people with mental health problems, & considers the interface with social work practice. Children's mental health has never previously attracted so much attention from government departments. This is seen as a reflection of the recent recognition of the widespread nature of mental health problems in the community & an understanding of the cost to society if they are left unaddressed. Figures, References. Adapted from the source document.

Releasing Potential -- the Future of Social Work and CAMHS

Author: Walker, Steven11 Instit Health & Social Care, Anglia Ruskin U walker54@beeb.net

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61388453?accountid=14667

Abstract: Several recent UK government initiatives are set to have an impact on child & adolescent mental health services. As a result new primary mental health worker & similar posts are being established. These jobs are proving attractive to social workers seeking to develop their special interest in child & adolescent mental health. This article sets out some of the problems & prospects for social workers undertaking them seeking to develop a modern psycho-social practice using psychodynamic skills. References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Releasing+Potential+--+the+Future+of+Social+Work+and+CAMHS&amp;rft.au=Walker%2C+Steven&amp;rft.aulast=Walker&amp;rft.aufirst=Steven&amp;rft.date=2005-11-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=235&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530500291039

A Child Psychotherapist in Primary Mental Health

Author: van Heeswyk, Paul11 Highpoint House, Memorial Hospital, London, UK paul.van-heeswyk@oxleas.nhs.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61392168?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper outlines the author's application of psychodynamic thinking & approaches to brief therapeutic work with children, adolescents & their families in community mental health settings. It is the author's belief that systemic & narrative therapy insights & techniques combine well with psychoanalysis in the assessment & treatment of many concerns felt & expressed by parents & young people. The therapist's tasks are to listen empathically to clients who are in distress & to explore the clients' beliefs about the origins of their problems, as well as their previously attempted solutions. In proceeding at the family's pace, opportunities arise for facilitating more effective ways of resolving conflict. Clients are often more free than they realize to change their interpretation of their experience, & this has important consequences for the maintenance & solution of problems. Brief therapy seeks to remind clients of their strengths & resources & to share ways to encourage clients to resume effective ways of learning about themselves. References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=A+Child+Psychotherapist+in+Primary+Mental+Health&amp;rft.au=van+Heeswyk%2C+Paul&amp;rft.aulast=van+Heeswyk&amp;rft.aufirst=Paul&amp;rft.date=2005-11-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=251&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530500291047

Questions and Hindsight: Work with Zara, an Asylum Seeking Care Leaver

Author: Simpson, Sheila

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61396915?accountid=14667

Abstract: Psychodynamic ideas are used to think about social work with an asylum-seeking young woman with mental health problems. Questions are raised about her needs & our response to them in relation to her individual history, the organization & the wider socio-economic context. These lead to reflections on adolescence & the leaving care task, non-dependence, loss of home & homelessness, fear of madness, attitudes to difference & asylum seekers & institutional racism. Failure & learning from it is also a theme. References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Questions+and+Hindsight%3A+Work+with+Zara%2C+an+Asylum+Seeking+Care+Leaver&amp;rft.au=Simpson%2C+Sheila&amp;rft.aulast=Simpson&amp;rft.aufirst=Sheila&amp;rft.date=2005-11-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=263&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530500291054

An Educational Response to Deliberate Self-Harm: Training, Support and School-Agency Links

Author: Best, Ron11 School Education, Forebel Coll, Roehampton U, London, UK r.best@roehampton.ac.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61383353?accountid=14667

Abstract: Although a contested concept, there is a growing awareness of the phenomenon of deliberate self-harm (DSH) in the UK, & particularly of self-injury by adolescents. Trends in the prevalence of DSH have been monitored, & schools have been used as a means for gathering self-reported data from pupils, but to-date there is no known research on the way self-harm is perceived & responded to by schools & the agencies to which they refer. This paper reports a Nuffield Foundation-funded project which examined the experiences & perceptions of DSH of 34 teachers & others in support & clinical roles. The report includes data on the range & prevalence of self-harming behaviours encountered; levels of awareness amongst school staff; teachers' reactions to DSH; links between schools & other agencies (including CAMHS); & levels of training, support & supervision for teachers & others responding to DSH in school settings. It concludes with a discussion of the implications of the findings, including the potential for CAMHS, social workers & other agencies to provide crucial training & support to 'front-line workers' in schools. References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=An+Educational+Response+to+Deliberate+Self-Harm%3A+Training%2C+Support+and+School-Agency+Links&amp;rft.au=Best%2C+Ron&amp;rft.aulast=Best&amp;rft.aufirst=Ron&amp;rft.date=2005-11-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=275&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530500291070

Making Space for Therapeutic Work with Adolescents and Their Families

Author: Bowley, Julia1; Bratley, Mary1 c/o Bratley -- SAFE, Enfield

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61393110?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper discusses our experiences of working with troubled adolescents in the context of a specialist multi-disciplinary adolescent service that is part of a local CAMHS. We discuss our working practices & explore the importance of the idea of space, both mental & physical, when working with disturbed young people. We develop some different meanings of space through discussing some illustrative case examples. These focus on the importance of thinking space within the team & the development of therapeutic work. References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Making+Space+for+Therapeutic+Work+with+Adolescents+and+Their+Families&amp;rft.au=Bowley%2C+Julia%3BBratley%2C+Mary&amp;rft.aulast=Bowley&amp;rft.aufirst=Julia&amp;rft.date=2005-11-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=289&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530500291096

Action Research, Self Esteem, and Children and Young People in Need with 'Medium Range' Behavioural Difficulties

Author: Barker, Richard1; Reynolds, Joanna; Place, Maurice1 School Health/Community/Education Studies, Northumbria U, Newcastle upon Tyne, UK richard.barker@northumbria.ac.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61370822?accountid=14667

Abstract: There are large numbers of children & young people in need who have significant behavioral or social difficulties but who are not seen to be a sufficient priority for hard pressed agencies to offer services to them until their behavior deteriorates to crisis point. This paper reports the impact of a self esteem group based package on children & young people with such 'medium range' difficulties & considers implications for users & services. Tables, References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Action+Research%2C+Self+Esteem%2C+and+Children+and+Young+People+in+Need+with+%27Medium+Range%27+Behavioural+Difficulties&amp;rft.au=Barker%2C+Richard%3BReynolds%2C+Joanna%3BPlace%2C+Maurice&amp;rft.aulast=Barker&amp;rft.aufirst=Richard&amp;rft.date=2005-11-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=299&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530500291278

Implementation of Parent Management Training at the National Level: The Case of Norway

Author: Ogden, Terje1; Forgatch, Marion S; Askeland, Elisabeth; Patterson, Gerald R; Bullock, Bernadette M1 Atferdssenteret -- Unirand, Oslo, Norway terje.ogden@atferd.unirand.no

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61365780?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article describes early aspects of the nationwide implementation of an evidence-based program (EBP) in Norway & the design for studying program fidelity over time. The EBP is the Parent Management Training, Oregon Model (PMTO). The project is a combination of a 'top down' initiative at the governmental & ministry level, & a 'bottom up' initiative from practitioners seeking effective interventions in the prevention & remediation of behavior problems in children & youth. The main components of the implementation strategy were to (a) establish a national implementation & research center; (b) provide for regional & local participation at county & municipal levels; (c) establish a comprehensive therapist recruitment, training, & maintenance program; (d) create a network for collaboration, supervision, & quality control; (e) conduct clinical outcome research; & (f) study the implementation process. Following the training of three successive generations of PMTO specialists, a study was designed to examine how individual, family, interventionist, organizational, & community characteristics influence program adoption & implementation, as well as how these factors impact upon how PMTO specialists provide the intervention to families with competent adherence to the model. Within the framework of the collaborative North American & Norwegian project, challenges & facilitators in the process of the continental crossing of the PMTO model are discussed. Tables, Figures, References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Implementation+of+Parent+Management+Training+at+the+National+Level%3A+The+Case+of+Norway&amp;rft.au=Ogden%2C+Terje%3BForgatch%2C+Marion+S%3BAskeland%2C+Elisabeth%3BPatterson%2C+Gerald+R%3BBullock%2C+Bernadette+M&amp;rft.aulast=Ogden&amp;rft.aufirst=Terje&amp;rft.date=2005-11-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=317&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530500291518

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Implementation+of+Parent+Management+Training+at+the+National+Level%3A+The+Case+of+Norway&amp;rft.au=Ogden%2C+Terje%3BForgatch%2C+Marion+S%3BAskeland%2C+Elisabeth%3BPatterson%2C+Gerald+R%3BBullock%2C+Bernadette+M&amp;rft.aulast=Ogden&amp;rft.aufirst=Terje&amp;rft.date=2005-11-01&amp;rft.volume=19&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=317&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530500291518

____________________________________________________________

Containing Persecutory Anxiety: Child and Adolescent Mental Health Services and Black and Minority Ethnic Communities

Author: Lowe, Frank11 Tavistock Centre, London, UK flowe@tavi-port.nhs.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61401820?accountid=14667

Abstract: There is a serious problem between CAMHS & black & minority ethnic communities, in particular their lack of access to these services, but this is often denied &/or avoided in the practice of CAMHS professionals. This paper explores the reasons for this. It argues that the inaccessibility/way of functioning of CAMHS, is a defence against its members experiencing persecutory anxiety from engaging with black & minority ethnic people. Whilst avoidance & other defences give some relief to staff, it however damages their confidence & prevents them from realising to the full their capacity for concern & for helpful action. This thesis is illustrated & discussed through examples. References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Containing+Persecutory+Anxiety%3A+Child+and+Adolescent+Mental+Health+Services+and+Black+and+Minority+Ethnic+Communities&amp;rft.au=Lowe%2C+Frank&amp;rft.aulast=Lowe&amp;rft.aufirst=Frank&amp;rft.date=2006-03-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=5&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530600565845

____________________________________________________________

Something in the Air: Otherness, Recognition and Ethics

Author: Treacher, Amal11 Centre Social Work, U Nottingham, UK amal.treacher@nottingham.ac.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61378526?accountid=14667

Abstract: This essay will address the troublesome matter of relatedness between human beings. Taking everyday interactions as a point of investigation & exploration I will explore how recognition is simultaneously essential to human relatedness & impossible to achieve. Similarly, I will argue that an ethical stance is crucial for human relatedness. Using a psychoanalytic & philosophical framework, I will contend that it is essential to know our separateness & our profound connections to one another, & that in short, we are nothing without the other. Drawing upon the work of Arendt, Benjamin, Levinas & Young the complexities of recognition & alterity will be explored. The illusion of feeling emotionally settled & bolstered through the fantasies of recognition are here conceptualised as part of being human & sustaining oneself, & are approached here as problematic processes that need urgent investigation & action. References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Something+in+the+Air%3A+Otherness%2C+Recognition+and+Ethics&amp;rft.au=Treacher%2C+Amal&amp;rft.aulast=Treacher&amp;rft.aufirst=Amal&amp;rft.date=2006-03-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=27&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530600565860

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Something+in+the+Air%3A+Otherness%2C+Recognition+and+Ethics&amp;rft.au=Treacher%2C+Amal&amp;rft.aulast=Treacher&amp;rft.aufirst=Amal&amp;rft.date=2006-03-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=27&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530600565860

____________________________________________________________

Community Centre Practice -- Potential and Possibilities for Creating Change

Author: Sanders, Jackie1; Munford, Robyn1 School Sociology/Social Policy/Social Work, Massey U, Palmerston North, New Zealand j.sanders@massey.ac.nz

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61396531?accountid=14667

Abstract: It has been suggested that community centre practice offers important possibilities for addressing the complex needs of families. This paper arises from a larger study of the Aintree Community Centre. The goal of the research was to understand better the multi-faceted ways in which community centre practice contributed to family & community change. Discussion is structured around the consideration of a single case study of a family seeking support at the Aintree Family & Community Centre. It pays particular attention to the early period of engagement between the family & staff. This focus allows us to explore the contribution which psycho-dynamic & systemic approaches made to practice in the centre & also to think about other characteristics of centre practice that assisted the family to embark upon a journey of change. The complexity of the practitioner/client nexus & the role of the support relationship in client/family change are examined. Through this the value of community centre practice in the delivery of support to families facing complex troubles & the nature of the change process as gradually accumulative can be appreciated. Figures, References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Community+Centre+Practice+--+Potential+and+Possibilities+for+Creating+Change&amp;rft.au=Sanders%2C+Jackie%3BMunford%2C+Robyn&amp;rft.aulast=Sanders&amp;rft.aufirst=Jackie&amp;rft.date=2006-03-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=39&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530600565910

Adapting the Model: Therapeutic Work with Children from Army Families

Author: Briggs, Andrew1; Atkinson, Pam1 Child & Adolescent Mental Health Service, Dartford, Kent, UK Andrew.briggs@btinternet.com

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61356139?accountid=14667

Abstract: The paper discusses the authors' joint-disciplinary therapeutic work with young children & families referred to their under-fives' service within CAMHS. Their familiarity with the Tavistock under-fives model of early, brief, therapeutic intervention allowed them to adapt it for work with these complex referrals. Their model extended the number of sessions available allowing time to better grasp the complex dynamics within the family & the clinical work, whilst offering a service sensitive to the unpredictability of army life. The importance of both practitioners working each case together, or in parallel, is discussed in terms of its ability to meet unconscious material, largely the families' propensity for splitting practitioners. Working with such emotional deprivation brought powerful countertransference material. The model incorporates a weekly case meeting that enabled this material to be better understood. A discussion of work with one family serves to illustrate many of the points raised throughout the paper. References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Adapting+the+Model%3A+Therapeutic+Work+with+Children+from+Army+Families&amp;rft.au=Briggs%2C+Andrew%3BAtkinson%2C+Pam&amp;rft.aulast=Briggs&amp;rft.aufirst=Andrew&amp;rft.date=2006-03-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=51&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530600565951

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Adapting+the+Model%3A+Therapeutic+Work+with+Children+from+Army+Families&amp;rft.au=Briggs%2C+Andrew%3BAtkinson%2C+Pam&amp;rft.aulast=Briggs&amp;rft.aufirst=Andrew&amp;rft.date=2006-03-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=51&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530600565951

____________________________________________________________

Too Little Fear Can Kill You. Staying Alive as a Social Worker

Author: Smith, Martin11 Buckinghamshire Emergency Duty Team, Social Services Dept, High Wycombe, UK msmith@buckscc.gov.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61356181?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper provides a psychodynamic exploration of risk assessment of service users who might represent a danger to others &, in particular, to the social workers involved in their care & treatment. Substantive quotations from participants in a qualitative research study enquiring into experiences of fear in social work & counselling are provided & discussed in the light of psychodynamic theory. Fear is seen to be of crucial & life-enhancing significance, while not listening to the 'survival signals' transmitted from fear responses is shown to be potentially dangerous, even fatal. The need for workers to locate themselves accurately on the continuum of the depressive/paranoid-schizoid position is highlighted throughout as is the need for them to appear to disturbed & disturbing service users as whole people rather than part objects. The importance of clearing a space through the fear to think about what is happening between service user & worker is emphasised & the parts played by the eyes & the emotions in this are also considered. The paper concludes with the contention that workers should aim to cultivate an attitude of appropriate fearfulness as this is a helpful albeit complex balance worth striving for. References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Too+Little+Fear+Can+Kill+You.+Staying+Alive+as+a+Social+Worker&amp;rft.au=Smith%2C+Martin&amp;rft.aulast=Smith&amp;rft.aufirst=Martin&amp;rft.date=2006-03-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=69&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530600565977

Some Thoughts on the Relevance of the Work of D. W. Winnicott for Present Day Social Work Practice with Adults

Author: Dwyer, Sandra11 School Social Work, U Leicester, UK sd83@le.ac.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61401937?accountid=14667

Abstract: The work of D. W. Winnicott is of topical relevance & value to current social work students who are learning to work with adult service users. Winnicott's theories & ideas on essential matters like reliability & proper listening are raised, together with issues of ambivalence, & some implications for inter-professional practice. Winnicott is clear, accessible & meaningful in practice terms, which is what social work students crave. References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Some+Thoughts+on+the+Relevance+of+the+Work+of+D.+W.+Winnicott+for+Present+Day+Social+Work+Practice+with+Adults&amp;rft.au=Dwyer%2C+Sandra&amp;rft.aulast=Dwyer&amp;rft.aufirst=Sandra&amp;rft.date=2006-03-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=83&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530600566116

____________________________________________________________

The Mental Health of Looked After Children: Challenges for CAMHS Provision

Author: McAuley, Colette1; Young, Ciara1 School Sociology/Social Policy/Social Work, Queen's U Belfast, UK c.mcauley@qub.ac.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61374813?accountid=14667

Abstract: Recent prevalence studies in Great Britain have revealed that children who are looked after are almost five times more likely to have a mental disorder than children in the general population. Looked after children are already vulnerable to developing mental health problems by the time they become looked after. They are more likely to come from disadvantaged families where social/environmental risks are present. Many have lived in families where there has been mental illness, alcohol/drug misuse or domestic violence. A large proportion of children who now enter the care system have experienced abuse &/or neglect. The care experience itself &, in particular, the high rate of placement instability, may also contribute to this vulnerability. The general challenges facing child & adolescent mental health service provision for looked after children are considered & issues related to therapeutic work highlighted. References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=The+Mental+Health+of+Looked+After+Children%3A+Challenges+for+CAMHS+Provision&amp;rft.au=McAuley%2C+Colette%3BYoung%2C+Ciara&amp;rft.aulast=McAuley&amp;rft.aufirst=Colette&amp;rft.date=2006-03-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=91&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530600566157

Finding the Words: Social Work from a Developmental Perspective

Author: Van Nijnatten, Carolus11 U Utrecht, Netherlands C.vanNijnatten@fss.uu.nl

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61370449?accountid=14667

Abstract: Dialogue is at the heart of social work. In conversations with the professional, clients speak out about their pains & sorrows, & about their hope & beliefs. The conversation is the place where social worker & client try to find new words to express these emotions. In doing that, they construct new meanings & create new perspectives. The role of dialogue in child development is used to understand this underlying process of social work. It shows how children learn to use language as an instrument to organize their world. The role of social workers is similar to that of parents, to help their clients to find the words that enable them to reposition themselves. As soon as they become the author of their life story again, they will be better able to reconstruct their lives. References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Finding+the+Words%3A+Social+Work+from+a+Developmental+Perspective&amp;rft.au=Van+Nijnatten%2C+Carolus&amp;rft.aulast=Van+Nijnatten&amp;rft.aufirst=Carolus&amp;rft.date=2006-07-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=133&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530600776780

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Finding+the+Words%3A+Social+Work+from+a+Developmental+Perspective&amp;rft.au=Van+Nijnatten%2C+Carolus&amp;rft.aulast=Van+Nijnatten&amp;rft.aufirst=Carolus&amp;rft.date=2006-07-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=133&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530600776780

____________________________________________________________

Jumping on Shadows: Catching the Unconscious in the Classroom

Author: Price, Heather11 School Social Sciences/Media/Cultural Studies, U East London, UK h.s.price@uel.ac.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61378385?accountid=14667

Abstract: This article discusses case material from a psychoanalytically informed ethnographic research project where the author had a dual role as a teaching practitioner & researcher in an infant school. It suggests that practitioner researchers can deepen a concern with reflexivity in the research process by transferring elements of the practice of the psychoanalytic clinician -- specifically, attention to 'counter-transference' -- to their research practice. The article reviews the concept of counter-transference. It suggests that working out the difference between transference & counter-transference may be connected unconsciously to working out the distinctions between ego & superego. The article then goes on to provide an illustration of the way in which the author attempted to use her own counter-transference to inform her research into young children's learning, specifically in relation to her experience of being a teacher. The discussion connects this to the teacher's transferential place as a parental & 'superego' figure for pupils. Observational extracts are drawn from the case study of 'Lutfa', a Bengali girl placed at the lower end of the ability group range. The article concludes by suggesting that attention to counter-transference dynamics as a form of reflexivity can provide the practitioner-researcher with valuable information about the research subjects & about dynamics in the setting, particularly the participants' relationships to 'superego' figures. References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Jumping+on+Shadows%3A+Catching+the+Unconscious+in+the+Classroom&amp;rft.au=Price%2C+Heather&amp;rft.aulast=Price&amp;rft.aufirst=Heather&amp;rft.date=2006-07-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=145&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530600776830

Race-Specific vs. Culturally Competent Social Workers: The Debates and Dilemmas Around Pursuing Essentialist or Multicultural Social Work Practice

Author: Patni, Rachana11 School Health Sciences & Social Care, Brunel U, West London, UK rachana.patni@brunel.ac.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61371053?accountid=14667

Abstract: Many geographical areas of the United Kingdom have a distinct multicultural presence. Welfare services in the United Kingdom need to cater to the needs of this diversity & there is active experimentation with regard to various modes of ensuring effective service delivery to the minorities that represent this diversity. In the past, the burden of being culturally appropriate has been appropriated by the voluntary sector & the community-based organisations. However, the statutory sector now has certain 'named' responsibilities toward ensuring that relevant welfare services are available for various groups of people who might be in need. While there are guidelines & directives to ensure that diversity is attended to, there is a great deal of ambiguity about how this will best be achieved. This paper is an attempt to add to the active deliberations in service provision in a multicultural society & will discuss the pros & cons of the alternatives of race-specific & culturally competent service provisions. It will draw from experiential accounts from working in a race-specific provision & from other studies of relevance. References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Race-Specific+vs.+Culturally+Competent+Social+Workers%3A+The+Debates+and+Dilemmas+Around+Pursuing+Essentialist+or+Multicultural+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.au=Patni%2C+Rachana&amp;rft.aulast=Patni&amp;rft.aufirst=Rachana&amp;rft.date=2006-07-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=163&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530600776863

Alone and Together: Some Thoughts on Reflective Learning for Work with Adult Survivors of Child Sexual Abuse

Author: Leech, Nigel1; Trotter, Joy1 School Health & Social Care, U Teesside, Middlesbrough, UK n.leech@tees.ac.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61378574?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper explores issues around reflective practice & refers to an undergraduate module 'Understanding & Responding to Adult Survivors of Child Sexual Abuse', designed for professionally qualified students undertaking various 'top-up degrees' (e.g. nurses, social workers, midwives, health visitors & other health-care workers). The module incorporated a reflective writing component at the end of each weekly session. In this context we suggest that reflection is an active mulling over of experiences so that difficult thoughts & feelings can be explored & learnt from. Reviewing these writings revealed key personal & emotional experiences, & a number of themes were clearly identified. Although many of the emotions & experiences were recurring, some seemed to be developing over the 10 weeks of the module. We concluded that the group's disparate emotions of denial, fear, disgust & confusion were turned into learning, acceptance & understanding & suggest that these were achieved partly because of the reflective process. This was a crucial factor in the students' learning for themselves & about each other, as well as improving professional practice. Tables, References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Alone+and+Together%3A+Some+Thoughts+on+Reflective+Learning+for+Work+with+Adult+Survivors+of+Child+Sexual+Abuse&amp;rft.au=Leech%2C+Nigel%3BTrotter%2C+Joy&amp;rft.aulast=Leech&amp;rft.aufirst=Nigel&amp;rft.date=2006-07-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=175&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530600776889

____________________________________________________________

Intervention with Multi-Problem Poor Clients: Towards a Strengths-Focused Perspective

Author: Sousa, Liliana1; Ribeiro, Claudia; Rodrigues, Sofia1 Dept Health Sciences, U Aveiro, Portugal lilianax@cs.ua.pt

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61353107?accountid=14667

Abstract: Since multi-problem poor clients are mostly recognized by their problems, intervention is developed from a problem-centered perspective, which has shown itself to be only modestly effective. The strengths perspective, on the other hand, which assumes that every system has competences, has been shown to be more effective. Nevertheless, incorporating the strengths approach is difficult since the problem-centered view is embedded in our social, cultural & professional context. This study aims to learn whether the strengths approach is incorporated (or not) in practice involving multi-problem poor clients, thus allowing us to perceive what obstacles & potentialities to such an approach emerge. An interview was administered to both clients & practitioners, & the results confirm that the problem-centered perspective is dominant & that a shift in perspectives is still in an incipient stage. Tables, References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Intervention+with+Multi-Problem+Poor+Clients%3A+Towards+a+Strengths-Focused+Perspective&amp;rft.au=Sousa%2C+Liliana%3BRibeiro%2C+Claudia%3BRodrigues%2C+Sofia&amp;rft.aulast=Sousa&amp;rft.aufirst=Liliana&amp;rft.date=2006-07-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=189&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530600776913

Working with Involuntary Clients: Perceptions and Experiences of Outreach Social Workers in Hong Kong

Author: Chui, Wing Hong1; Ho, Kit Mui1 School Social Sciences, U Queensland, Australia w.chui@uq.edu.au

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61378623?accountid=14667

Abstract: The outreach social work service is one of the dominant youth work approaches in dealing with delinquents & youths 'at-risk' in Hong Kong. Yet this approach presents particular challenges. Outreach social workers usually play an active role in initiating & establishing contacts with young people, yet young people are reluctant to engage with the outreach social workers & are resistant towards therapeutic change. To date, little is known about what strategies & techniques are most effective in dealing with client resistance in this context. The aims of this paper are to gain a better understanding of the common resistant behaviours that outreach social workers usually encounter in their day-to-day practice, & to investigate how the outreach social workers respond to their clients' resistance with reference to case examples given in the in-depth interviews. The findings of this study provide evidence that whilst client resistance is common in the outreach social work setting, social workers' patience as well as sensitivity are essential in resolving resistance & building up a rapport with clients. Tables, References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Working+with+Involuntary+Clients%3A+Perceptions+and+Experiences+of+Outreach+Social+Workers+in+Hong+Kong&amp;rft.au=Chui%2C+Wing+Hong%3BHo%2C+Kit+Mui&amp;rft.aulast=Chui&amp;rft.aufirst=Wing&amp;rft.date=2006-07-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.spage=205&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530600776947

The Age-Shift: Observations on Social Policy, Ageism and the Dynamics of the Adult Lifecourse

Author: Biggs, Simon1; Phillipson, Chris; Money, Anne-Marie; Leach, Rebecca1 Instit Gerontology, King's Coll London, UK simon.biggs@kcl.ac.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61373256?accountid=14667

Abstract: Through a critical engagement with policy trends, we ask how shifts in ideologies of ageing might influence the possibilities available to adults as they grow older. Of particular interest are the implications for how people are being encouraged to think about the adult lifecourse. We address these questions by looking at policy development, taking the 2000-2005 period in the UK as a case example, & by comparing this period to wider regional & international trends. Finally, we assess the implications of contemporary policy, from a psychodynamic point of view, for the maintenance of a viable identity in later life & for intergenerational relationships. References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=The+Age-Shift%3A+Observations+on+Social+Policy%2C+Ageism+and+the+Dynamics+of+the+Adult+Lifecourse&amp;rft.au=Biggs%2C+Simon%3BPhillipson%2C+Chris%3BMoney%2C+Anne-Marie%3BLeach%2C+Rebecca&amp;rft.aulast=Biggs&amp;rft.aufirst=Simon&amp;rft.date=2006-11-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=239&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530600931708

____________________________________________________________

The Poverty of Older People in the UK

Author: Price, Debora11 Instit Gerontology, King's Coll London, UK debora.price@kcl.ac.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61386779?accountid=14667

Abstract: The quality of life of older people is markedly affected by their material resources & experience of income poverty. In 1997, almost a third of those past state pension age in the UK lived in poverty. Changes to benefits & payments to older people since the advent of a Labour government have on some measures reduced these poverty rates significantly. This article critically examines this claim, posing three substantive questions: what do these measurements of poverty rates among older people mean, who are the disadvantaged in old age, & what might the future of poverty in old age look like? Poverty rates are extremely sensitive to the measures used, & particular problems for older people such as depth of poverty & persistent poverty are disguised by headcount poverty rates. Among older people, gender, social class, age & marital status are important determinants of poverty. Following the Pensions Commission's report in November 2005, the government will introduce pension reforms that will have some impact on pensioner poverty decades in the future, but will have almost no impact on current pensioners, & little impact on those who will shortly become pensioners. Older people are institutionally marginalised in these reforms. Material disadvantage accumulates not only through socio-economic correlates & life events, but also because of age, generation & cohort. The failure by the current Labour government to undertake paradigmatic reform of the pension system means that these problems will persist into the future. Tables, Figures, References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=The+Poverty+of+Older+People+in+the+UK&amp;rft.au=Price%2C+Debora&amp;rft.aulast=Price&amp;rft.aufirst=Debora&amp;rft.date=2006-11-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=251&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530600931724

Exploring the Links between Spirituality and 'Successful Ageing'

Author: Sadler, Euan1; Biggs, Simon1 Instit Gerontology, King's Coll, London, UK euan.sadler@kcl.ac.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61390574?accountid=14667

Abstract: In this paper we examine the relationship between 'successful ageing' & spirituality. Whilst the former has received considerable attention both as a state & as a process, the latter has been virtually ignored as a source of well-being in later life. Here we critically examine the relationship between these two concepts, based on a review of the literature, & draw conclusions for policy & practice. References. Adapted from the source document.

Counseling Older People: What Can We Learn from Research Evidence?

Author: Hill, Andy; Brettle, Alison

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61384676?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper reports on a systematic review aimed at providing a reliable overview of the effectiveness, appropriateness & feasibility of counselling older people. Papers were located from a wide range of sources to ensure comprehensive coverage of the literature & 47 papers were included in the final review. The review concluded that counselling is efficacious with older people, particularly in the treatment of anxiety, depression & in improving subjective well-being. Evidence indicates that individual, as opposed to group counselling, is the psychological treatment of choice among the community-dwelling elderly & that this may be the more effective modality with this population. Group counselling for nursing home residents & home-based individual counselling for community-dwelling older people are both feasible modes of service delivery. A pro-active approach to the identification of psychological problems among residential & community-dwelling older people is necessary to ensure problems are not left untreated. Tables, Figures, References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Counseling+Older+People%3A+What+Can+We+Learn+from+Research+Evidence%3F&amp;rft.au=Hill%2C+Andy%3BBrettle%2C+Alison&amp;rft.aulast=Hill&amp;rft.aufirst=Andy&amp;rft.date=2006-11-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=281&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530600931807

The Distinction between Being and Feeling Frail: Exploring Emotional Experiences in Health and Social Care

Author: Grenier, Amanda11 School Social Work, McGill U, Montreal, Quebec Amanda.grenier@mcgill.ca

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61379918?accountid=14667

Abstract: The concept of frailty provides access to key health & social care services. While health care professionals charged with implementing standard assessments generally agree on what constitutes frailty, lay understandings make a crucial distinction between 'being' & 'feeling' frail. The distinction between the imposition of a medical/functional classification (being frail) & the emotions related to impairment, traumatic events, & maintaining a continuous identity (feeling frail) reveal how that which is commonly considered 'frailty' plays out within the everyday experiences lived in, & in relation to, the body & self. Older women's interpretations illustrate some of the conflicts & emotions within experiences of impairment, disability & decline -- showing how these are much more personal than we are led to believe by policies & practices focused on objective criteria & standard measurement. Further, they suggest that older women's identities & strategies are at least partly negotiated in relation to the experience of 'feeling' frail, that the identity & self may serve as a protective mechanism from 'becoming' frail, & the existence of a threshold between these two conditions. Understanding & addressing the emotional aspects of what professionals know as 'frailty' may improve the likelihood of appropriate professional responses to older persons. References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=The+Distinction+between+Being+and+Feeling+Frail%3A+Exploring+Emotional+Experiences+in+Health+and+Social+Care&amp;rft.au=Grenier%2C+Amanda&amp;rft.aulast=Grenier&amp;rft.aufirst=Amanda&amp;rft.date=2006-11-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=299&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530600931849

Psychoanalytically Informed Research in an NHS Continuing Care Unit for Older People: Exploring and Developing Staff's Work with Complex Loss and Grief

Author: Holman, Cheryl1; Meyer, Julienne; Davenhill, Rachael1 City U, St. Bartholomew School Nursing & Midwifery, London, UK

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61373413?accountid=14667

Abstract: There are studies about the emotional & social aspects of loss & grief in continuing care environments such as care homes & hospital wards, but researchers have tended to focus on either the cultural aspect of the organisation or the emotional response of individuals [Holman, C., Meyer, J. & Cotter, A. (2004) "The complexity of loss in continuing care institutions for older people: a review of the literature", Illness, Crisis and Loss, vol. 12, no. 1, pp. 38-51]. This splitting in the body of knowledge misses the opportunity to examine the link between the personal & the broader public domain [Williams, S. J. & Bendelow, G. (1996) "Emotions, health & illness: the missing link in medical sociology?", in Health and the Sociology of Emotions, eds V. James & J. Gabe, Blackwell Publications Ltd, Oxford]. This paper concerns the methodology & initial findings from a psychoanalytically informed research study. It was aimed deliberately at exploring the juncture between the psychological & social domains that care staff have to negotiate in order to provide care related to loss & grief in an NHS continuing care ward. The method draws heavily on the Tavistock approach to learning about emotions [Rustin, M. (2003) "Learning about emotions: the Tavistock approach", European Journal of Psychotherapy, Counselling and Health, vol. 6, no. 3, pp. 187-208] but also adopts participant observation methods rooted in the ethnographic tradition [Fielding, N. (2001) "Ethnography", in Researching Social Life, 2nd edition, ed. N. Gilbert, Sage Publications, London]. The study identifies the emotional demand of caring for people experiencing loss & grief in a continuing care unit & the development of a reflective group that supported practice developments in meeting these tasks. The paper will argue that research that develops an understanding of social practices underpinned by psychoanalytic perspectives can inform development in areas where staff are expected to cope with high levels of anxiety & stress. References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Psychoanalytically+Informed+Research+in+an+NHS+Continuing+Care+Unit+for+Older+People%3A+Exploring+and+Developing+Staff%27s+Work+with+Complex+Loss+and+Grief&amp;rft.au=Holman%2C+Cheryl%3BMeyer%2C+Julienne%3BDavenhill%2C+Rachael&amp;rft.aulast=Holman&amp;rft.aufirst=Cheryl&amp;rft.date=2006-11-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=315&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530600931872

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Psychoanalytically+Informed+Research+in+an+NHS+Continuing+Care+Unit+for+Older+People%3A+Exploring+and+Developing+Staff%27s+Work+with+Complex+Loss+and+Grief&amp;rft.au=Holman%2C+Cheryl%3BMeyer%2C+Julienne%3BDavenhill%2C+Rachael&amp;rft.aulast=Holman&amp;rft.aufirst=Cheryl&amp;rft.date=2006-11-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=315&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530600931872

Thinking about the Experience of Dementia: The Importance of the Unconscious

Author: Balfour, Andrew11 Tavistock & Portman NHS Trust, London, UK abalfour@tccr.org.uk

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61379325?accountid=14667

Abstract: This paper explores the challenge of comprehending the experience of dementia, & highlights the importance of understanding unconscious processes both at the level of the individual with dementia, & at the level of care-giving relationships in formal & informal settings. The contribution of insights from the research & clinical literature to understanding what may be happening at an unconscious level in dementia care settings is reviewed, & the implications for our understanding of the psychological needs of people with dementia & their carers are discussed. References. Adapted from the source document.

Psychodynamic Ideal Types of Elderly Suicidal Persons based on Counter Transference

Author: Lindner, R1; Fiedler, G; Altenhofer, A; Gotze, P; Happach, C1 U Hamburg-Eppendorf, Germany lindner@uke.uni-hamburg.de

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61379426?accountid=14667

Abstract: Suicidality among the elderly is a serious health & social problem. In contrast to the quantitative significance of suicidality in old age, utilisation of psychiatric & psychotherapeutic treatment by the suicidal elderly is low. Single case based knowledge of the intra-psychic dynamics of the suicidal elderly exists but this has mostly been gained from long-running psychotherapies, & not from people who remain silent about their suicidality, even during treatment. In a systematic qualitative study, in-depth interviews were conducted with 30 people (60+), who judged themselves as suicidal but had not talked about it in treatment. Using the method of 'forming types by understanding', ideal types were developed by means of the suicidal elderly's transference offers on the background of their main biographic accounts & their suicidal symptoms. This typology presents the suicidal elderly's varied & multi-reasoned dynamics of psychosocial retreat, which both encourage & maintain suicidality, also leading to the fact that these people keep silent about their suicidality in professional health care relationships, or they contribute to negative counter-transference reactions, which make the start of a therapeutic relationship difficult. Tables, References. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Psychodynamic+Ideal+Types+of+Elderly+Suicidal+Persons+based+on+Counter+Transference&amp;rft.au=Lindner%2C+R%3BFiedler%2C+G%3BAltenhofer%2C+A%3BGotze%2C+P%3BHappach%2C+C&amp;rft.aulast=Lindner&amp;rft.aufirst=R&amp;rft.date=2006-11-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=347&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530600932011

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=Psychodynamic+Ideal+Types+of+Elderly+Suicidal+Persons+based+on+Counter+Transference&amp;rft.au=Lindner%2C+R%3BFiedler%2C+G%3BAltenhofer%2C+A%3BGotze%2C+P%3BHappach%2C+C&amp;rft.aulast=Lindner&amp;rft.aufirst=R&amp;rft.date=2006-11-01&amp;rft.volume=20&amp;rft.issue=3&amp;rft.spage=347&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530600932011

RETHINKING AGENCY IN MEMORY: SPACE AND EMBODIMENT IN MEMORIES OF CHILD SEXUAL ABUSE

Author: Reavey, Paula1; Brown, Steven D1 Department of Psychology, London South Bank University, London SE1 OAA, UK

http://proxy.lib.umich.edu/login?url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/61403050?accountid=14667

Abstract: Contemporary 'forensic' models of memory emphasise the need for continuity and stability in relation to self-hood and identity and attention can be too readily focussed upon the 'literal' and 'accurate' recollections of past events. Such concerns, however, neglect the practical uses of remembering in specific contexts and moments in time. Attending to these practical uses of memory can enable a reading of the contradictory positions and ambivalences experienced by individuals aiming to make sense of a complex set of memories of child sexual abuse. Part of the reason these memories are experienced as highly complex is related to the ways in which such memories hold survivors accountable for not only the past, but present sexual actions, where management of choices take place. Drawing on Haaken's feminist transformative model of memory and Halbwach's ideas on group membership, we argue for a reworking of remembering by inviting an engagement with its relational, practical and collective qualities. Issues surrounding the organisation of social spaces in negotiating choices and agency, the localised contexts of remembering and the way in which the body is called on to manage these issues will form the basis of the analysis. Specific attention will also be given to how the past and present interrelate with regard to the management of adult survivor identities. Adapted from the source document.

Links: http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=RETHINKING+AGENCY+IN+MEMORY%3A+SPACE+AND+EMBODIMENT+IN+MEMORIES+OF+CHILD+SEXUAL+ABUSE&amp;rft.au=Reavey%2C+Paula%3BBrown%2C+Steven+D&amp;rft.aulast=Reavey&amp;rft.aufirst=Paula&amp;rft.date=2007-03-01&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=5&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530601173508

http://mgetit.lib.umich.edu/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;ctx_enc=info:ofi/enc:UTF-8&amp;rfr_id=info:sid/ProQ%3Asocialservicesshell&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.atitle=RETHINKING+AGENCY+IN+MEMORY%3A+SPACE+AND+EMBODIMENT+IN+MEMORIES+OF+CHILD+SEXUAL+ABUSE&amp;rft.au=Reavey%2C+Paula%3BBrown%2C+Steven+D&amp;rft.aulast=Reavey&amp;rft.aufirst=Paula&amp;rft.date=2007-03-01&amp;rft.volume=21&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.spage=5&amp;rft.isbn=&amp;rft.btitle=&amp;rft.title=Journal+of+Social+Work+Practice&amp;rft.issn=02650533&amp;rft_id=info:doi/10.1080%2F02650530601173508
